title: May 2, 2011
body:
This edition sponsored by:

Liquor Depot Has Exciting News

Liquor Depot (previously known as West Salem liquor) is under new ownership and management.

The GRAND OPENING for the new location (next door to current store) will be announced later this month. Come meet the new owners and managers and help us celebrate the exciting new changes.

As a new addition to the services, Liquor Depot is offering FREE delivery to businesses. Now open 7 days a week. Mon.-Thurs. 10 a.m-8 p.m., Fri.-Sat. 10 a.m.-9 p.m., and Sun. 11 a.m.-7 p.m.

The store is bringing in new and exciting spirits, mixers and gifts on a weekly basis. A new gift design program that allows you to choose your spirits and/or mixers for fun gift baskets or bags has been incorporated. The gifts are made to order and are available already assembled. Jazz up the your gifts with greeting cards and other creative gift items.

To keep up with our exciting changes or get ideas for drinks, gifts, or an upcoming party follow us on Facebook.

Liquor Depot
1144 Wallace Rd. NW
Salem, OR 97304
503-399-8554
liquordepotinc@gmail.com
www.myliquordepot.com

title: July 8, 2013
body:
Pondering where to stay and what to see and do while in Oregon's capital city and the region? Let these creative packages and specials make your stay an Absolutely wonderful experience.

  • Limited Time Offers
  • Year Round Packages & Specials
  • Local Discount & Deal Websites

Limited Time Offers

Dinner Escape Package
Oregon Garden Resort

Enjoy a romantic Dinner Escape Package at the Oregon Garden Resort! Package includes accommodation, two dinner entrees in our Garden View Restaurant, a bottle of house wine, a full American buffet breakfast and admission to The Oregon Garden, an 80-acre botanical garden. Starting at $109.

For reservations, call 800-966-6490 or visit www.oregongardenresort.com. Reservations based on availability. Not to be combined with other offers. Valid  through June 30, 2013. 800-966-6490 or 503-874-500. www.oregongardenresort.com

 

Movies in the Garden Package
Oregon Garden Resort

Enjoy a movie under the stars at The Oregon Garden on Thursday nights. Package includes movie tickets; a picnic of wine, breads and cheeses; a picnic blanket; admission to The Oregon Garden and a continental breakfast. Starting at $150.

For reservations, call 800-966-6490 or visit www.oregongardenresort.com. This package is available on Thursday nights, July 11th through August 29th. 503-874-2500 or 800-966-6490. www.oregongardenresort.com  

 

Year Round Packages & Specials

A Grand Romance Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

This wonderful package includes overnight accommodations for two in your choice of suite, champagne or cider, fresh flowers and our complimentary hot continental breakfast buffet. Enjoy a late checkout of 1 p.m.

 

For package pricing or to purchase this package, call 877-540-7800 or 503-540-7800 or visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Advanced Purchase Package

Phoenix Inn Suites South Salem

Are you a business traveler who has a packed calendar of obligations? If you have weekly or monthly travel requirements, you can take advantage of Phoenix Inn's Advanced Purchase Package. This package offers a discounted rate when you reserve a room at least 5 days in advance with payment paid in full with no refunds, cancellations or changes.

 

To purchase this package call 503-588-9220 or visit www.phoenixinnsuites.com. (Note: Advanced purchase packages can be booked online www.phoenixinnsuites.com and must be booked 5 days in advance.) This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Complimentary Reserve Tasting for Two

Willamette Valley Vineyards

Receive a complimentary reserve wine tasting for two at Willamette Valley Vineyards. Enjoy six of our award-winning, delicious and sustainable wines at our beautiful Estate Winery. Hours: 11 a.m.-6 p.m. daily.

 

To receive this deal, you must print a coupon by clicking here and bring it to Willamette Valley Vineyards. No expiration, coupon required. 503-588-9463 or 800-344-9463. www.wvv.com

 

Create Your Own Stay

Grand Hotel in Salem

Create your own stay! Choose one option or choose them all! From A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village to Special Romance Packages such as balloon rides, romantic dinner and flowers. Let your imagination run WILD!

 

To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Dinner and Movie Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Need a fun night out? Try this package on for size. Start your stay in a suite of your choice. Check in, relax and enjoy dinner at Bentley's Grill (a $75 value). Our on-site restaurant features the finest in Northwest cuisine and one of Willamette Valley's grandest wine selections. Movie passes for two await you in your room at check-in and are valid at any one of Salem's Regal Cinema movie theatres. In the morning, enjoy our complimentary continental breakfast buffet and a late checkout of 1 p.m.

To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

Explore the Waterfront Package
Shilo Inn Suites Salem

Package includes a one night stay at the Shilo Inn Suites in Salem, a gift certificate for 4 to A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village and 4 tokens for Salem's Riverfront Carousel. Package price: $92 plus tax (additional nights $79.95 plus tax).

To purchase this package call 800-222-2244 or visit www.shiloinns.com. Requires 48 hour notice and has no expiration date.

 

The Grand Wine Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Start your day with complimentary wine tasting at Willamette Valley Vineyards. Sample some of the Valley's most enological treasures. Continue your day with a self-guided tour of the Willamette Valley's many vineyards, and finally, a complimentary bottle of Willamette Valley Vineyards wine and an Oregon Wine Guide await you in your room of choice. The Grand Hotel in Salem wine glasses are yours to keep. In the morning, take advantage of our wonderful complimentary continental breakfast buffet. As a final touch, enjoy a late checkout of 1 p.m. Package pricing: Deluxe King - $169, Deluxe Double Queen - $179, King Suite - $189, Double Queen Suite - $199, Jacuzzi King Suite - $229. Additional tax to be added.

 

To purchase this package call 877-540-7800 or 503-540-7800 or visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's AAA Offer
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. $2 off admission by showing your AAA card.

To redeem this special, present your AAA card at the time of purchase. No expiration date. AAA card must be current. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's 1/2 Off Offer
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. 50% off admission for up to 4 with coupon from the Entertainment Book.

To redeem this special, present your Entertainment Book Coupon at the time of purchase. Expiration date is printed on the coupon. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's  National Trust for Historic Preservation Offer
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. $2 off admission with National Trust for Historic Preservation card.

 

To redeem this special, present your National Trust for Historic Preservation card at the time of purchase. No expiration date. National Trust for Historic Preservation card must be current. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's Online Coupon
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. $1 off admission when Jason Lee bucks are downloaded from www.WillametteHeritage.org and redeemed at the museum.

To redeem this special, present your Jason Lee bucks at the time of purchase. No expiration date. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Northern Lights Package
Shilo Inn Suites Salem

Package includes a one night stay at the Shilo Inn Suites in Salem and a $25 gift certificate good for movie tickets and food and beverages at Northern Lights Theatre Pub. Package price: $94.95 plus tax (additional nights $79.95 plus tax).

To purchase this package call 800-222-2244 or visit www.shiloinns.com. Requires 48 hour notice and has no expiration date.

 

Oregon Golf Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Enjoy a relaxing night in a suite of your choice before teeing off at the Salem Golf Club. Complimentary breakfast and a late checkout will no doubt assist you in a perfect game of golf for two.

To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Romance Package
Phoenix Inn Suites South Salem

We do the groundwork for your surprise and you get all of the credit! The Phoenix Inn Suites Romance Package includes a one night stay in our King Spa Suite. Your room will be adorned with truffles and sparkling cider. A $50 gift certificate for McGrath's Fish House is included in the package, as well as a late checkout of 1 p.m. Package price: $199.

To purchase this package, please call 503-581-7004 or visit www.phoenixinnsuites.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Salem Shopping Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Need a night away before a good day of shopping? Treat yourself to a night in a suite of your choice. A $50 Salem Center gift card, complimentary breakfast buffet, free parking and a late checkout of 1 p.m. top off this package, making your stay relaxing, enjoyable and fun!

To purchase this package, visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Local Discount & Deal Websites

Door to Door Savings Magazine/GoldStar Media

www.DoorToDoorSavings.com

title: April 9, 2015
body: This is a test item for a newsletter

title: Innovative Partnership between Travel Salem and Willamette Valley Vineyards
body:
Travel Salem is committed to strengthening the communities that it serves. In efforts to further enhance the vitality of our communities in the region, Travel Salem has introduced "Absolutely Giving Back."

Travel Salem holds various events throughout the year such as Marketing Exchange Luncheons, Team Salem meetings and special events. These activities involve hundreds of people and in an effort to "Absolutely Give Back" Travel Salem's staff and meeting attendees are encouraged to bring canned or non-perishable food items to these events. The contributions will be collected and donated quarterly to various local charities or aid organizations. Travel Salem will also be a collection point for new and used winter coats for children with distribution occurring as soon as possible to meet the immediate need of many shelters.

Upcoming opportunities to give back include a free international seminar with Travel Oregon's international marketing team held exclusively for Travel Salem members; and at upcoming social media seminars in November. Read the articles in this newsletter for more details about these meetings.

Join Travel Salem in our "Absolutely Giving Back" campaign!

title: Lunch-n-Learn
body:
Presented by: 

May 21, 2014
11:30am-1:30pm
Red Lion, Salem  
For owners, managers and customer service teams  

 Are you... 

Worried your business may be losing valuable customers due to poor customer service?
Concerned that some team members may be over-promising and under-delivering?
Experiencing "difficult" customers who then get passed off to management to "deal with" ?
Frustrated that customer issues may not be followed up with or tracked and measured for ensured success and resolution?
Unsure how to train all employees to meet customer expectations?
Eroding profits because your service team misses upselling opportunities? 

Strategic Customer Care: On the frontlines
In this time you'll learn how to help your customer service team: 

  • Establish trust with your customers
  • Up-sell and cross-sell 
  • Improve customer communication 
  • Nurture difficult people 
  • Better understand your customers
  • Differentiate your company 
  • Recognize defeating behavior 
  • Break through comfort zones 

FREE for Travel Salem members!
$45 for nonmembers (can be applied toward membership)

Join Marjorie Dudley with Flywheel, a Sandler Training company, for this action packed workshop.
RSVP to: Sue 503-581-4325 x22 by May 19 or email to: Snichols@TravelSalem.com 

Seating is limited ~ RSVP today!
Special lunch menu $9 per person. No outside food or drink, please.

title: "Absolutely Giving Back"
body:
Travel Salem will be holding several social media seminars beginning in November. Social media has quickly become a powerful tool that businesses and organizations are using to market themselves. The seminars will give participants the opportunity to learn about social networking tools that are changing the way businesses and organizations connect with consumers, and strategies on how to effectively utilize these tools.

Follow the link below for a short online survey to determine interest, content, scheduling, and the option to submit questions you may have about social media ahead of time.

http://www.surveymonkey.com/s.aspx?sm=jVyv_2b9ioIMEVDhxY9rFn2g_3d_3d

Exact dates and times to be announced soon. Contact Anthony Tham for additional information, 503-581-4325, ext. 25 or atham@TravelSalem.com.

title: "Last Call" to Lock in Your Advertisement
body:
This is the "last call" to lock in your advertisement for the 2012-13 Salem Area Visitor Guide. Ad sales will close Friday, March 9. Businesses interested in purchasing a display ad should contact Terra Moreland at terram@mediamerica.net or 503-445-8830.

The Salem Area Visitor Guide is the official visitor guide and resource for visitors to the Salem and mid-Willamette Valley. The guide is distributed to 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia and serves as the response piece to all Salem inquiries generated through Travel Salem's advertising, public relations and consumer engagement strategies.

  • Back to newsletter

title: "Last Call" to Lock in Your Advertisement
body:
Give Us Your Best Pitch!

Travel Salem is looking for your input regarding ideas for future articles, stories, and pitches that we can add to our "content library" for potential pitches and presentations to the media to encourage them to write about Salem and the surrounding area. In order to gather your input, we are hosting a "speed pitching" open house on Thursday, March 7. Anyone representing a Marion or Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. and share with us what's new or newsworthy at your organization.

What constitutes a "newsworthy" pitch? Basically, we're looking for ideas that are unusual, new and innovative. If your organization or business has recently launched - or is planning to launch - a new product, service, event, or program that is unique and of interest to a large audience (especially visitors), this is your chance to tell us about it!

Here's how it works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Travel Salem Travel Cafe Visitors Center (located at 181 High St. NE in downtown Salem) any time between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. on Thursday, March 7.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 10 minutes (minimum) to share their idea with a member of Travel Salem's marketing staff.
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it needs to occur in the late summer, fall or winter of 2013 or in 2014. (Most of the regional and national publications we target are working at least 6-9 months in advance).
  • We encourage you to bring a one-page summary of your pitch and/or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).
  • While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published. 

If you cannot attend "Speed Pitching" but would like to submit an idea, please do so through our online Public Relations Request Form.

Travel Salem will be evaluating this "Speed Pitching" opportunity and if it is successful, we will add more opportunities throughout the year. We look forward to hearing all of your creative ideas!

  • Back to newsletter

title: "Map Your Adventure" at the 2010 Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism
body:
We invite you to join your Oregon tourism and hospitality friends and colleagues at the 26th annual Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism, April 11-13, 2010 in Bend. Each spring Oregon's tourism and hospitality industry gathers to educate, share, and develop new ways to create the best Oregon experience possible for our visitors - and the industry itself.

The conference theme is Map Your Adventure -anopportunity for you to look ahead and strategically plot a course for your personal and professional life. Keynote presenters, educational workshops, networking, social and culinary events, and the annual industry awards are some of the opportunities you have to connect, or reconnect, with friends and industry partners as you explore and map out your own adventure.

Prepare to Map Your Adventure at the 2010 Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism. For details and to register, visit www.OregonTourismConference.com.

title: "Wintercation" in the Mid-Willamette Valley
body:
Travel Salem 101
January 31, 2013
3-4:30 p.m.
Travel Salem's Travel Cafe 

Join Travel Salem's staff for a free session to learn about advertising, consumer (visitor) marketing, customer service training, media and public relations, industry relations, niche markets, partnerships, Salem Visitors Guide, TravelSalem.com, research, visitor information and convention sales and service strategies.

Sessions are limited to 10 people, reservations are taken on a first come/first reserved basis. Reserve your seat by Tuesday, January 29th!

Contact Tara Preston at 503-581-4325 ext. 58 or tpreston@TravelSalem.com.

  • Back to newsletter

title: "Must See Oregon" Provides Showcase for Businesses
body:
The second annual Must See Oregon tourism showcase will be held at The Oregon Garden in Silverton on Saturday, May 16 from 10 a.m.to 4 p.m. Admission to the event is free with Oregon Garden admission. This state-wide event is in partnership with Travel Oregon, Travel Salem and The Oregon Garden; featuring destinations, attractions and activities all around Oregon. The goal is to encourage Oregonians to travel in Oregon and to provide information about travel opportunities in our own state. 

From outdoor adventures and resorts to craft brews and world" renowned wines, Oregon has it all. The state's vast array of attractions, destinations, travel, and extended vacation opportunities will be showcased at Must See Oregon, presented by Capitol Subaru and coordinated by Class Act Events. 

"There is no other showcase like this in Oregon," said Must See Oregon organizer Susan Adkins. "We have so many exciting opportunities in this state and you'll have one place to go for a glimpse of Oregon's best kept secrets."

Throughout the day, visitors will have opportunities to learn more about Oregon's treasures from over 40 Oregon destinations and attractions. Families can experience activities such as skiing demonstrations, geocaching and rock climbing, plus presentations from travel experts such as Steve Arndt, author of Roads Less Traveled in Oregon, to help with trip planning. Food and beverages avilable from Gilgamesh Brewing. Proceeds from Must See Oregon will benefit SMART and SKEF. A $2 donation is suggested.

For more information visit: www.MustSeeOr.com
Facebook: facebook.com/mustseeor
Twitter: @mustseeoregon
Instagram: instagram.com/mustseeoregon

Photo: The Oregon Garden ~ courtesy of The Oregon Garden

Back to newsletter

title: "Winter Party Planning" -- December First Wednesday at Travel Salem
body:
Everybody loves a party! At Travel Salem's Travel Cafe we are kicking off the holiday spirit at the December 7th First Wednesday with ideas to help you party your way through 2012. Visitors to the Travel Cafe will enjoy delicious treats from Trader Joe's; Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum will be showcasing their museum, IMAX and Wings and Waves Water Park with a special raffle; The Lodge at Detroit Lake is offering holiday special discounts; Chemeketa Center for Business and Industry will be on hand to share all the details regarding their state-of-the- art facility; and Willamette Valley Vineyards will be pouring their spectacular wines.

  • Chemeketa Center for Business and Industry (CCBI): CCBI representatives will be on hand to share the resources available to small business at their state-of-the-art facility (626 High St. NE) as well as their Bank of the Cascades, EDGE Business Incubator program. www.ccbi.chemeketa.edu
  • Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum: Evergreen will be revealing all of the fun and educational amenities of their campus including: the Aviation and Space Museums, IMAX and the Wings and Waves Water Park. Evergreen has festive events for the holidays and they will be raffling Museum tickets and have coupons for the water park. www.evergreenmuseum.org
  • The Lodge at Detroit Lake: The Lodge at Detroit Lake will be offering special holiday pricing ending December 14, 2011 at midnight. Promo code: TS1stWED. "Come and stay at our beautifully rebuilt hotel!!" www.lodgeatdetroitlake.com
  • Trader Joe's: They will have a delicious array of wonderful treats and sparkling juices. Just perfect to serve at your next party. www.traderjoes.com
  • Willamette Valley Vineyards: Come sip award-winning, sustainable wines! www.wvv.com

Contribute to Travel Salem's "Absolutely Giving Back" program by dropping off a canned and non-perishable food item.

  • Return to newsletter

title: 11-12 Annual Report & 12-13 First Quarter Report
body:
The holiday season is in full swing and if you're still on the hunt for great gift ideas, consider a gift from one of our area nonprofit organizations. Not only will you find thoughtful presents for friends and family, but your purchase will help support our community's best nonprofit arts, heritage and service organizations.

Art enthusiasts will be delighted with the Hallie Ford Museum of Art "Experience the Arts" package, which combines visual, theatre and musical performances into one unique gift. The special package includes a one-year family/dual membership to the museum, two tickets to a Grace Goudy Distinguished Artists Series concert, and two tickets to a Willamette University Theatre production - all for $100.

For the kid on your list - or for anyone who relishes the opportunity to act like one - head over to Salem's Riverfront Carousel and pick up a $20 punch card, which is valid for 18 rides. The Carousel's colorful gift shop also offers whimsical and unique gifts for kids and adults. What's more, you can enjoy free Carousel rides on Christmas and New Year's Day between 1 p.m. and 4 p.m. with a canned food donation to Marion-Polk Food Share.

For theater goers, consider a gift certificate to the Pentacle Theatre. Certificates are available in any dollar amount and can be used toward the purchase of tickets to any of the theatre group's 2013 productions. Upcoming plays include the wacky musical Willy Wonka and Incorruptible, a comedy by Michael Hollinger.

If you're looking for a last minute gift for your pet, stop by Davenport's Den, the pet supply store located inside Willamette Humane Society. Named after a cat who resided in the shelter for many years, Davenport's offers toys, treats, and pet-related gift items. Proceeds from store sales support shelter pets.

Who wouldn't enjoy receiving a one-year membership or a set of day passes to the Salvation Army Ray & Joan Kroc Community Center? With an aquatics program, library, gymnasium, fitness center, and art studio, this local gem offers year-round activities to suit a wide variety of interests.

If a green-thumbed gardener is on your list, he or she will surely "dig" a membership to The Oregon Garden. Members receive free admission to The Garden all year long as well as discounts on any purchases in The Garden's gift shop, Cafe, Moonstone spa, The Oregon Garden restaurant and the resort.

History buffs will appreciate a membership to any one of our area's museums or historical societies. The Independence Heritage Museum displays the history and culture of the river town of Independence and surrounding areas. Museum memberships can be purchased online, making gift giving easy and convenient.

For hip and affordable arts and crafts by regional artisans, check out the ArtMarket exhibit at the Bush Barn Art Center. Sales from the second annual exhibition benefit the Salem Art Association's Community Arts Education (CAE) program. ArtMarket is open through December 24.

For more information - including deals and packages that would also make great gifts this season - visit Travelsalem.com.

~Originally published December 13, 2012 on Travel Salem's blog on StatesmanJournal.com by Angie Morris.

title: 12-13 Second Quarter Report
body:
You're invited to join your Oregon tourism and hospitality industry friends and colleagues at the 2013 Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism, April 14-16, 2013 at the Salem Convention Center.

Oregon loves dreamers, and the focus for the 2013 conference is on the great people, past and present, who have made Oregon an innovative place to do business. From adventurous souls rolling toward the Willamette Valley on wagon trains to elected leaders preserving Oregon's landscapes to today's entrepreneurs transforming our state into a thriving destination for technology, creativity and adventure - Oregon's residents illuminate a model of new thinking.

We look forward to seeing you for three days of networking, and immersion in the travel and tourism industry's best practices. Join more than 400 creative industry professionals to learn more about marketing, destination development, international marketing and sales and leadership training at Oregon's premier tourism and hospitality event.

 

View Event Summary

View Event Agenda & Workshops

Click to Register

title: 2012 Nation-wide Adventurecation Promotion
body:
If you haven't already met Travel Salem's Golden Pioneer, we'd like to introduce you to our pal Sal, everybody's favorite guy because he is part of Travel Salem's Golden Pioneer Giveaway, where visitors and folks in the community can win freebies if they log onto Travel Salem's Facebook page. People have to "guess where the Golden Pioneer is," in a kind of Where's Waldo fashion or participate in other Travel Salem contests which change monthly.

Borrow Sal for the Day!

As members, you have the opportunity of taking Sal out for a day and using him to help promote your event or business or market your products!

Sal is open to creative suggestions! The sky's the limit, literally, as Sal has flown in a hot air balloon with Balloon Flying Service of Oregon! He made it to Ladies' Night at Bentley's Grill and went cycling at JoyRide Cycling Studio. He visited the pets at the Willamette Humane Society, helped at a rally at the State Capitol, worked as a referee at an athletic game to promote breast cancer awareness and was even on television helping promote A. C. Gilbert's Discovery Village.

Sal also hopes you'll consider giving away a prize, free tickets to your event or gift certificate that we can giveaway in connection with the Golden Pioneer Giveaway. Tell us what kind of promotion you'd like to do. Would you like more BUZZ on your Facebook site? Would you like to give free coffee to the first 10 people who show up at your location at a certain time? Would you like to create a fun video to broadcast on Youtube of Sal at your event/business?

We encourage you to plan a "photo shoot" with our celebrity Sal. After you take fun photos, please send us the photos and captions that explain what Sal was up to. For more information contact Kathie Reeves at kreeves@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 24.

  • Back to newsletter

title: 2013 Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism
body:
Travel Salem Seeks Story Ideas

Give Us Your Best Pitch!

Travel Salem is looking for your input regarding ideas for future articles, stories, and pitches that we can add to our "content library" for potential pitches and presentations to the media to encourage them to write about Salem and the surrounding area. In order to gather your input, we are hosting a "speed pitching" open house on Thursday, March 7. Anyone representing a Marion or Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. and share with us what's new or newsworthy at your organization.

What constitutes a "newsworthy" pitch? Basically, we're looking for ideas that are unusual, new and innovative. If your organization or business has recently launched - or is planning to launch - a new product, service, event, or program that is unique and of interest to a large audience (especially visitors), this is your chance to tell us about it!

Here's how it works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Travel Salem Travel Cafe Visitors Center (located at 181 High St. NE in downtown Salem) any time between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. on Thursday, March 7.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 10 minutes (minimum) to share their idea with a member of Travel Salem's marketing staff.
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it needs to occur in the late summer, fall or winter of 2013 or in 2014. (Most of the regional and national publications we target are working at least 6-9 months in advance).
  • We encourage you to bring a one-page summary of your pitch and/or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).
  • While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published. 

If you cannot attend "Speed Pitching" but would like to submit an idea, please do so through our online Public Relations Request Form.

Travel Salem will be evaluating this "Speed Pitching" opportunity and if it is successful, we will add more opportunities throughout the year. We look forward to hearing all of your creative ideas!

title: 2015 GOLD 16U National Championship Heads West to Salem
body:
The Amateur Softball Association (ASA) of America and USA Softball announced that the 2015 ASA/USA Girls' 18-Under and 16-Under Fast Pitch GOLD National Championships, two of the most prominent tournaments in Junior Olympic (JO) play, will be hosted by the Oregon ASA. The 16U GOLD, which will be held in Salem, Ore., and the 2015 18U GOLD, which will be held in Hillsboro, Ore., are slated for July 19-25, 2015.

Known as the "Softball Capital of the Northwest", Salem, Ore. will host the 16U GOLD at Wallace Marine Park. The complex features five playing fields and is the original star designed complex in the nation. Wallace Marine Park Softball Complex opened in 1986 and was renovated in  2007, when the City of Salem Public Works Recreation Services took over running the park full time. The infields and outfields were also refurbished in 2012 after the complex was completely flooded. All fields at the complex are lighted, have scoreboards and bleacher seating, with Les Schwab Championship Stadium Field as the main field for championship games. The complex sits at the edge of the beautiful Willamette River and is a short walk across the pedestrian walking bridge to Salem's Riverfront Park which sits on the edge of Salem's vibrant downtown. 

"Salem looks forward to welcoming the 2015 16U ASA/USA GOLD participants, their families and the high caliber of play during the tournament," said Mayor of Salem Anna Peterson. "Salem is a major softball City and our partnership with this tournament is proof that Salem and softball go hand in hand."

As the capital city, Salem offers visitors a variety of restaurants, attractions and historic sites and museums. Rich with historic sites, tax-free shopping, museums, galleries, parks, wineries and outdoor recreation, Salem offers several historic properties and attractions that are located within walking distance of downtown. The city has a long history with ASA/USA Softball and has hosted 21 ASA/USA National Championships, including the 2003 18U GOLD National Championship and five girls' fast pitch Western Territory National Championships. This year Salem, also known as Softball City USA, hosted the ASA/USA Girls' Fast Pitch 10U and 12U Class A Western National Championship July 27-August 3, 2014, and the Men's Slow Pitch Class D Western National Championship August 30-September 1, 2014.

"It is an honor to host the 2015 16U ASA/USA GOLD in Salem," said Debbie McCune, director of sales for Travel Salem, Marion and Polk Counties' destination marketing organization. "In Salem we recognize the tremendous dedication it takes from the players to get to this level, and Travel Salem will do everything in our power to make sure this an experience that the players and their families will never forget."

title: 25 Fields for Oregon
body:
25 fields for Oregon is a registered nonprofit that recently signed an agreement to purchase 195 acres in the Central Willamette Valley just north of Salem/Keizer to build a premier youth field sports park. Upon opening, planned for 2014, this park will boast the highest quality natural grass multi-sport playing surfaces in the country and will match FIFA (Federation International Football Association) standards and regulations.

The bigger vision and the ultimate goal of 25 fields for Oregon is to support field development and scholarships throughout the state of Oregon as a philanthropic organization; granting funds and lending expertise and guidance to youth organizations in need of quality field sites. This is a singularly special opportunity for Oregon's youth sports to fund themselves.

To learn more about 25 Fields for Oregon visit www.25fields.org.

  • Back to newsletter

title: 5 ways to warm up on a fall day
body:
The air is cool, fog rolls in, and the leaves begin dressing in fantastic colors. It's that time of year again when we slow down and wander in search of warm places to settle into. Travel Salem wants to help you up your coziness quotient this time of year, so here's a few ideas to help you do just that.

  1. Sip Soup. Try one of the fresh stewed soups at Willamette Noodle Co., including tomato basil, sausage and red pepper or creamy carrot. Or, if you're in a mood to socialize, order a bowl from the bar at Wild Pear Restaurant, where you're sure to strike up a conversation with another happy soup sipper. Try anything with chicken broth and spice or their signature coconut curry squash accompanied soup with bread baked fresh daily from dough ordered from a famous San Francisco bakery.
  2. Gaze at Art. Next, walk to bug heaven, Pheromone Gallery, to see wonders of the natural world fashioned in artistic ways by artist Christopher Marley. Check out Solar Ellipse, Southern American butterflies arranged in a winged circle that resemble a lemon and apricot-colored flower in bloom. Or create your own artwork. Paint a ceramic platter or fuse color and heat together by making a vibrant glass trivet or lamp shade at the Create a Memory studio. Or stop in at Greenbaum's Quilted Forest to buy fabric to quilt or sew with; just walking into the store is a feel-good experience, you'll be enveloped in quilts that hang from the ceiling and walls.
  3. Indulge in wine and chocolate. On Friday nights, head over to Grand Vines to listen to sultry jazz and sip Oregon port between sampling chocolates in exotic flavors such as currant and East African spices, salty caramel, black cherry pinot, chili, coconut, toasted hazelnut and guinness. On a cold day, try the truffle-flavored hot buttered rum. Swing by Travel Salem's Travel Cafe for a wine tasting and to view the framed pastel artwork that inspired the upcoming Oregon Wine Country License Plate. Buy a raffle ticket for $5 and enter to win the work of art.
  4. Swig cider. Take a toasty seat beside the coffee bean roaster inside The Governor's Cup Coffee Roasters. Order a whipped cream-covered latte with pumpkin spice or a steaming cup of fresh-pressed hot cider from E.Z. Orchards, available in caramel through Christmas.
  5. Get pampered. Slip into a robe that's as soft as a cloud, warm up in a sauna then finish with a deep-tissue massage from Today's Hair Salon and Spa in West Salem. Or for a quick relaxation treatment, spend 10 minutes in an Aqua Massage machine at Hydro Zen, a new business on Court Street where you lay face down and feel water pressure massage you from head to toe (and stay dry and clothed in the process).

To see images from Travel Salem's cool weather, warm-up stops in Salem, go to Travel Salem's Facebook page at www.facebook.com/TravelSalem.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 10/23/11

  • Back to newsletter

title: AbFab Award Winners
body:
Travel Salem announced the recipients of this year's Absolutely Fabulous awards at the fourth annual "Ab Fab" Awards Luncheon, held Thursday, May 18, at the Salem Convention Center.

The "Ab Fab" awards recognize tourism industry partners who go above and beyond to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers who turned ideas upside down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaborations, partnerships and strategies. 

Travel Salem recognized six business partners for their outstanding commitment to the tourism industry in 2012-13: 

The Absolutely "Mega Minds" Award was presented to Salem Business Computers for the round-the-clock IT support that the company provides to Travel Salem, which helps ensure that visitors, journalists, meeting planners, tour operators and residents have online access to trip planning information 24 hours a day. 

Adelman Peony Gardens received the Absolutely Brilliant Award for turning their passion for growing peonies into a successful business and beautiful display garden that draws visitors from around the globe each year. 
The Absolutely "Going the Distance" Award went to Kurt and Erica Haas and the NW Tandem Rally for bringing the group's 27th annual rally to Salem in 2012, which brought more than 700 cyclists to the area over a three-day period and infused $294,000 into the region. 
The new Hampton Inn & Suites was presented with the Absolutely "Heads in Beds" Award for their impeccable customer service and for investing $9.5 million into the industry during a recession, which also generated 30 jobs. 
For their devotion to the art of craft brewing and engaging multiple generations of their family to build an outstanding new visitor attraction, Gilgamesh Brewing received the Absolutely "Gilga Generation" Award.
The Absolutely Fabulous Award was presented to the new Oregon State Hospital Museum of Mental Health and the dedicated volunteers who worked to catalog the museum's vast collection of artifacts, gather stories, raise funds and open the museum.

title: Advertise in the 2014 Visitor Guide!
body:
They say 30 is the new 20.  Well we certainly don't want to go back 10 years - we've come so far! Whether you know us as the Salem Metropolitan Area Convention and Tourism Association (SMACTA) or Salem Convention & Visitors Association (SCVA) or Travel Salem; the fact is your destination marketing organization is celebrating its 30th year in 2014.

SMACTA was formed in 1984 by Salem's lodging establishments who wanted to see tourism strengthen, grow and prosper in the Salem area. Their goal was to see the tourism industry recognized as an economic development generator and to establish a self-imposed fee to fund the promotion of the Salem area as a visitor, convention and event destination.

Thirty years, and two name changes later, Travel Salem continues to serve as the marketing and public relations arm for Salem as well as Marion and Polk counties.

To thank our many partners for years of support and collaboration we have created a commemorative 30 year anniversary poster. These posters were made possible by Salem Electric, who has been a member of Travel Salem since 1984 and are FREE to each member. 

If you would like a copy of the poster please stop by the Travel Salem office (181 High Street NE) or pick one up at any of our Marketing Exchange Luncheons throughout the year.

Local businesses have benefitted from the results-oriented marketing opportunities that Travel Salem provides its partners. Check out our list of Current & Renewing Members. If you are not on the list, please call us today! We are ready to help you take advantage of all the marketing tools and resources available through Travel Salem, including our quarterly Marketing Exchange Luncheons that provide networking and industry highlighted speakers.

If you know a business interested in partnering to promote the region's lucrative $511.3 million tourism industry that employs 6,290 people, please contact Sue Nichols, Travel Salem's Community Development Director at 503-581-4325, ext. 22 or snichols@TravelSalem.com.

We would like to thank all CURRENT, NEW, and RENEWING members for their continued investment in Travel Salem and the Tourism Industry.  We look forward to working hard for you and your businesses this coming year. 


Thank you and happy anniversary to our Mid-Willamette Valley visitor industry!

title: ALERT! Advertising Confusion
body:
Members of Travel Salem have recently called to inquire about a company, Ad Ventures, that is selling advertisements for a "Relocation Guide." Neither Travel Salem nor the Salem Chamber of Commerce is affiliated with Ad Ventures and is not producing a Relocation Guide.

Travel Salem's official publication is the Salem Area Visitors Guide (including Marion and Polk Counties) which will be printed in January 2010 and advertising sales have closed.

Travel Salem will continue to communicate any advertising opportunities to our members. We encourage you to check with Irene Bernards, Travel Salem's marketing director, if any company tells you they are working with Travel Salem, or that their information will be distributed through the Travel Cafe or other statewide locations.

Irene Bernards, 503-581-4325, ext.27or ibernards@TravelSalem.com.

title: Become a Bike Friendly Business  and Enhance Your Exposure to Bicyclists
body:
Oregon loves bicyclists. Bicycle-related tourism contributes $400 million to Oregon's economy - approximately $1.1 million per day. Your business may be able to tap into this growing segment of Oregon's economy by participating in Travel Oregon's Bike Friendly Business program. The program is free and will give tourism-related businesses special recognition through Travel Oregon's marketing channels, including RideOregonRide.com, Oregon's premier website promoting bicycle travel and TravelOregon.com, Oregon's official travel website. title: BMW Motorcycle Owners of America Event
body:
The BMW Motorcycle Owners of America ("MOA) will be holding its 2013 International Rally July 18-20, 2013, at the Oregon State Fairgrounds.

The BMW Motorcycle Owners of America was formed in April of 1972 as an all volunteer organization. The goal of the club is to promote the camaraderie and friendship of individual members and BMW motorcycle clubs. Since 1972 the BMW MOA has grown to be the largest brand specific motorcycle club in the world.

As the 'MOA has grown, attendance at the rally has grown as well, now averaging over 9000 like-minded riders. The rally site rotates throughout North America; previous rallies have been held in Montana, Colorado, Oregon, Illinois, New York, Connecticut, Tennessee and Trenton, Ontario. The rally is a great place to meet wonderful people as well as visit with vendors who manufacture many specialty items for BMWs. BMW Motorrad is a fixture at the annual rally, often bringing along over four dozen motorcycles which are available for guided test rides. The Rally also features over 100 seminars and classes.

The BMW MOA International Rally routinely generates $4 to $6 million in revenue for the local area in which is takes place. 

If you'd like to offer any specials or discounts for your business during the rally please contact Tara Preston at 503-581-4325 ext. 58 or tpreston@TravelSalem.com.

title: Calling all Wrestling Fans: Oregon State Fair Expo Center Hosts the West Coast World Championship for K-8 Wrestlers
body:
SALEM, ORE. -- Travel Salem is pleased to announce the Oregon State Fair Expo Center will host the 2nd annual Rocky Mountain National's West Coast World Championship on December 10th and 11th at the Expo Center at 2330 17th street in Salem at 8:30 a.m. The event is one of the highest profile K-8th grade wrestling competitions in the West Coast region and the venue offers competitions held on 10 mats throughout the center with a seating capacity of 4,000 spectators.

Last year, over 500 athletes competed from across the Western U.S. including members of several mat clubs from Marion and Polk counties. Participating clubs this year include the Dallas Mat Club, Team Aggression and Salem Elite Mat Club, among others.

The competition is a rare opportunity for elementary-aged youth to get a taste for competing against some of the best youth wrestlers in the West at an event judged by certified High School wrestling referees. This is the second year the Oregon State Fair Expo Center hosted the event.

"We can look forward to building something very special for the great people in Oregon our second time around," said Ed Gutierrez, director of Rocky Mountain Nationals events. "Oregon offers up some of the best wrestling in the country and we want to complement what they are already doing, but add a different flavor. We adopted the slogan to inspire, encourage and recognize these kids. It's inspiring to see these little guys compete. We make the competition more than an event, but an unforgettable weekend."

Mat clubs can enter their wrestling teams online for $36.00 before Sunday, December 5 at midnight. If a wrestler does not make weight, he can pay another registration fee of $20 to declare another weight. Late registration is $56 at weigh-ins.

To volunteer for the event contact Debbie McCune at 503-581-4325 ext. 28 or email her at dmmcune@TravelSalem.com. RMN needs help organizing, distributing information and awards, setting up, tearing down and coordinating things throughout the day.

For participants- Weigh-ins begin on December 10th from 4 to 7 p.m. in the arena of the Expo Center.

General admission to the event is $12. Receive a $2 discount when you bring in a can of food to donate to the Marion-Polk Food Share.

Rocky Mountain Nationals (RMN) is a youth wrestling program based in Colorado which provides opportunity for youth to participate in wrestling championships which encourages their development not only as athletes but as students as well. Involvement with wrestling and sports in general has been shown to increase youths' self esteem, confidence, and social skills. For more information, visit www.rockymountainnationals.com or contact Ed Gutierrez at 303-635-1549.

title: Create a recreational 'bucket list' of sorts
body:
I recently floated the Santiam River, courtesy of North Santiam River Trips, with a group of adrenaline junkies from Travel Salem, the Statesman Journal and Travel Oregon. The day was filled with adventure and surprises as we connected with nature and a few wild rapids.

I quickly learned that first is not always best when rafting. I was the human "Sham-Wow" towel at the bow of our raft, while the rest of the crew was safely shielded by my "exuberance" to be first.

My next adventure took me to Black Rock Mountain Biking facility in Polk County, near Dallas. Nestled in a lush, old-growth forest, this mountain bike course is not for wimps. Built by mountain bike enthusiasts and maintained by the honor system, this track attracts serious international and domestic off-road bikers.

My senses were heightened during my ride. The sights, sounds, smells of the forest, and taste of the earth as I paid homage to the "deity of dirt," made this physical experience truly memorable. No cars, no crowds, no clutter - just me and the trail.

After my ride, I realized that even at my age I was still able to "shred it," and that I live in a spectacular area with diverse and abundant recreational opportunities all close to home.

My recreational "bucket list" still has plenty on it such as: snowshoeing through Opal Creek; soaking in the geothermal hot springs at Breitenbush; a hot air balloon ride with Balloon Flying Service; and catching that illusive Santiam River salmon, in the third swirling eddy, to the right of the petrified fallen fir tree, at mile three of the float. However, jet skiing on the Willamette River sounds good too"_so many choices!

Visit the Travel Salem Travel Cafe Visitor Center at 181 High Street NE in historic downtown Salem to create your own recreational "bucket list." TravelSalem.com

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 7/18/10

title: Delicious Summer Staycation Ideas!
body:
Summer has arrived! The season of fun! It's a great time to plan "staycations" close to home with family and friends: barefoot backyard BBQ's, trolling on Detroit lake, live music at Salem's Riverfront Park or days spent wine tasting through our region's vineyards. I'd love to suggest a wonderful itinerary for those seeking adventure close to home. Don't underestimate how relaxing a night away from home can be; book a room at the Grand Hotel in Salem where you can crawl into a perfect bed and not worry about making the bed when you wake. When the sun comes up, take a Salem Bicycle Taxi ride through Salem's Riverfront Park and over the Union Street Railroad Pedestrian & Bicycle Bridge. Ride it to Historic Deepwood Estate or the Bush House Museum to wander their gardens. For lunch, plan a picnic with supplies from a farm stand like E.Z. Orchards Farm Market: pints of blueberries, Italian olive oils, fine chocolates and a bottle of their champagne-like "Hard Cidre" made from French apple varieties you might find in Northern France. Or order a dish of berry or peach shortcake with loads of whipped cream!

Pick up a pre-made picnic lunch created by Chef Karo Thom of Alcyone Cafe & Catering, who makes to-die-for curried chicken and golden raisin salad or a wrap with prosciutto and mint, order some smoked salmon from Smokin' Mike's Seafood Delights and mini pies from Willamette Valley Fruit Company and drive to Van Duzer Vineyards where you can spread out a colorful tablecloth, buy a bottle of Winemaker Jerry Murray's famous Pinot Gris and eat up! Bring along a kite, the Vineyard is situated in a special wind corridor, and when the breeze picks up, unfurl your kite into the sky to enjoy the same wind the raptors like to ride in the late afternoon. If you're in the mood to pair nature with wine, make a bee-line to Left Coast Cellars, to see beehives dotting the vineyard (wild bees they've collected from their native oak trees) and walk their newly-developed 9-mile trail system while you enjoy Winemaker Luke McCollom's own Pinot Noir and eat carrot cake with buttery frosting from their onsite cafe. Want to learn about the intricacies of pairing wine and food?  Invite a guest to your picnic: Byron Williams, owner of Grand Cru Wine Tours, is an expert on what wines to pair with local cheeses and dishes. He'll bring the food and the wine along- you just pick the location!

Or head over to Willamette Valley Vineyards (WVV), order a dessert from their onsite restaurant and a bottle of delicious semi-sparkling Muscat-Frizzant' (of the same requested for a special dinner hosted by former President Clinton) and sit on their veranda overlooking a Burgundy-esque valley of vineyards and farms below. If Gilgamesh Brewing Company is hosting one of their down-home brewing parties, leave WVV and follow the smell of sweet, yeasty hops to Gilgamesh's wooded brewery in Turner where they make experimental brews like their springy, mint kolsch. If you want the best of what's seasonal but don't want to do the foraging and cooking yourself, reserve a table at the Silver Grille in Silverton this month. Jeff Nizlek painstakingly prepares unforgettable dinners from scratch (he even makes his own salumi). Try his perfect summer salad of strawberries and candied hazelnuts or a chilled tomato soup that's as sweet as candy. If you're not ready to go home yet, drive into the wilderness and stay at the secluded Elkhorn Valley Inn Bed and Breakfast where you'll feel like you've left the world behind.

There is so much adventure right in our neck of the woods, it would be a shame if you drove right past! Plan your next adventure right in our greater Salem area! For ideas to create other  Staycation itineraries, visit Travel Salem's newly-refreshed website: www.TravelSalem.com.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 7/31/11

title: Don"t Miss the Parade of Sweetness!
body:
As summer fades and the days shorten, Willamette Valley hosts one of the most colorful yet under-the-radar events of the year. The event isn't formally announced but is possibly Oregon's oldest celebration, going on without fail and fanfare for years. . . it's the annual fall HARVEST, coming to you LIVE from a farm near you!

During the harvest, Willamette Valley comes alive and puts on its true colors: crisp yellow of apples, plump orange of pumpkins, sugary-sweet red of tomatoes and indigo of grapes ready for the winepress. Sure, it's nothing as flashy as a parade of floats, but harvest time is a wonderful parade for the taste buds!

It's easy to seek adventure beyond our borders, but any foodie worth their salt knows they need to appreciate what's right in front of their nose first. Instead of booking a flight to culinary capitals like Italy or Southern France, delve deeper into the culinary treasures in our own backyard: visit Prudence Uncorked (www.prudenceuncorked.com) to taste Oregon wild mushrooms on the menu. Save money on a Provence cheese tour, stop at Willamette Valley Cheese Company (www.wvcheeseco.com) and munch on award-winning Herb de Provence Havarti. No need to fly to the East Coast for apple cider to swig down with a homemade donut stop by E.Z. Orchards Farm Market (www.ezorchards.com) to get both. Or, if you like your cider hard, try Wandering Aengus' (www.wanderingaengus.com) brews made in the American cider tradition. Pick up a loaf of old-world sourdough at the Bread Board Bakery (www.thebreadboard.net) in Falls City.

Consider making the Salem area's agritourism hotspots the highlight of a trip, not just the side attraction. Our farms, orchards, wineries, breweries, restaurants, bakeries and artisan-crafted food stops are truly national and international treasures. For information about the area's agritourism destinations, visit www.TravelSalem.com.

Help Promote Oregon Bounty - Travel Oregon's Fall Travel Promotion, Oregon Bounty, is underway! 

Oregon Bounty kicked off August 23rd with this year's theme Oregon Bounty Wanderfeast. The campaign features ten chefs, over ten weeks, pursuing ten tastes they're crazy about, including wine, seafood, artisan spirits, mushrooms, craft brews and more. Go here to read an overview of the promotion and the "Win an Oregon Bounty Wanderfeast" contest.

Oregon Bounty is a million dollar campaign with an estimated 52 million impressions delivered to consumers in our target markets. New this year, we will feature interactive, expanding banner ads on culinary, travel, lifestyle and local websites like Sunset, Trip Advisor, Facebook, Yelp, Frommer's, OregonLive.com, SeattleTimes.com, SacBee.com and SFGate.com. All drive traffic to the redesigned culinary website, TravelOregon.com/bounty.

We created a marketing toolkit to help you draw upon the campaign to amplify your local marketing efforts. View the toolkit here. To make this promotion as successful as it can be, we encourage you to use the tools provided for your own consumer outreach. Together we can increase Oregon's overall share of voice and get folks traveling to and within our state.

The toolkit provides a variety of opportunities to customize the campaign for your own marketing efforts. We encourage you to:

  • Place a banner ad and Oregon Bounty logos on your website (starting Aug. 23)
  • Publish an e-newsletter article in your existing consumer communication pieces (starting Aug. 23)
  • Embed the Wanderfeast videos on your website (the first videos will be at youtube.com/TravelOregon starting Sept. 12)
  • Tweet and update your Facebook profile (please use #ORBounty as your hashtag); you can also retweet Travel Oregon posts
  • Encourage other businesses to use these tools

All the materials you need are provided in the toolkit. You will find other resources and news about Oregon Bounty as it happens on our dedicated news room page at TravelOregon.mediaroom.com.

For support in working with media interested in Oregon Bounty, please contact Michelle Godfrey at 503-378-8861 or Michelle@TravelOregon.com.

Otherwise, if you have questions about Oregon Bounty or the toolkit please contact Amy Nyberg at 503-378-8801 or Amy@TravelOregon.com.

Thank you very much for your support of Oregon Bounty.

title: Don"t Waste a Good Recession
body:
The downturn in the economy is forcing companies to examine budgets and reduce costs to compensate for a decrease in sales and overall business. Marketing, a vital investment, is one area frequently sacrificed during cost-cutting times. While it's important to be practical in your spending, a recession is no time to cut back on marketing.

Read the entire article that was published in the Sunday Statesman Journal.

title: Don't Miss the 2013 Salem Visitor Guide
body:
While temperatures hover near zero in many other parts of the country throughout the winter, our temperate climate means we generally experience much milder weather here in the Salem area. Yes, it's rainy, but with the right gear and attitude, we can enjoy the beauty of the great outdoors during the winter months. So, grab your rain gear, seize your sense of adventure, and plan a "wintercation" in the mid-Willamette Valley.

For an authentic Northwest adventure this winter, head to the Detroit Lake Recreation Area. Located in the heart of the Willamette National Forest, much of the 3,500 acre area is accessible year round. If you like to hike or snow shoe, you'll enjoy many miles of trails that lead through misty old growth forests and snow-covered clearings. Detroit Lake is also open to boaters in winter months. A winter boat ramp was constructed in 2009 at Mongold State Park, making it possible to launch a boat safely during the winter months when other ramps in the lake are on dry ground. Also located just a few miles east of Detroit is the McCoy Creek snowmobile area, featuring 60 miles of well-maintained trails and even a designated snowmobile shelter.

If you're heading to Detroit, plan to stay overnight at The Lodge at Detroit Lake. Renovated in 2010, these cozy cabins offer the best of both worlds: a rustic lodge feel and modern amenities including flat screen TV's, gas fireplaces, and in-room Wi-Fi. Soothe your muscles after a day of hiking or snowshoeing with a hot bath in a jetted tub, which comes standard in every room. And if you forget to bring your toothbrush, don't worry. Mountain High Grocery & Gifts is conveniently located close to The Lodge and stocks the essentials, plus snacks and small souvenir items. On your way to or from Detroit, be sure to stop at Rosie's Mountain Coffeehouse in Mill City for their famous scones, a cup of hot java, or a bowl of delicious homemade soup.

Whether you're an experienced fisherman or just getting your feet wet, winter can be a great time to plan a fishing trip. Oregon Outdoor Excursions offers guided trips throughout the year, including a "Siletz River Winter Steelhead" trip. Take advantage of their guides' knowledge and expertise as you drift down the Siletz, fishing for steelhead.

Winter is also an ideal time for viewing certain types of wildlife. Just west of Salem lies the Baskett Slough National Wildlife Refuge - a sanctuary for wintering geese, great blue heron, hawks and other birds and mammals. Winter is the best time to see the dusky Canada goose or catch a glimpse of the beautiful Bald Eagle.

For a unique experience you won't soon forget, consider a horseback adventure with Into the Wild Equine Adventures, a family-owned and operated trail riding business specializing in intimate, guided group trail rides. While summer is the busiest season for tours, the company also offer a limited number of winter rides exploring the foothills of the Cascade Range.

For a cold weather outing close to the city, head to Minto-Brown Island Park. This nearly 900-acre natural park offers many miles of trails for walking, jogging, biking, and hiking, and also boasts one of the largest off-leash dog parks in the Northwest. After hiking or exploring Minto-Brown, find a place with cozy fireplace ambiance and great food and drink like Bentley's Grill or Gilgamesh Brewing's newly opened restaurant and brewery, The Campus.

For more events and ideas for exploring the Salem area this winter, visit the Official Salem Area website www.TravelSalem.com.

~Originally published January 15, 2013 on Travel Salem's blog on StatesmanJournal.com by Angie Morris.

title: Draw Visitors to Your Business with Creative Travel Packages
body:
Whether it is a limited time offer or an annual travel package, it's time to create a special travel package for your business or organization by collaborating with one of your neighbors. If you need ideas or help contact Sue Nichols, Travel Salem's Community Development Director at snichols@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 22.

The opportunities in the near and distant future are plentiful:

Holiday packages
There are plenty of holidays and themes throughout the year that fit a travel package: Christmas and shopping, Valentine's Day and romance, Memorial Day & Thanksgiving wineries, Independence Day all-American activities and many more. Just look at your calendar, contact Travel Salem and plan ahead.

Wine packages
Since we live in the middle of the richest wine country in the world, let's partner to bring those wine visitors here.  The wineries are always looking for partners to enhance their offerings and they have year-round opportunities.  Look at TravelSalem.com for a list of member wineries that will be happy you called.

2017 Eclipse packages 
Yes, we are already taking calls for the 2017 Solar Eclipse. Oregon is the perfect viewing location for the 2017 Eclipse and we want to be sure the Salem area has travel packages ready to meet consumer demand. Remember Travel Salem is here to help you. For more information about the 2017 Eclipse visit: http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEgoogle/SEgoogle2001/SE2017Aug21Tgoogle.html

Spring & Summer packages 
With a blink of the eye, spring will be here. Start thinking about packages you would like to create and have them ready by January for Travel Salem to promote. Families are thinking about spring break and summer vacations, so start planning now.

title: Economic Summit -- Property Values, Land Use, Development and Jobs
body:
Wednesday, October 17, 2012
5-9 p.m. at the Keizer Civic Center

Please join us to examine significant economic forces related to economic development in Marion County, and to discuss ways we can work together.

A panel of speakers from the public and private sectors will share their insights:

  • Mayor Lore Christopher, City of Keizer
  • Van Khieu, Marion County Assessor's Office
  • Jay Gordon, Willamette Valley Multiple Listing Service
  • Jim Rue, Oregon Department of Land Conservation and Development
  • Alan Roodhouse, RPS Development
  • Nick Harville, SEDCOR
  • Suzanne Dufner, Mid-Willamette Valley Council of Governments

To register, simply respond via email to drusso@co.marion.or.us and provide your current contact information. There is no fee. A modest buffet will open at 5 p.m. during the social hour; the program begins at 6 p.m. Registration deadline is October 1.

This Economic Summit is sponsored by the Marion County Economic Development Advisory Board, a group who advise the Marion County Board of Commissioners.

title: End of Year Deadline for Economic Development Grant Funds
body:
December 31 is the deadline to apply for the 2nd cycle of economic development grant funds allocated by Marion County. Grants up to $50,000 will be awarded from a fund provided to Marion County from Oregon Lottery proceeds. The primary purpose of the grant program is to assist private-sector employers to retain and create jobs.

Established private-sector business entities are eligible. Start-ups with less than three years of financial performance and nonprofit organizations are not eligible at this time. Applicants must demonstrate how they will meet the following criteria: 

" Retain or create jobs;
" Expand an employer's services or production;
" Bring in additional sales revenue from outside Marion County;
" Enhance the property tax base.

In the first cycle of the grant program earlier this year, four grants were awarded totaling $130,000. For the second cycle, $70,000 is available to award. 

A competitive process is used to score proposals and award funds. The Marion County Economic Development Advisory Board (EDAB) will review and rank all applications, then make recommendations to the Marion County Board of Commissioners for funding approval. The Board of Commissioners holds decision-making authority for all grants. "We have a tremendous resource of experience and knowledge on our Economic Development Advisory Board," said Commissioner Patti Milne, who had pushed for the creation of EDAB in 2003.  "Their work on this grant program and their continued interest in economic development is greatly appreciated."

Bill Cummins, chair of EDAB, said, "Our volunteer board is eager to stimulate economic development in Marion County and we encourage people to apply. Our priority is to assist employers already based here to strengthen their businesses. We believe economic development is critical to help retain and create jobs, increase revenue from outside sources, and improve the tax base for government and schools." Mr. Cummins is plant engineer at Diana Foods, a food processing company in Silverton, and is also a member of the Silverton City Council.

Each year, Marion County receives 2.5% of the net revenues of the video lottery games played within the county. According to ORS 461.547, that money is to be targeted toward economic development.  

The grant application form and other materials are available at the Marion County web site at www.co.marion.or.us

title: Feature Your Business on the New Digital Smartphone Concierge
body:
Is your business featured on over 800 Salem and Keizer hotel rooms and on the plasma screens in the official Travel Cafe Visitors Center? Travel Salem has a creative partnership with HospitalityVision, the host of the default television channel in over 800 Salem area hotel rooms.

Not only do the ads run eight times an hour, 160 times a day, and 5,400 times a month, this advertising medium visually reaches overnight visitors; promoting businesses who want to attract visitors to their front door. And, it is also featured on the local area "My Concierge To Go" apps. Pictured to the right is "Lewis" in the lobby of the Comfort Inn and Suites in Salem.

"My Concierge To Go" provides visitors with a custom, personalized digital concierge. Using the new phone app available on Android, the iPhone and other smartphones, guests can remotely review hotel amenities, hotel layout, check meeting times, agendas, play games, enjoy entertainment, book more room nights, and find partner restaurants, shops and attractions, too.

Guests simply check into a hotel, download the app or scan a QR code, enter a hotel code, and ring a bell to meet their personal concierge. The information on the "My Concierge To Go" directory mirrors the digital guest directory on the televisions. Check out a sample in iTunes. With HospitalityVision, you can take the directory out of the room and your concierge goes wherever you go.

If you would like your business featured on the Salem area "My Concierge To Go" apps and in more than 800 hotel rooms, contact Tina Winge at membership@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 59.

body:

5:00 - 8:00 p.m.

Celebrate "Spirit of America" at Travel Salem! Come to the Travel Cafe to get your picture taken in a "red carpet" style setting with In The Spotlight Photobooth; treat your taste buds to a delightful mix of wine and cheese provided by Willamette Valley Vineyards and Willamette Valley Cheese Company; find out about staycation specials for you and your friends and family offered by La Quinta Inn & Suites; and while you are here, visit with the Salem Relocation Team about Fannie Mae properties. It's sure to be a fun-filled evening you won't want to miss!

" In The Spotlight Photobooth will be located in the Willamette Room to capture the live photobooth experience with a variety of props to choose from and on-site printing for instant souvenirs.
" Salem Relocation Team will be staffed with experts to answer any questions you may have regarding Fannie Mae foreclosed properties.
" Willamette Valley Cheese will be complementing the Willamette Valley Vineyards' wines with delicious cheese pairings.
" La Quinta Inn & Suites will be on hand to talk about their specials and promotions.
" Willamette Valley Vineyards will be serving delicious and sustainable wines. Wine tasting and Riedel wine glass for only $5.00. Also, receive 20% discount on all bottles purchased at the Travel Cafe. (Tasting fee waived for purchases over $30. Stemware not included.)

Put a little bit of love in your heart this season! Bring your loved ones to Travel Salem for a heart-warming experience as we feature three local wineries in an exclusive wine tasting event at our Travel Caf_. Enjoy buttery cheeses from Willamette Valley Cheese Company, shop around for clothing and gift ideas for your loved ones and find information about how to get involved in YWCA's Women helping Women programs! Plus, come check out our pal, Sal, the famous Golden Pioneer!

  • Latitude One _ Dallas' delicious Italian restaurant is back by popular demand! If you didn't sample their dishes last year, you won't want to miss the red velvet cake and other decadent treats the Chef will be baking up for our February event.

  • YWCA _ Learn about their outreach programs and events for women and children and how you can become involved.
  • Special Complimentary Wine Tasting Event!!
    ---> Firesteed Cellars _ The wines of Firesteed display distinctive varietal character and consistently over deliver' in terms of value for the price. Try for yourself the Premium Citation Chardonnay, 2006 Willamette Valley Pinot, and Dry Riesling.
    ---> Left Coast Cellars _ They'll be pouring tastes of three of their estate-grown, hand-crafted Pinot Gris and Pinot Noir wines. Wine will also be available for purchase.
    ---> Willamette Valley Vineyards _ Special Pre-release pouring of their 2008 Pinot Noir style Port. Complimentary tastes of this limited wine. Perfect for pairing with Valentine's Day chocolate. (stemware not included.)

title: Foster Strong Customer Service Culture through "Q Care" Program
body:
Tourism is an $8.4 billion industry in Oregon and one of the state's largest employers. Superior customer service is a top priority for the tourism industry to ensure repeat visitation and promote a positive community brand. Just like photos and videos are used by visitors to remember and share their memories, the type of service a visitor receives impacts how they share their experience with friends and family. You've heard it before, customers that have a bad experience with a business tell at least 10 friends - that's not the kind of "word of mouth" exposure that helps the bottom line. Going the extra mile for your customers will provide a huge return for the long-term health of your business. And many times it's the small things that make a big difference.

Some employees just have a knack with customers - they know how to please and deliver value because helping customers just comes naturally to them. These employees are incredibly valuable as they create loyal customers. Businesses can foster a strong customer service culture by encouraging all employees to become certified customer service professionals through Travel Oregon's free "Q Care" program. This online certification program develops strong customer service skills necessary for personal and professional growth.

The Quality Care (Q Care) Customer Service Training Program is a statewide certification created to support the growth of the tourism and hospitality industry through enhanced guest experiences. But you don't have to be a tourism-related business to participate or reap the benefits of a robust customer service program. The Q Care program provides Oregon employees with the tools and resources needed to better serve customers and visitors alike.

If growing your bottom line and increasing your market share are important to your business, invest in training your employees to be quality ambassadors for your organization. There is no expense to you other than staff time to complete the Q Care Training which only takes one hour. It's free and available online so employees can complete the certification at their convenience. Visit www.oregonqcare.com for more information.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem

title: Funding for Building Improvements in Downtown's Core Area Available!
body:
Program designed to:

  • Serve as a catalyst and showcase for revitalization and redevelopment
  • Increase retail vitality and density
  • Attract new and/or existing businesses to the downtown core

Open House to learn more about the program:
November 9, 2011
8 a.m. - 9:30 a.m.  and 5 p.m. - 6:30 p.m.
Salem Urban Development Department
350 Commercial Street, NE

Program overview:
It is the intent of this program to enhance the character and identity of a proposed impact area. There are opportunities to enhance storefronts and buildings so they create interest and draw people to the area. These investments should be attractive to consumers, perhaps enhancing outdoor and sidewalk use for consumers or adding creative amenities that stimulate consumer engagement in the area. By offering funding for multiple properties/projects in a targeted area, the program aims to create an immediate and visible impact, resulting in a more marketable retail, office, and housing environment.

For more information, including program criteria:

  • Visit www.cityofsalem.net/RiverfrontDowntownURA
  • Contact Project Manager, Annie Gorski at 503-588-6178 or agorski@cityofsalem.net

Back to newsletter
