title: Historic vote in Congress will boost inbound travel to the Salem area and stimulate local economy
body:
Travel Salem welcomed news today that the U.S. Congress passed legislation to create economic growth and thousands of new American jobs by welcoming millions more international travelers to the United States. The Travel Promotion Act will allow the United States to establish a multi-million dollar promotion program to compete on the global stage for the billions of dollars and immeasurable goodwill that would come with overseas travelers. The bill is expected to become law within 10 days.

"The Salem area is an international destination with visitors from all corners of the globe," said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. "International travelers seek out Salem for its authentic experiences, abundant and unique outdoor recreational opportunities, culinary bounty and rich historic amenities. This monumental legislation establishes a new revenue stream necessary to compete on the global stage. Travel Salem will continue its partnership with Travel Oregon as we look for new ways to attract international travelers and leverage this new legislation."

"This is a historic victory for the U.S. economy and the one in eight American workers whose jobs depend on travel," said Roger Dow, president and CEO of the U.S. Travel Association. "The United States Congress has sent a clear message that travel is a high priority to our nation and that tangible steps must be taken to increase travel to and within the United States. We are extremely grateful to the bill's champions: Senators Reid, Dorgan, Ensign and Klobuchar in the Senate and Representatives Delahunt, Blunt and Farr in the House."

The Travel Promotion Act establishes a public-private partnership to promote the United States as a premier international travel destination and communicate U.S. security and entry policies. According to analysis by Oxford Economics, the bill is estimated to drive $4 billion in new consumer spending annually, provide $321 million in new federal tax revenue each year and create 40,000 U.S. jobs nationwide. Further, it is expected to reduce the federal budget deficit by $425 million over the next 10 years, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

Overseas visitors spend an average of more than $4,000 when they visit the United States.

The Travel Promotion Act is modeled after successful state-level initiatives and is funded through a matching program featuring up to $100 million in private sector contributions and a $10 fee on foreign travelers who do not pay $131 for a visa to enter the United States. The fee is collected once every two years in conjunction with the Department of Homeland Security's Electronic System for Travel Authorization. No money is provided by U.S. taxpayers.

The U.S. Travel Association is the national, non-profit organization representing all components of the $770 billion travel industry. U.S. Travel's mission is to promote and facilitate increased travel to and within the United States. For more information, visit www.ustravel.org.

title: Hotel TV Digital Directories Are Now "To Go"
body:
Travel Salem's partner Hospitality Vision, formerly Digital City Guide, is pleased to announce that for the first time in the hotel industry, guests can take their hotel TV digital directories "to-go!" on their phone.

Using a new phone application, guests can remotely review hotel amenities, hotel layout, rent a car, arrange a wine tour, order pizza, check meeting times, find restaurants, shops and local attractions and be directly navigated to your business.

If you are an existing Travel Salem Digital City Guide advertiser, you will be listed on "My Hotel to Go" as an added value at no extra charge.

The "My Hotel to Go" Directory is the perfect, interactive complement to your TV listing on the big-screen in 800+ Salem area hotels. "My Hotel to Go" will be launching in Salem this year so be sure to contact Sue Nichols, Travel Salem's Community Development Director at 503-581-4325 ext. 22 or snichols@TravelSalem.com to learn more and sign up!

title: Interactive Map Highlights Resources for Visitors
body:
Travel Salem's Interactive Online Map (IOM) is an easy-to-use digital tool that helps visitors plan their Mid-Willamette Valley experience. 

The IOM highlights the wonderful resources we have in our region. The following categories on the IOM feature points of interest in our area: 

  • Culture/Heritage 
  • Vineyards/Wineries 
  • Specialty Food & Beverage 
  • Recreation 
  • Farms/Markets 
  • Gardens
  • Birding/Nature 

Visitors can view a general region of interest, which will populate with icons representing specific venues. A viewer can zoom in as far as street level and scroll over an icon, which opens a pop-up with the name of the business, image and brief description. Vistors can also take advantage of direct links to websites for each venue. 

Find out if your business qualifies for a listing on Travel Salem's Interactive Online Map! Contact Sue Nichols, Community Development Director at 503-581-4325, ext. 22 or email: snichols@travelsalem.com. 

Absolutely promoting Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley!

title: Introducing a New Partnership Program Between SwipeNow and Travel Salem
body:
Travel Salem's new direct credit card merchant processing alliance with SwipeNow has the potential to save your business thousands of dollars a year in merchant processing fees! If you accept credit cards for payment at your business you know how quickly merchant processing fees add up. By becoming a local direct processor and pooling together the purchasing power of hundreds of Travel Salem's members, SwipeNow is able to provide association members with an average savings of 23% off other card processing rates.

SwipeNow's benefits include: 

  • A local Direct processor that works directly with your business
  • Guaranteed lowest rates
  • Free terminal paper and supplies for terminals
  • Free special event loaners
  • A+ Better Business Rating along with superior local customer service
  • No application fees or start up costs for non processors

To schedule a free cost savings analysis or to start taking credit cards, contact Tim Holstein at 503-975-0660 or email him at timh@swipenow.com

title: Invite Sal, Travel Salem's Golden Pioneer, to your next event
body:
As a Salem business you can invite Sal, Travel Salem's Golden Pioneer, out for a day to help promote your next special event, advertise your business or market your products!

Sal recently paid homage to his 3-D twin atop the Oregon State Capitol during the Capitol's 75th anniversary celebration on Oct. 1. Sal has also taken a hot air balloon ride with Balloon Flying Service of Oregon; made it to Ladies' Night at Bentley's Grill; went cycling at JoyRide Cycling Studio and has even visited pets at the Willamette Humane Society.

We encourage you to plan a photo shoot with our promo pal, Sal. For further media exposure, send us your creative images and captions that explain what Sal was up to. We enjoy helping spread the news of Sal's latest adventures within Salem and the Marion and Polk County areas! For more information contact Dee Hendrix at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 25.

title: Jenie Skoy Joins Travel Salem
body:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce Jenie Skoy as the Association's new PR Manager. Jenie has a wealth of experience as a former magazine editor, newspaper reporter and freelance food and travel writer. Jenie grew up in Idaho and worked for more than a dozen years as a professional writer based in Salt Lake City, Utah.

Jenie holds a degree from Utah State University in English literature with a minor in print journalism. She's written for publications such as Sunset, USA Today, Fodor's travel guides, Dining Out, Utah Style and Design, Digital iQ magazine, Ancestry, Park City magazine, the Wasatch Journal and many others.

Jenie has also worked as a freelance PR writer, writing for clients as diverse as Microsoft and Beehive Cheese Company.  She also worked as the editor of Growing Edge magazine in Corvallis, the associate editor of Utah Business and Digital iQ magazines in Salt Lake City, Utah, as well as a special sections editor at the Register Guard in Eugene.

As an avid food blogger and photographer Jenie loves to cook and enjoys doing anything in the wilderness including rock climbing, hiking, fly-fishing and camping. She loves to cycle in Minto Brown Island Park, and dine in Salem's downtown restaurants.  Jenie also teaches yoga in Salem in her spare time.

Jenie claims that her true gift as Travel Salem's public relations manager is her tenacity at promoting Salem and Marion and Polk counties' rich destination attractions and activities to local and national media.

title: July 19th -- Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon
body:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon

Featuring
Keynote Speaker: John Zielinski, E.Z. Orchards Farm Market

Agri-Tourism - Growing Oregon's Economy One Berry at a Time!

July 19th, 2012
11:45 a.m. - 1:15 p.m.
Hart of the Garden Building
Oregon State Fair and Exposition Center
2330 17th Street NE
Salem, OR 97301
 
Call 503-581-4325 ext. 58 now to reserve your seat!
 
Sponsored by:

Frey's Dahlias
Just "Keeps' Kayakin'
Loustic Catering
Wild Oregon Tours
 
John Zielinski, owner of E.Z. Orchards Farm Market, is in the agri-tourism business and lives it every day! Come learn how E.Z. Orchards has successfully woven tourism into their agricultural roots boosting their bottom line and the area economy. John will share what the future holds for agri-tourism and how this industry will continue to grow.
 
Travel Salem's main leisure marketing pillars are Culture/Heritage, Culinary and Recreation. Agri-tourism has been a key component of Travel Salem's marketing. Farmers markets, outdoor markets, artisan crafted beer, wine, cheese bread, chocolate and so much more is a huge asset for our region. Learning more about these agri-tourism opportunities and partnering at the highest level to promote this niche is an important part of our regional tourism engine.
Please join John as he shares more about this important industry!
 
Keynote Speaker:
John Zielinski is a 4th generation Willamette Valley farmer who manages E.Z. Orchards Farm Market, and the annual E.Z. Orchards fall Harvestfest. John has visited farm stands from New England to Arizona in the constant search of innovative and cutting edge strategies to keep E.Z. Orchards in the forefront of the industry. E.Z. Orchards offers urbanites a pleasant farm setting where they can experience the authentic agricultural bounty of the Willamette Valley.
 
Giving back to the community is very important to John. He has served on various boards including: the Agri-Business Council of Oregon and is a past president of the Salem Area Chamber of Commerce. John is currently serving on the Silverton Hospital Board, the Oregon Community Foundation North Willamette Advisory Committee, and is President of the Marion County Farm Bureau.
 
John is married and has two daughters who he hopes will join him, and his two brothers, in the family business.
 
Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.
 
Enter-to-Win! - Enter to win a Wild Oregon Tours, trip for two to Abiqua and Butte Creek Falls; a beautiful dahlia bouquet courtesy of Frey's Dahlias; a gift certificate from Just "Keeps' Kayakin'; or a basket of delicious goodies from E.Z. Orchards Farm Market. Must be present to win.
 
RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door RSVP a must!
 
Reserve Your Seat Today
Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by July 16th!
-- Online - use your credit card at www.TravelSalem.com
-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301
 
Space is limited for this event. RSVP a must!
 
Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required. Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.
 
YOU WILL WANT TO ADD TO YOUR BUSINESS SAVVY AND NETWORK BY ATTENDING THIS MARKETING EXCHANGE
 
See you on July 19, 2012!
 
Sponsored by:

Frey's Dahlias
Just "Keeps' Kayakin'
Loustic Catering
Wild Oregon Tours

title: Keeping You Informed
body:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce Kara Kuh as the organization's new public relations manager. In this role, Kuh will develop and implement public and media relations activities that promote Salem and Marion and Polk counties for leisure tourism and event business.

Kuh has more than 11 years of experience working in nonprofit communications and public relations. Before joining Travel Salem, she served as the communications specialist for Willamette Humane Society for five years. Prior to that, she worked as the media relations and marketing manager for the American Cancer Society in Portland, Ore. A native Oregonian, Kuh earned a bachelor's degree in business administration and marketing from Pacific University in Forest Grove, Ore. While studying at Pacific, she also completed a marketing and PR internship with the Washington County Visitors Association in Beaverton, Ore.

"Kara's many years of experience in communications and media relations will help us promote Salem and the surrounding area as a key destination for leisure and business travelers," says Irene Bernards, Travel Salem's Marketing and PR Director. "We look forward to her contributions and are happy she is part of our team!"

Kara can be reached at kkuh@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 25.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Keeping You Informed
body:
External links not only improve your search engine ranking, but they also provide a valuable resource to your customers. Search Engine Optimizers, those who provide Search Engine Optimization service, believe that external links are one of the most important sources for improving search engine ranking because search engines consider them to be third-party votes.*

Linking to www.TravelSalem.com illustrates your support for tourism as an economic development generator and this simple link will help www.TravelSalem.com climb in search engine rankings, which allows your business information and link to be found by even more visitors as well. Travel Salem's website isn't just for out-of-towners either; it's a valuable resource for residents too.

Take a moment to ensure your business link on www.TravelSalem.com is correct. If you find your link is not listed with your business or needs to be updated, please email your correct website link to kreeves@TravelSalem.com.

A link might seem like something small, but linking our websites together and linking to other businesses in Salem and the mid-Willamette Valley, will benefit all businesses involved. This small little link opens up a world of possibilities!

*External Links, SEOmoz.org

title: Listing Reminder for Lodging Properties
body:
It's time for Oregon lodging properties to update their property listings for the 2014-2015 Travel Oregon Official Visitor Guide. Oregon Restaurant & Lodging Association (ORLA) is the official provider of lodging listings in the guide - the only statewide print piece for comprehensive lodging listings in Oregon. Through a strategic alliance with Travel Oregon, all properties are afforded a free basic listing in this annual printed guide and online at TravelOregon.com. 

To get your listing included in the 2014-15 guides, go online to OregonRLA.org/LodgingListings and log in with the username and password provided in the letter from ORLA. Properties must update or at least verify the listing information is accurate in order to be included in the guides. While members of ORLA are automatically included, non-members are required to verify their information annually.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Literary Life and History of Salem Featured on C-SPAN
body:
You may have noticed the colorful vans sporting the C-SPAN logo around Salem the week of February 2 and wondered what C-SPAN was doing in Salem. Known as LCVs (or Local Content Vehicles), the vans carried producers with C-SPAN's Cities Tour, who were on a quest to interview local historians, civic leaders and authors for a series of programs about Salem that aired on Book TV and American History TV in early March. 

Salem area historical sites featured on C-SPAN included the Oregon State Capitol, the Museum of Mental Health at the Oregon State Hospital, the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill at Willamette Heritage Center and the Asahel Bush House and Museum. 

Four local authors, including three professors from Willamette University, were also featured. The C-SPAN team also spoke with local cherry growers about the history and significance of the cherry industry in the Mid-Willamette Valley. 

The programs aired on Book TV/C-SPAN2 (Comcast channel 25) and American History TV/C-SPAN3 (Comcast channel 106) on March 1 and 2, but you can also view them on the Salem page of the C-SPAN Cities Tour website. 

  • Back to newsletter

title: Local Heroes "Show up" for a Good Cause
body:
When we remember those who gave their lives in the aftermath of the September 11th Attacks, our hearts go out to people in public service industries who "show-up" everyday and work to make our community better: law enforcement, firefighters, nurses, school teachers and everyone who devotes their life to serving others. Salem wants to pay tribute to some of these people in our region who champion extraordinary causes.

Meet local hero Tammi Burns whose mission is to help people "break the chain" of domestic abuse. She created the Break the Chain Apparel line that carries empowering messages: "Make a Stand against an Angry Hand," or "It's Not Love if There's Fear." The stylish apparel is especially popular with teenagers and Burns regularly travels to public schools to spread the word about abuse prevention, giving students a forum for expression as they create designs that find their way onto her apparel. Her work in the schools is part of her non-profit arm called Project Change Reaction. www.breakthechainapparel.com

Last Wednesday, hundreds of friendly red-shirted locals wielding paper plates descended on downtown Salem. You may have caught a glimpse of them lining Court and Liberty streets for a "stand-in" for Women Ending Hunger (WEH). They held plates with handwritten messages like: "End Hunger" and "No Empty Bellies," these plates represented 46,000 children who depend on free or reduced lunch at public school (9,000 more than last year) in Marion and Polk counties. Project manager for WEH, Kat Daniel, and a group of volunteers came up with the idea to create awareness that "there are a lot of kids right here that need local food assistance," said Daniels.

Local resident Kris Knox initiated and organized The Linda L. Vladyka Breast Wellness Foundation's Play for a Cure, a softball tournament that began 10 years ago between 15 teams at a softball field on a rainy day in Newberg. Today it has grown to become the largest co-ed softball tournament in Oregon with 40 teams competing. She started the games (named for her mother) when her Mom was battling breast cancer because she wanted her Mom and others in her situation - who couldn't meet the physical demands of a walk or run - to be able to participate in an event.

Last year, the group raised $42,500 - of which $25,000 went to the Susan G. Komen Foundation; $15,000 to the Salem Hospital Foundation for emergency financial aid for chemo patients; and $2,500 to the Salem YWCA for a mammogram screening program.

That annual tournament is the nexus of many inspirational stories: from the cancer survivors who throw out the first pitch from a wheelchair to the motivation behind the teams who band together to raise funds to honor their family and friends battling cancer.

September 11 will be the last day to wander through the haunting, but beautiful Patriot's Day Memorial the "Field of Flags" at Salem's Riverfront Park to honor victims of the September 11th Attacks and those servicemen and women who made the ultimate sacrifice in Afganistan and Iraqi conflicts. Go by today to see more than 5,000  flags and banners, or during the solitude of the evening when they are illuminated by a flood light against the dark sky. The event is sponsored by the Exchange Clubs of Salem. www.patriotsdaymemorial.com

But remember, it's not just grand efforts that "a hero makes," just "showing up" day after day and doing your part can make all the difference!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 9/11/11

  • Back to newsletter

title: Local Tourism Industry Experiences 6.6 Percent Increase in Travel Spending
body:
Tourism is big business for the Salem area and a vital economic generator. A recently-released study, Economic Impacts of Travel prepared by market research firm Dean Runyan Associates, reports that travel spending in the Salem area grew 6.6 percent over the previous year to $496 million in 2010.

Tourism-related businesses in the Salem area employed 6,260 people in 2010. Employees and business owners who worked in travel related businesses earned $132.7 million. Travelers to the Salem area contributed $2.5 million in tax revenue and $13.9 million in state revenue.

"Tourism is a major economic driver in the Salem area," said President & CEO Angie Morris, Travel Salem. "Visitors enjoy our region and contribute millions of dollars to our economy and this in turn creates jobs. Travel Salem continues to strategically position the Salem area as a premier destination, bringing in new dollars that support local economies and small businesses throughout the region."

Salem Area Travel Impacts (Marion & Polk Counties)
Accommodations - $49.1 million
Food Service - $112.9 million
Food Stores- $47.8 million
Local Transportation & Gas - $46 million
Arts, Entertainment & Recreation- $126.8 million
Retail Sales -$55.5 million
*Other Travel - $57.8 million

*outbound travel services and transportation

  • Back to newsletter

title: Lodging Properties ~ Remember to list in Travel Oregon Guide
body:
It's time for lodging properties to update property listings for the 2015-2016 Travel Oregon Official Visitor Guide. Oregon Restaurant & Lodging Association (ORLA) is the official provider of lodging listings in the guide _ the only statewide print piece for comprehensive lodging listings in Oregon. Through a strategic alliance with Travel Oregon, all properties are afforded a free basic listing in this annual printed guide and online at TravelOregon.com. 

Here is how to make sure your property is included:
To get your listing included in the 2015-2016 guides, go online to OregonRLA.org/LodgingListings and log in with the username and password provided in the letter from ORLA. Properties must update or at least verify the listing information is accurate in order to be included in the guides. While members of ORLA are automatically included, non-members are required to verify their information annually. 

If you did not receive a letter in the mail from ORLA:
For new properties (or if you did not receive login credentials) you will need to complete the Basic Listing Form available online. http://www.oregonrla.org/Documents/BasicListingForm-2014-prf1.pdf.

All updates for the listings must be completed by November 25, 2014.

Back to newsletter

title: Looking for the Best in Oregon -- It's time to "Be Scene" as an Award Winner!
body:
The Oregon Festivals and Events Association is accepting nominations for its annual Ovation Awards recognizing the "Best" in festivals, fairs and events celebrated in Oregon during 2011.

It's incredibly easy to nominate your favorite community event. Just go to the Association's website at www.oregonfestivals.org and click on "Ovations Nominations'. There are lots of categories. Select the category that fits your community event, fill out the form and, with the supporting documentation, send it to the association by the January 16 deadline.

Winners will be notified and asked to join association members for THE Conference for Festivals and Events awards presentation at Hilton Hotel in Eugene, March 6, 2012. "Be Scene in Eugene' (it's a Hollywood theme). This is Oregon's own festivals and events convention - educational sessions, trade show, entertainment showcase, keynote presentations, speakers and lots of networking opportunities. Applications for the conference are available online. Visit the OFEA website at www.oregonfestivals.org or call Scott Ingalls at 866-904-6165 for all the details on Ovation Awards and the conference.

  • Return to newsletter

title: Make Plans Now for Total Solar Eclipse
body:
Visitors are already booking lodging for 2017, because for the first time in 26 years, a total solar eclipse will occur. Salem is in the direct path and we will play host to thousands of the world's eclipse-chasers.

The shadow first touches land near Newport, Oregon at 17:15:50.6UT (at about 10:15 in the morning) on August 21, 2017 and lasts a full minute and fifty seconds of totality.

Within two minutes the shadow extends eastward toward Dallas, Albany, Corvallis, Lebanon, Philomath, McMinnville, Woodburn, and yes, Salem. The length of totality will vary based on distances from the centerline. On the steps of the State Capitol in Salem (the first of five state capitals the shadow will visit), lucky viewers will be treated to 1m54.5s of shadow at just after 10:17am. 

1. This will be the first total solar eclipse in the continental U.S. in 26 years. 

(The next one will be on Tuesday, July 2, 2019. You can see it on land at sunset, from small spots in either Chile or Argentina.)

2. A solar eclipse is a lineup of the Sun, the Moon, and Earth.  The Moon, directly between the Sun and Earth, casts a shadow on our planet. If you're in the dark part of that shadow (the umbra), you'll see a total eclipse.

3. A solar eclipse happens at New Moon. The Moon has to be between the Sun and Earth for a solar eclipse to occur. The only lunar phase when that happens is New Moon.

4. It's all about totality. Only totality reveals the true celestial spectacle: the diamond ring, the Sun's glorious corona, strange colors in our sky, and seeing stars in the daytime.

5. First contact is in Oregon. If you want to be the first person to experience totality in the continental U.S., be on the waterfront at Government Point, Oregon, at 10:15:56.5 a.m. PDT. There, the total phase lasts 1 minute, 58.5 seconds.

6. The centerline crosses through 10 states.

Here are some inspirational ideas to consider: 

" Eclipse lodging packages (i.e. partner up with wineries and restaurants to create an experience package)

" Eclipse wine label (i.e. Umbra Pinot -The umbra is the darkest part of the Moon's shadow) 

" Eclipse-themed events 

" Eclipse-themed souvenir items (i.e. T-shirts, mugs, bumper stickers)

" After-eclipse party or meal

" Eclipse menu (i.e. Solar Burger, Lunar Lemonade, Absolute Magnitude Porter)

" Eclipse exhibit (i.e. sun/moon, celestial artwork)

" Significance of astronomy in history

Share your plans with Travel Salem and we will market "Eclipse 2017" to the far reaches of the galaxy, or at least nationally. 

Of Note: Submit information by spring of 2016 for long-lead pitches. This allows maximum exposure for events. For PR questions please contact: Kara Kuh at KKuh@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, X 124

To learn more about the 2017 Eclipse visit:  

http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEgoogle/SEgoogle2001/SE2017Aug21Tgoogle.html

Back to newsletter

title: Marketing Exchange Luncheon
body:
Irene Bernards, Travel Salem's director of marketing and public relations, has been elected by the Willamette Valley Visitors Association (WVVA) as the 2009-10 board president.

WVVA is the Regional Destination Marketing Organization for the Willamette Valley, which includes counties of Marion, Polk, Yamhill, SW Clackamas, Linn, Benton and East Lane. The WVVA Board of Directors is made up of representatives from each regions' Destination Marketing Organization; promoting leisure visitation to the Willamette Valley through a myriad of marketing strategies including online, print, advertising, social media, public relations, and unique partnerships.

"Tourism is a $496 million dollar industry for the Salem area," said Bernards. "The Willamette Valley Visitors Association is one of Travel Salem's major marketing partners that helps increase those visitors' expenditures."

As board president, Bernards will oversee the Association's administration, marketing and promotions.

body:
Oregon's Relentless Good News Story

Featuring

Director of Communications and Interactive Marketing, Oregon Wine Board

February 20, 2014
(RSVP Required) 
11:45 a.m.-1:30 p.m.

Red Lion Hotel 
3301 Market St. NE,  Salem, OR 97301

Call now to reserve your seat! 503-581-4325, ext. 58

Courthouse Fitness Red Lion Hotel - Salem

 

       
       Viva!
      Event Management

 

Keynote Speaker, Charles Humble: Charles Humble joined the Oregon Wine Board staff in 2011 from a successful career in communications consulting at several agencies in the Portland area. In his current position, he is responsible for all internal and external OWB communications as well as all online and interactive communications. During his tenure at OWB, he has established a strong track record of communicating the successes and opportunities of the Oregon wine industry.

His accomplishments have included producing the winning bid for the 2012 Wine Bloggers Conference held in Portland in 2012. He also orchestrated the communications plan that turned the media environment for the 2011 grape harvest from negative to positive with a focused and hard-hitting campaign that was dubbed "the miracle harvest."

He is a graduate of Linfield College in McMinnville, OR, where he earned a degree in communications. He was a journalist at several Oregon daily newspapers, including the Albany Democrat-Herald, Oregon Journal and The Oregonian before joining the public relations profession.

He was president and CEO of Insync Communications in Portland before the agency was acquired by Waggener Edstrom Worldwide where he was an executive vice president. Charles resides in Vancouver with his wife, Lynne. His hobbies include wine, sports, reading, running and technology.

title: Marketing Opportunities for 2015!
body:
Photography
Travel Salem welcomes the submission of photographic images, taken within Marion and Polk counties, featuring the resources and venues of our area. Image content may include attractions, gardens, nature, recreation, dining, shopping, events, wine tasting or any image that helps tell the story of our wonderful Mid-Willamette Valley.

A picture does say a thousand words and we speak volumes every day with high-quality images from many talented photographers. Photographs help develop the first impression a visitor has of our area. Images are used in our print, online and social media marketing platforms. If you would like Travel Salem to consider your photographic images, please review the following criteria:

" Photos must be high resolution and a minimum of 300 dpi
" Photos should be experiential and include people when possible.
" Photos with people must have a "model release" included that gives permission to use images.

If you have images that meet the criteria please send them to:

Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director
Travel Salem, 181 High St. NE, Salem, Oregon 97301
ibernards@TravelSalem.com 

If you have questions contact Irene directly at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

Your Events, Workshops, Classes and Activities
Please remember to submit your events for 2015 to the TravelSalem.com Event Calendar through this easy-to-use online form. Thousands of visitors and residents view the Travel Salem Event Calendar every month! The event content is utilized in weekly Event E-blasts and monthly Industry E-news, both with a very broad reach. 

The Travel Salem Marketing Department also refers to the Event Calendar when pitching story ideas to the media. In fact, we are already pitching summer and fall 2015 story ideas! The sooner you submit events, the more impact they may have on visitors, trip planners, promoters and the media. Travel Salem also submits events to the Travel Oregon website (some criteria apply).

For your event to receive maximum exposure please submit it at least 60 days before the actual event. This gives Travel Salem time to proof, edit, post and syndicate your event to local, regional and national media outlets.

If you have any questions regarding event submissions please contact Dee Hendrix, Marketing & Online Manager at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 25.

title: Meeting Planners look to Green Venues
body:
Sustainability is abuzz, and meeting planners - those that make decisions on where events, meetings, and conventions will be held- are paying attention. Considered one of the catalysts in the revitalization of downtown Salem, the Salem Conference Center (SCC) has been a spark for driving economic impact and job creation to the area. Last year, SCC held 565 events that served more than 87,000 delegates - resulting in roughly 11,000 guest rooms booked at the Grand Hotel in Salem, and many other rooms booked at multiple properties throughout the city.

SCC increasingly satisfies the growing expectation of meeting planners and convention attendees for environmentally responsible venues. SCC is closing in on becoming LEED certified; an internationally recognized verification that a building is designed and built using sustainable practices.  Next year, plans are in motion for solar panels to be installed on the roof to reduce energy consumption and costs. SCC already participates in a pilot program for composting, which allows food and waste from the catering kitchen to be recycled. These are just some examples of the Salem Conference Center's sustainable attributes that serve as a marketable asset to attract conventions and events to the Salem area.

Sustainability is also in Travel Salem's DNA. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE - a Marion County program that recognize businesses who commit to environmentally friendly practices. Last year, Travel Salem assisted 87 conventions and distributed more than 7,000 biodegradable welcome bags. At the upcoming Association of Oregon Recyclers Conference to be held at the SCC in June, Travel Salem will embrace the "green" montra by arranging an information table staged with Salem area resources and staff who will provide the highest level of hospitality and encourage delegates to get out and experience the area's sustainable visitor amenities. For more information on how Travel Salem can assist your group with a diverse range of services for your convention or event contact Debbie McCune, Travel Salem's director of sales, at 503-581-4325, ext. 28.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 4/24/10

title: Music Festival Electrifies a New Era of Engagement
body:
Going into its fourth year, the Cherry City Music Festival has continued to ignite a new era of engagement among a younger generation, and brings their talents to the forefront of Salem's music scene. Last year, 142 bands participated in the Festival, attracting more than 20,000 people during what was an electrifying weekend filled with great music offered to a mix of Salem visitors.

The music these extraordinary bands play varies but their energy, creativity, passion and talent transcend all differences. These artists have worked hard at their craft; offering unique gifts of masterful sounds and experiences.  The Cherry City Music Festival gathers people interested in specific genres and unites them by serving up an array of options that expands their musical palette. The passion is contagious and many share their same enthusiasm toward independent music. They have the keen ability to influence their own generation; empowering renewed dedication to keep the vibrant arts scene alive and well in Oregon's capital city.

The Cherry City Music Festival is a perfect example of social media marketing at its best. The majority of the event is promoted through Facebook, Twitter, blogs and word of mouth. Using these social networking sites, an online community of local and national fans interested in the Festival is weaved together months prior to the event. All of the volunteers for the festival are also found through these avenues, building buzz about the festival!

The 4th annual Cherry City Music Festival will take place April 8-10, 2010 at venues throughout Salem. Registration for the bands will take place at Travel Salem's Travel Cafe. For more information about the Cherry City Music Festival, visit www.cherrycitymusic.com, or for information about other Salem area events, visit www.TravelSalem.com.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 3/28/10

body:
Travel Salem recently unveiled the official 2012-13 Salem Area Visitors Guide. This 65 page, full color visitors guide promotes Salem as well as Marion and Polk counties. Trip ideas, attractions and points of interest, lodging, dining, events, shopping, wineries, gardens, agri-tourism, transportation, recreation and relocation information resources are included along with tour ideas and stories.

"The Salem Area Visitors Guide plays a vital role in promoting the area for leisure visitors as well as convention and event business," said Irene Bernards, Travel Salem's Marketing and PR Director. title: New Greeter Program Needs Volunteers
body:
Become a Salem Greeter and Meet Visitors from Around the World

Do you love Salem and want to share your passion with visitors? Do you consider yourself a natural entertainer with knowledge of interesting, little-known historical facts? Then consider becoming a Salem Greeter and be part of a prestigious international group of volunteer guides affiliated with the Global Greeter Network.

Greeters are volunteers who take individual tourists and small groups of 6 or less on informal, unscripted tours around the city's most iconic places and share their personal perspectives for a truly authentic Salem experience. 

Greeters are part of a global sustainable tourism effort and make visitors feel welcome, comfortable and excited about our city. If you are interested in becoming part of the Salem Greeter program, please contact lgomez@travelsalem.com.

Photo by Ron Cooper

title: New Hours for Travel Salem's Travel Cafe Visitors Center
body:
Beginning July 1 Travel Salem's Travel Cafe Visitors Center will have new hours; Monday through Friday 10:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., closed Saturday and Sunday. These changes are a result of program realignment due to budget restrictions. Travel Salem will continue to maintain program continuity and delivery in a manner that is consistent with visitor expectations.

"The new hours reflect the time of the day with the highest visitor volume," said Angie Morris, Travel Salem's CEO. "Our professional staff serve as the region's concierge providing Salem visitors with expert local resources and recommendations to help them explore what the area has to offer," said Morris. The Travel Cafe Visitors Center offers wine tasting, ticket sales to events and attractions, GPS rentals, and customized itineraries to name a few.

Travel Salem oversees a visitor information network that includes an official Oregon Travel Plaza located at the BEST WESTERN PLUS Mill Creek Inn, which is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week; as well as locations at the Red Lion Hotel, Salem Conference Center, Salem Airport, Amtrak, Lancaster Mall, Aurora Airport and the Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill.

After hours visitors will be able to access the Salem Area Visitors Guide, maps and other high demand resources via an outdoor brochure rack. Travel Salem offers Wi-Fi services so visitor information can also be obtained by visiting www.TravelSalem.com.

title: New Legislation Helps Support Oregon's Tourism Industry
body:
What if you didn't pay your taxes?  Chances are you would face the consequences. Why, then, was Oregon allowing out-of-state, online corporations to dodge their full tax obligations?

House Bill 2656 was introduced to the Oregon Legislature and recently passed. The bill levels the playing field for local transient lodging taxes. These taxes are paid by Online Travel Companies (OTC's) such as Expedia and Orbitz, and local hoteliers. 

The Oregon Destination Marketing Organization (ODMO) worked cooperatively to assist with the passage of HB 2656. ODMO is a non-profit organization representing destination marketing organizations (such as Travel Salem), convention and visitors bureaus, and chambers of commerce responsible for marketing specific geographic areas as visitor destinations.

Transient lodging tax dollars expended on tourism promotion and activities in our local communities have decreased during the recent economic downturn. This negatively impacts jobs and revenues for the state. One reason for the decrease is that out-of-state companies don't pay the same amount of transient lodging taxes as our local businesses.

Currently, some rooms booked online through OTC's do not generate the same amount of taxes as those booked directly through the hotel. In some cases, a hotel enters a contract with an OTC to provide rooms at a discounted rate, i.e. the "wholesale cost." The OTC then posts the rooms at a higher rate to consumers. This is referred to as the "wholesale booking model."

OTC's typically calculate state and local hotel occupancy taxes based on the "wholesale cost" they pay to a hotel, rather than the "retail price" they charge the customer. This practice results in lower taxes collected by state and local jurisdictions for rooms booked through an OTC, rather than directly with a hotel.

If a guest books a room directly through a hotel, the tax reflects the jurisdictions rate where the hotel is located. For example, Mr. Public books a room in Anytown, USA, through a hotel's website. The room rate is $100 and Anytown levies a 10% occupancy tax on rooms, so a total of $110 is charged to Mr. Public. The hotel then remits the $10 occupancy tax to the city.

In contrast, if Mr. Public books the same room through an OTC, the charge will still be $110 to cover the room rate, plus the OTC's "taxes and fees."  The OTC then calculates the occupancy tax based on what it owes the hotel, rather than what it charged the consumer. Implementing the "wholesale booking model," the OTC remits only $88 to the hotel ($80 for the contracted cost of the room and $8 for the occupancy taxes), and the OTC retains the remaining $22 from the transaction.

Many jurisdictions have become aware of this strategy and have filed lawsuits against some of the OTC's for these unpaid tax revenues. In response, the OTC's are seeking legislation that would protect this practice by making it a legitimate tax exemption through a federal preemption of state and local authority.

ODMO has worked with local governments, tourism promotion groups and industry members to develop a statewide standard and to ensure state and local tourism dollars are uniformly collected. House Bill 2656 will establish a statewide standard for the rate for taxes on rooms in Oregon stating, "All rooms in Oregon will be taxed at the room rate paid by the consumer." This proposal will only apply to future sales of rooms occupied after the time of the enacted date.

HB 2656 will ensure that out-of-state companies, including OTC's, pay the same amount of taxes as local businesses. This will help level the playing field and maximize the resources our communities have for tourism promotion.

Travel Salem would like to thank ODMO for their work on HB 2656 and for their advocacy for Oregon's tourism industry.

  • Back to newsletter

title: New Oregon Wine Country License Plate Now Available
body:
Oregon's Wine Country license plate is now available through the DMV. This wine country specialty license plate is the first of its kind in the nation. Plates are available from the DMV for an ongoing $30 surcharge due at issuance and every two-year renewal.

Wine Country plate proceeds will be directed to the Oregon Tourism Commission to support the promotion of Oregon as a travel & tourism destination, and will be distributed as follows:

  • 50% to matching grants for wine and culinary tourism promotion
  • 50% to regional tourism agencies throughout Oregon, based on an acreage formula of grapes in production

The bill was conceived and initiated by Travel Salem and co-sponsored by Senator Jackie Winters and Representative Kevin Cameron. The Oregon Winegrowers Association provided critical guidance and advocacy on behalf of the bill.

"This marketing strategy is meant to focus attention on Oregon's culinary scene, drive new tourism revenues to support economic growth across the state, and to galvanize the tourism & wine industries," said Angie Morris, Travel Salem's CEO. "The Wine Country plate celebrates Oregon's rich agricultural resources and world-class culinary heritage, and serves as a moving "billboard" promoting Oregon's status as an agri-tourism hotspot. The plate provides Oregonians with the opportunity to show their support for the tourism industry and contribute toward a healthy and vibrant tourism economy."

  • Return to newsletter

body:
WHAT: SB 442 was recently signed into law by Governor John Kitzhaber establishing the Wine Country specialty license plate, the first initiative of its kind in the nation.

Plates will be available for a $30 surcharge due at issuance and every two-year renewal. Wine Country plate proceeds will be directed to the Oregon Tourism Commission to support the promotion of Oregon as a travel & tourism destination, and will be distributed as follows: 50% to matching grants for wine & culinary tourism promotion 50% to regional tourism agencies throughout Oregon, based on an acreage formula of grapes in production

The bill was conceived and initiated by Travel Salem and co-sponsored by Senator Jackie Winters and Representative Kevin Cameron. The Oregon Winegrowers Association provided critical guidance and advocacy on behalf of the bill.

WHY: This "jobs bill" was developed as an innovative marketing strategy to focus attention on Oregon's culinary scene, drive new tourism revenues to support economic growth across the state, and to galva-nize the tourism & wine industries. The Wine Country plate celebrates Oregon's rich agricultural re-sources and world-class culinary heritage, and serves as a moving "billboard" promoting Oregon's status as an agri-tourism hotspot. The plate provides Oregonians with the opportunity to show their support for the tourism industry and contribute toward a healthy and vibrant tourism economy.

title: New Partnership Program with SwipeNow and Travel Salem
body:
Travel Salem's new direct credit card merchant processing alliance with SwipeNow has the potential to save your business thousands of dollars a year in merchant processing fees. If you accept credit cards for payment at your business, then you know how quickly merchant processing fees add up. As a local, direct processor and pooling together the purchasing power of hundreds of Travel Salem's members, SwipeNow provides association members with an average savings of 23% compared wtih other card processing rates. 

SwipeNow's benefits include:

  • A local, direct processor that works directly with your business
  • Guaranteed lowest rates 
  • Free terminal paper and supplies for terminals
  • Free special event loaners
  • A+ Better Business rating along with superior local customer service
  • No application fees or start up costs for non processors

To schedule a free cost savings analysis or to start taking credit cards, contact Tim Holstein at 503-975-0660 or email him at timh@swipenow.com. 

Back to newsletter

title: New Scenic Bikeway Rolls Through Marion County
body:
The Oregon State Parks and Recreation Commission approved the new Cascading Rivers Scenic Bikeway in June. The Oregon Scenic Bikeways program now features 12 designated bikeways statewide. 

The Cascading Rivers Bikeway rolls through 70-miles of forested cascade foothills between Estacada and Detroit. With elevations gains of 3,125-feet near Estacada and a 1,985-foot climb near Detroit, the route offers challenges and beautiful scenery for experienced riders. A family-friendly ten-mile round trip begins on Faraday Road near Estacada, which is closed to motor vehicles.

The route follows the Breitenbush River and the nationally designated Wild and Scenic Clackamas River. There are plans for signage to be posted designating this new route by late summer. The route will be closed during late fall and winter due to snow. 

Information to plan a ride can be found on RideOregonRide.com, including a printable map, accommodations and amenities along the route.

Back to newsletter

title: November 21 -- Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon
body:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon
Featuring

THE STATE OF THE INDUSTRY
Keynote Speaker: Angie Morris, President & CEO, Travel Salem

November 21, 2013
(RSVP Recommended)
11:45 a.m.-1:30 p.m.
Willamette Heritage Center

The "State of the Industry" presentation will highlight the achievements and milestones from 2013 and offer insight into what's ahead for 2014.
Mark you calendar and make plans to attend this important Marketing Exchange Luncheon!  This is your opportunity to learn how Travel Salem has leveraged funding and promoted the area in creative ways to make a positive impact on the wonderful people and businesses in our region.
Call now to reserve your seat! 503-581-4325, ext. 58

Keynote Speaker: Angie Morris
Angie Morris was hired as the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Travel Salem in 2007 after a nationwide search. In 2011, she initiated Senate Bill 442 to create the Wine Country plate, a specialty license plate to support tourism economic growth across the state. This "jobs bill" was signed into law by Governor Kitzhaber. As of 2013, there are more than 8,000 of these plates on the road, with the Oregon Wine Country plate being the first of its kind in the United States and the second fastest selling specialty plate in Oregon. In 2008, Angie launched another first with the Travel Cafe, the first-ever destination visitors center in the country. The Travel Cafe received the 2008 Governor's Award for Creative Tourism Development and the 2009 Green Building of the Year Award from the Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards. And in 2007, she received the Governor's Award for Tourism Industry Awareness.

Before joining Travel Salem, Angie was the Executive Director for Pentacle Theatre, one of the oldest and most respected community theaters in Oregon, where she completed a $1 million capital campaign to renovate the theater.  Prior to that, Angie was the Director of Marketing and Public Relations for the Portland Opera: "Broadway Across America' series where she generated $9-12 million in ticket sales annually. She directed the branding campaign to position Portland Opera as the 14th opera company in North America and propelled the "Broadway Across America' series to "top-tier" status nationally out of 55 markets.

Angie has a degree in Journalism from the University of Oregon, and lives in Salem with her family.

Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Enter-to-Win!: 
A "Woodland Escape" trail ride package for two riders - Into the Wild Equine Adventures

Beautiful gift basket filled with goodies - Madrona Hills Ace Hardware

Guests must be present for a chance to win.

  RSVP's and prepayment of $18 required/$23 at the door. RSVP a must!

Reserve Your Seat Today - Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by:
Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 58
Mail - send you check to:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301
Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required.
Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success. 
See you on November 21, 2013!

 Thank you to our sponsors:

title: One-year Anniversary Party! Come Sip New Release Wine and Drop Off your Corks!
body:
It started with a romping grape stomp outside the front doors of Travel Salem last year, but this year we celebrate the one-year anniversary of Travel Salem's partnership with Willamette Valley Vineyards to create a downtown Travel Cafe where visitors can come to sip some of the valley's most delicious wines! Come join us next Thursday, October 14th for a wine tasting party from 5 to 7 p.m. Oct. 14 at the Travel Cafe on 181 High St. NE.

Enjoy new releases of Willamette Valley Vineyards sustainable wine: 08 Pinot Noir, 08 Signature Cuvee Pinot Noir, 08 Estate Chard, and 07 Syrah, as well as delicious library wines.

We're also trying to collect a massive pile of corks to send to the cork recycler, so bring by your corks, by the load, if you have "em! Whoever bring the most corks, wins a prize! Learn about Willamette Valley Vineyards cork recycling program from their Cork reHarvest director. The party will be catered by Wild Pear restaurant, a favorite of locavores. www.wildpearcatering.com

The first 25 guests will receive a complimentary "It's Willamette Dammit" T-shirt.

Weekly tastings are available from 11 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Mondays through Saturdays at Travel Cafe, 181 High St. NE.

General Admission: $10.00 includes Riedel wine glass
Wine Club Members: $5.00 includes Riedel wine glass

For more information, call (503) 588-9463 or go to www.willamettevalleyvineyards.com.

title: Oregon Days of Culture 2011: Register (also, maybe win $1,000)
body:
Oregon Days of Culture
October 1 -8, 2011

In 2010, 65 Oregon cities and towns hosted 599 Days of Culture events: film screenings, live performances, tours, exhibits, readings, lectures, dinners, community gatherings, volunteer activities, and family events. From October 1st to 8th, Oregon communities converged across the state, from Ashland to Portland to Pendleton, from Eugene to Bend to Burns.
 
Register your 2011 events now. Registration is simple.
 
Your event page will link to your own website, ticket buying and donation pages.  We especially encourage the posting of free events:  free admission to museums, free author readings, free open rehearsals, free talks or tours.
 
Here's how to get started:

  1. Go to www.oregondaysofculture.org.
  2. Scroll to the bottom of the home page and click either Register to add an event OR Login under Add your event. Hint: You'll want to click on Login if you submitted an event last year.
  3. Follow the instructions and voil', your event(s) will be published to the site in less than 24 hours.

This is Culture: 2011 Photo Content
 
For the first time, this year Days of Culture will feature a statewide photo contest. Prizes include fancy cameras, cash, and gifts from sponsors. And get this: We'll give two winners $1,000 each to donate to the cultural nonprofit of their choice. Which could be yours, right?
 
So get listing! The Oregon Cultural Trust is looking forward to the biggest Days of Culture celebration yet.
 
Any questions? Contact Kimberly Howard with the Oregon Cultural Trust at 503-986-0089 or kimberly.howard@state.or.us.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Oregon's Third Capitol Building Celebrates 75 Years in October
body:
On October 1, one of Oregon's most distinctive buildings, The Oregon State Capitol, will turn 75. The Oregon State Capitol Foundation's Special Events Committee, and Capitol staff, has been hard at work planning a celebration. Visitors will enjoy tours, music and special displays reflecting the history of the Capitol. Plans also include a Light up the Dome event with super-sized birthday candles surrounding the Capitol dome.

Rich in history, Oregon's present Capitol has its origins in two fires. On December 30, 1855, fire swept through a newly occupied Statehouse, completely destroying the structure. On April 25, 1935, fire again destroyed the elegant Statehouse patterned after the U.S. Capitol.

The current building was dedicated October 1, 1938. A four-story structure of Modern Greek architecture, it was completed at a cost of $2.5 million. The building houses several elected state officials - the Governor, the Secretary of State, and the State Treasurer - in addition to the entire Legislative Branch of state government. 

A Capitol "Wings" project completed in 1977, at a cost of $12.5 million, added further space for legislative offices, hearing rooms, support services, a first floor galleria, and underground parking.

In the late 1990's a series of health and safety issues were identified in the Capitol wings. The 74th Legislature approved the "Capitol Restoration Project" in June 2007. Work in the Capitol wings took place between July 2007 and November 2008.

It's not too late to join the celebration! Do you have an idea or event you would like to host? Please email your event information to capitol.foundation@state.or.us, or email/call juliene.popinga@state.or.us (503-986-1555) for additional information.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Oregon's Visitor Industry Honors Travel Salem
body:
Travel Salem received the Oregon Governor's Creative Tourism Development Award Sunday, April 19, 2009 at the 25th Annual Governor's Conference on Tourism held in Salem at the Salem Conference Center. This prestigious award was presented to Travel Salem from the Oregon Tourism Commission for the creation of the Travel Salem Travel Cafe. The award recognizes an innovative program, promotion, or product by an Oregon individual, organization, business, community or region which epitomizes a new way of thinking about the tourism and hospitality industry.

On hand to accept the award for Travel Salem was Angie Morris, President & CEO; Irene Bernards, Tourism Marketing & PR Director; Debbie McCune, Director of Sales; Kathie Reeves,Marketing & Online Manager; Sue Nichols, Community Development Director; and Anthony Tham, Public Relations Manager.

"This project started with a vision to dramatically improve how we showcase our region and how we connect with the visitor. As the project moved forward, the concept gained momentum and support from partners who believed in its ability to drive economic development. The Travel Cafe is the direct result of our community pulling together to create something fresh and exciting - for both visitors and local residents. By design, it reflects the beauty and vibrancy of our region, and enhances our ability to sell the Salem area as a true destination," said Morris.

Travel Salem has been recognized five other times throughout the Association's history with Governor's Tourism Awards including the 1991, 1993 and 2005 Governor's Regional Tourism Award, which recognizes cooperative marketing efforts; the 1997 Governor's Tourism Award; and the 2008 Tourism Industry Awareness Award.

title: Our Pal, Sal!
body:
If you haven't already met Travel Salem's Golden Pioneer, we'd like to introduce you to our pal Sal, everybody's favorite guy because he is part of Travel Salem's Golden Pioneer Giveaway, where visitors and folks in the community can win freebies if they log onto Travel Salem's Facebook page. People have to "guess where the Golden Pioneer is," in a kind of Where's Waldo fashion or participate in other Travel Salem contests which change monthly.

Borrow Sal for the Day!

As members, you have the opportunity of taking Sal out for a day and using him to help promote your event or business or market your products!

Sal is open to creative suggestions! The sky's the limit, literally, as Sal has flown in a hot air balloon with Balloon Flying Service of Oregon! He made it to Ladies' Night at Bentley's Grill and went cycling at JoyRide Cycling Studio. He visited the pets at the Willamette Humane Society, helped at a rally at the State Capitol, worked as a referee at an athletic game to promote breast cancer awareness and was even on television helping promote A. C. Gilbert's Discovery Village.

Sal also hopes you'll consider giving away a prize, free tickets to your event or gift certificate that we can giveaway in connection with the Golden Pioneer Giveaway. Tell us what kind of promotion you'd like to do. Would you like more BUZZ on your Facebook site? Would you like to give free coffee to the first 10 people who show up at your location at a certain time? Would you like to create a fun video to broadcast on Youtube of Sal at your event/business?

We encourage you to plan a "photo shoot" with our celebrity Sal. After you take fun photos, please send us the photos and captions that explain what Sal was up to. For more information contact Kathie Reeves at kreeves@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 24.

title: Our Pal, Sal!
body:
Your one-stop source for ticketing needs is AbsolutelyTix, a state-of-the-art network for Marion and Polk Counties. AbsolutelyTix allow consumers to easily purchase tickets at the Travel Cafe Visitors Center or online, and provides a single source of online information about upcoming local shows and events. 

More than 24 partners (and growing) - local arts organizations, non-profits, and other community organizations - have partnered with Travel Salem to sell tickets and transact other business over the Internet. Some partners include: Taste & See Salem food tours, Friends of the Grand Theatre, Willamette University Theatre, and Salem Film Festival. Tickets for events, theater performances, concerts and more from our AbsolutelyTix partners are available for purchase online and at the Travel Cafe (181 High St. NE, Salem). Visit AbsolutelyTix.com for a complete list of upcoming events, shows, and performances.

We will consider the following shots within Salem, Marion County and Polk County: scenic & natural beauty, attractions & points of interests, wineries/wine tasting, shopping, dining, events, performances, architecture, crops, farms, gardens, downtown (skylines & specific buildings), lodging, cycling, galleries, recreation, children activities, and people enjoying the area in general.

title: Pitching for a Home Run
body:
Travel Salem's Director of Sales, Debbie McCune, will be representing Salem in Oklahoma City on November 12 during the Amateur Softball Association (ASA) Council's annual meeting. The City of Salem's Softball Recreation Coordinator, Billy Powers, will join McCune as they promote Salem during the bidding process for the 2015 ASA softball tournaments. Communities throughout the United States will be in attendance as they vie to host these highly coveted tournaments which have a significant impact on local economies.  

"It is highly competitive and we are working hard to convince council members that Salem, Oregon is an excellent site for ASA tournaments. We look forward to highlighting Salem during the tradeshow, as well as making a formal presentation in front of the council," said McCune.  Salem currently hosts Softball City USA (www.softballcityusa.com) at Wallace Marine Park. Softball City USA has received many awards, including the James Farrell award for the excellent tournaments. The 2015 schedule will be announced as soon as possible.

body:

To promote your business to these visitors, mail or deliver coupons, special offers and/or promotional items to Travel Salem (181 High Street, Salem, OR 97301). Please provide a quantity for all events, or pick which group you'd like to target (see numbers above). Please contact Tara Preston, Services Manager at 503-581-4325 ext. 58 or Tpreston@TravelSalem.com with any questions.

Coming right up, Salem will host the 3rd Annual Capital Cup Soccer Tournament, held June 27-29, 2014. More than 175 teams from Oregon and Washington will gather in Salem to compete for the honor of being named the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament champions. There will be multiple champions since the tournament is divided by gender and grade level, 3rd through 12th.

Multiple venues from throughout the Salem area will be used, including Capital FC Timbers Complex, Corban University, Geer Park, McKay High School, River Road Park, Salem Academy Christian School, Sprague High School, South Salem High School, Wallace Marine Park, West Salem High School and Willamette University.

The estimated economic impact of this event is $720,000, which is significant to Salem. Each team has an average of 15 players, plus the families that travel with the teams to support their children.  

Travel Salem has been working with the Capital Cup Soccer organizers and they have partnered with 13 local hotels to assist with housing the teams.

Join us as we welcome these visitors and provide them with information, deals and resources that make our region an exciting place to visit!

title: Put Your Business On The Map
body:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce the launch of Phase II of the Interactive Online Map (IOM), including an upgrade to the original map produced for Phase I. This versatile tool is designed to provide visitors to the TravelSalem.com website with an easy-to-use resource to help plan their Mid-Willamette Valley experience. 

Currently, the map targets our region's diverse cultural and heritage assets. Phase II, which we will begin to populate by early April, showcases the following categories: 

  • Culture/Heritage (e.g. historic museums, galleries, theaters, cultural museums)
  • Vineyards/Wineries (e.g. must be a producing vineyard or winery)
  • Specialty Food & Beverage (e.g. cheese maker, cider maker, coffee roaster, bread maker, candy manufacturer. No restaurants.)
  • Recreation (e.g. hiking, biking, horseback riding, golf, rafting, fishing)
  • Farms /Markets (e.g. farmers markets, farm stands, farms that allow tours)
  • Gardens
  • Birding/Nature (e.g. Baskett Slough, natural area)

    • The IOM is also a great tool to help local residents discover the wonderful resources we have in our own backyard. This makes it a great resource when planning staycations with family and friends.

    The IOM offers points of interest (POI) that will attract new visitors and lengthen the stay of current visitors to the region (Salem, Polk County, Marion County).  Since the map is interactive, visitors can see the general location of the POI. They can then zoom in as far as street level and scroll over an icon which opens a pop-up with the name of the business and a brief description. A corresponding list with photos is also located in the left sidebar and provides a direct link to businesses. 

    The Travel Salem IOM illustrates how much there is to see and do in our region, while also promoting visitation. Phase I of this project was funded by a Travel Oregon grant and Phase II is made possible through a Polk County grant.

    Want to know if your business qualifies for a listing on Travel Salem's Interactive Online Map? Please contact Dee Hendrix, Marketing and Online Manager at 503-581-4325, ext. 25 or email: dhendrix@travelsalem.com. 

    Absolutely promoting Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley!

title: Registration Opens for the Oregon Rural Tourism Studio Program
body:
Polk County Residents Invited to Participate September 2014 - January 2015

Oregon's Rural Tourism Studio (RTS), offered by Travel Oregon, is now open for registration. The fall/winter program will focus on communities in Polk County, including The Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde, Dallas, Falls City, Independence, Monmouth and Willamina. 

Oregon's RTS program is a series of tourism development workshops designed to assist rural communities interested in stimulating their local economies through sustainable tourism development, while protecting and enhancing local resources.  

Community leaders, tourism business entrepreneurs, tour operators, lodging property owners, land managers, guides, outfitters, outdoor enthusiasts, restaurateurs, and anyone interested in strengthening the local economy through tourism are encouraged to participate in the program. 

Although Travel Oregon recommends that participants attend all workshops and events in order to maximize the impact from the RTS program, community members are encouraged to attend any workshop or event they can. Participants who attend at least four of the six workshops or events will receive a certificate of completion from Travel Oregon. 

The cost to participate in any one workshop is $5 (and includes lunch), or $25 for all six workshops. Space is limited to 50 participants per workshop. For a complete list of workshops, dates and registration information, go to Industry.TravelOregon.com/PolkCounty. 

To find out more about the Polk County RTS, contact Shawn Irvine with the City of Independence at irvine.shawn@ci.independence.or.us or 503-837-1191.

title: Reminder ~ Travel Salem Seeks Story Ideas
body:
Speed Pitching Open House
Wednesday, May 21
1-5 p.m.  

Give us your best pitch! Share your best ideas for our "content library" that we can use for potential pitches to the media or for use in blogs, social media posts or other publications. Anyone representing a Marion or Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. and share what's new and newsworthy at your organization.

Here's how it works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Travel Salem Travel Cafe & Visitors Center (located at 181 High St. NE in Salem) any time between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. on Wednesday, May 21.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 15 minutes (maximum) to share their news with a member of Travel Salem's marketing staff.
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it needs to occur in late 2014 or 2015. (Most of the regional and national publications we target request information 3-4 months in advance).

You're welcome to bring a short, one-page summary of your pitch or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).

While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published.

If you cannot attend Speed Pitching, but would like to submit an idea, email it to kkuh@TravelSalem.com. We look forward to hearing all of your creative ideas!

Back to newsletter

title: Reminder: Tourism Summit Tomorrow!
body:
Travel Salem, in partnership with Travel Oregon, is hosting a regional Tourism Summit on Thursday, January 14, 2010 from 1:30-3:30 p.m. at the Red Lion Hotel and Conference Center (3301 Market St. NE, Salem). Join in the discussion!

This Summit is a forum to discuss how tourism connects to businesses and powers local economies. A diverse panel has been selected in an effort to put together a broad cross-section of expertise on a variety of issues (e.g. land use, industry, recruitment, retail, development, lodging, policy, education, etc.). Confirmed panelists include: Shelly Hansen, Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde; Steve Johnson, VIPs Industries; Austin McGuigan, Polk County Community Development; Stacy Palmer, Silverton Chamber of Commerce; Ray Burstedt, Strategic Economic Development Corporation; Steve McCoid, Oregon Restaurant Association; Teri Sunderland, Woodburn Company Stores; Craig Smith, Chemeketa Community College; and Hazel Patten, Community Volunteer.

The summit will be moderated by Travel Oregon's Chief Executive Officer Todd Davidson. This free "town hall" forum will foster a brainstorming roundtable designed to bring out the perceptions and reality of tourism as it relates to the business environment.

This discussion will be a catalyst to a statewide discussion so please plan on attending! Free and open to the public.

title: Salem Area Businesses Recognized at "Absolutely Fabulous" Awards Luncheon
body:
Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem presents Steve Martin, Historic Elsinore Theatre with the "Absolutely Entertaining" Award.

Travel Salem announced the recipients of this year's "Absolutely Fabulous" awards at the fifth annual "Ab Fab" awards luncheon, held on Thursday, May 15, at the Salem Convention Center.

The "Ab Fab" awards recognize tourism industry partners who go above and beyond to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers who turn ideas upside down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaborations, partnerships and strategies. 

This year, Travel Salem presented six business partners with awards:

" The Absolutely Entertaining Award was presented to the Historic Elsinore Theatre for consistently bringing quality entertainment to the Salem area and for their commitment in preserving one of Salem's historic treasures.


" Bauman's Farm and Gardens received the Absolutely Authentic Award for their understanding of how agriculture and tourism work together and for providing visitors with an authentic Oregon agricultural experience.  


" Garten Services, Inc. was presented with the Absolutely Valuable Award for their unparalleled partnership, which allows Travel Salem to effectively reach consumers, resulting in a positive economic impact on the region.


" For choosing Salem as the 2013 site for their international motorcycle rally and generating approximately $1.7 million in economic impact, The BMW Motorcycles Owners of America Association received the Absolutely "Heads in Beds" Award.


" The Absolutely "Trail Blazing" Award went to the Salem Area Trail Alliance for their continued efforts in building new trail systems for both visitors and residents to enjoy.


" For their ability to transport the world's diverse cultures to Salem and for bringing thousands of visitors to the area to view the "Breath of Heaven" ancient Near East art exhibit, The Absolutely Fabulous Award was presented to the Hallie Ford Museum of Art.

"We are extremely proud to honor these amazing people in the tourism sector, who, through their tireless work, creative energy and remarkable vision, make the Salem area one of the best places on the planet to call home!" said CEO of Travel Salem, Angie Morris, about the recipients of this year's Ab Fab awards. "They truly have demonstrated a commitment to creating the best of what Salem has to offer, helping to strengthen community and building the travel industry in powerful ways."  

Back to newsletter

title: Salem Area Businesses Recognized at "Absolutely Fabulous" Awards Luncheon
body:
Travel Salem announced the recipients of this year's Absolutely Fabulous awards at the fourth annual "Ab Fab" Awards Luncheon, held Thursday, May 21 at the Salem Convention Center. The "Ab Fab" awards recognize tourism industry partners who went above and beyond in 2014 to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers who turned ideas upside down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaborations, partnerships and strategies. 

This year, Travel Salem recognized nine business partners for their outstanding commitment to the tourism industry: 

" The Absolutely "Cultivating Success" Award was presented to The Oregon Garden for creating an outstanding new event - Christmas in the Garden - which drew a record-breaking 22,500 visitors over 14 nights in 2014. 

" The Hampton Inn & Suites received the Absolutely "5-Star" Award for their impeccable customer service and Number One ranking on Tripadvisor.com out of 314 hotels in the Willamette Valley. 

" The Absolutely "Scorin'" Award went to the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament for bringing 191 teams to Salem for the 2014 tournament and for the partnerships they've forged with other organizations to encourage attendees to experience additional activities while visiting Salem. 

" Publishing company MEDIAmerica was presented with the Absolutely "Above the Fold" Award for the exceptional job they do producing Travel Salem's annual visitors guide - considered one of the best guides in the state. 

" AleWays Brewery Tours and owner Bobby Marcum received the Absolutely "Hopping" Award for his dedication to promoting Salem's craft beer industry and the gracious hospitality that he always shows to guests on his tours.  

" The Absolutely "Cr'me de la Cr'me" Award was presented to Wild Pear Restaurant & Catering's Jessica Ritter and Cecilia Ritter James for helping to spark the Mid-Valley's culinary renaissance and for their commitment to showcasing the bounty of the Willamette Valley in their inspiring dishes. 

" Shawn Irvine, economic development director for the City of Independence, received the Absolutely "Activated" Award for his success in securing a Travel Oregon Rural Tourism Studio (RTS) Grant - designed to boost sustainable tourism in rural communities - and for his unwavering efforts to support tourism development in Polk County.

" The Absolutely Fabulous Award was presented to Willamette Valley Vineyards for the recent remodel of their tasting room and creating an award-winning visitor destination that showcases the Mid-Valley's fine wine, breathtaking scenic beauty and locally-sourced food. 

Back to newsletter

title: Salem Area Draws in Convention Business
body:
Travel Salem's convention/group sales and marketing efforts generated $5.8 million for the community in 2008-09 by attracting 43,378 convention delegates, meeting attendees and event participants to Salem. Travel Salem markets the Salem area as a premier destination; working closely with meeting and event planners who are the key decision-makers as to where meetings/conventions/events will be held.

The Salem area is fortunate to have a diverse range of indoor facilities and outdoor spaces to market for conferences, sporting events such as softball or wrestling, RV rallies, weddings and reunions, and much more. However, it is more than the facility that attracts groups to Salem. Our location, the value of the experience, the attractions and activities, and the unparalleled service and hospitality; attract not only new business, but ensure repeat business.

Travel Salem recently pinned down the 2009 West Coast World Championship Youth Wrestling Tournament hosted by Rocky Mountain Nationals. This event will take place at the Oregon State Fair & Expo Center on December 11-12, 2009 with nearly 1,500 K-8th grade participants from across the country. Families will be accompanying these athletes and many will be experiencing Salem and Oregon for the first time. Providing these guests with visitor information to promote lodging, dining, shopping and touring is vital to their enjoyment and to the local economy.

Partnerships play a key role in pulling all the pieces together to book a convention/group to Salem. Travel Salem partners with all facilities to ensure we are aggressively promoting our destination and capturing business.

You can help boost our economy by bringing your group to Salem. Contact Travel Salem for free assistance 503-581-4325, ext. 28. Travel Salem's Travel Cafe Visitors Center is located at 181 High Street NE in vibrant downtown Salem.

~ Angie Morris, President and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 10/18/09
