title: Salem Bewitched by the Spirit of Volunteerism
body:
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 10/31/10

With Halloween around the corner, we're all a little more attuned to paranormal activity in our beautiful community-paranormal being defined as: "beyond the range of normal." 'Tis the season when leaves decay, pumpkins are carved with ghoulish faces and folks dress-up front yards and themselves in ghostly, spooky ways. Let's face it, it's the time of year we invite spirits to come out and haunt us! I'd like to mention a few "beyond normal" happenings I've witnessed; a unique "spirit" haunting our community. Don't be alarmed, this spirit is a happy one: it's the spirit of volunteerism and it has taken hold of our community.

Here's a few examples of paranormal sightings observed from our Travel Salem office. One is the dedication of our volunteers who help staff our Travel Cafe Visitors Center: people like Bob Krebs, retired from the Oregon Department of Transportation (ODOT) Rail Division, who is also an expert tour guide and regularly shares his knowledge of the Salem area with visitors.

Another is how local businesses supported the recent Extreme Makeover - Home Edition cast, crew, producers and stars when they came to help renovate and film the Oregon School for the Deaf's Nightmare Factory. When Travel Salem put out the call to local businesses to create gift and VIP bags for the Extreme staff, we were flooded with support, to the tune of $80,000 worth of products, services and vouchers. The executive producer of Extreme Makeover personally relayed thanks to the community and said the gesture attested to our community's generosity.

And what about community events organized by dedicated volunteers who contribute countless hours to showcase our region as a fun place to live, work and play? Salem's First Wednesday is a perfect example of the collective work and genius of local businesses to create a dynamic venue that brings the community together while generating economic growth.

The spirit of volunteerism still looms large over the land. Keep your eyes peeled for new sightings of this paranormal activity! Happy Halloween and remember to do your part to keep this happy haunting alive!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem

title: Salem Scores Soccer Tournament ~ Again!
body:
The 3rd Annual Capitol Cup Soccer Tournament will return to Salem, June 27-29 2014. The tournament has quickly become one of the favorite tournaments to kick off the summer soccer season and is expecting to draw over 150 teams, with an estimated economic impact to Salem of over $750,000.  All games will occur in Salem.

All of the fields are conveniently located to restaurants, tax-free shopping and great hotels. Teams traveling to the tournament will have access to a personal travel coordinator. The coordinator can help you find the hotel that will best suit the teams and can help arrange team dinner reservations and assist with scheduling team activities around your soccer games.

Nearly 90% of all teams will have a single game on Friday, which allows the organizers to honor requests for late starts. For the most part, teams will have two games on Saturday with games occurring between 9 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. All teams should plan on playing at least one game on Sunday and those games will occur from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

All teams are guaranteed four games and each team will advance to the playoff rounds once the preliminary rounds have been completed. First and second place bracket champions will receive medals. Championship photos will be available to all families after the tournament. Players, coaches and managers listed on the roster will receive a customized souvenir pin.

For more information go to www.capitalcup.org to find out why the Capital Cup should be the event to kick-start your summer soccer season!

Back to newsletter

title: Salem Selected for 2013 BMW MOA Rally
body:
Motorcycle event attracts 9,000 riders

The BMW Motorcycle Owners of America (MOA) has selected the Oregon State Fairgrounds in Salem, Oregon as the location for their 2013 International Rally. The event will be taking place July 18-20, 2013. "We've had some really great events in Oregon in the past years," explains BMW MOA president Greg Feeler. "Our Rally in Redmond in 2010 was one of our best ever. We are very excited about Salem next year!"

In partnership with the Oregon Sate Fair and Expo Center, Travel Salem was instrumental in attracting the BMW MOA group to Salem. The Rally was initially bid on four years ago, and Travel Salem just recently hosted a two day tour for the rally event planners. The event has grown to average over 9,000 riders and offers its members a place to meet new people, as well as vendors who manufacture specialty motorcycle items. Event attendees can also test ride new motorcycles, or participate in one of 100 seminars and classes being offered.

"The BMW MOA is the largest brand specific motorcycle club in the world that is not owned or operated by the manufactures. They are a great group of people who are looking forward to their 2013 Rally and spending quality time in the Salem area," said Debbie McCune, Director of Sales for Travel Salem. "Salem is a hospitable community and we want this group to feel welcome, enjoy the area, and come back time and time again," said McCune.

Founded in 1972, the BMW MOA promotes relationships between individual members and BMW motorcycle clubs, unifying smaller clubs across the US. According to BMW MOA, the economic impact of this group on the Salem area is estimated between $4 and $6 million dollars.

For more information about the BMW Motorcycle Owners of America, visit www.bmwmoa.org or call headquarters at 636-394-7277.

  • Return to newsletter

title: Salem to Host Second Largest Tandem Bike Rally in the U.S.
body:
A group of passionate Salem-area tandem riders have recently announced that next year (2012), Salem will host the 27th Annual Northwest Tandem Rally, the second largest tandem rally in the U.S. A few weeks ago Travel Salem's Director of Sales, Debbie McCune, attended the Spokane Tandem Rally to pre-promote the Salem Rally. More than 600 tandem cyclists pedaled through Spokane, Washington on the Fourth of July weekend at this year's Northwest rally and Travel Salem was there to promote Salem and encourage cyclists to attend the 2012 event.

The 2012 event will take place June 29th through July 2nd on cycling routes throughout the Salem region. The organizer of the rally is Salem NWTR 2010 LLC, a group of about 14 dedicated tandem cyclists living in the Salem area. Salem NWTR will partner with The Grand Hotel in Salem and Willamette University for food services and accommodations.

One of the organizers, Kurt Haas, who races with local Capitol Velo Racing Club, says the group is busy planning routes and locations for events. Eventually they will welcome volunteers and sponsors for the rally.

The mission of the 2012 Northwest Tandem Rally; is to share the Wonders of the Willamette (WOW) Valley - its hospitality, history, and scenic bicycle routes - with tandem families and friends from the Northwest and across the US and beyond - all at an affordable price.

"Our goal is to involve community in the ride as much as possible," he said, "to benefit the riders along with the Willamette Valley, the economy, local businesses and community relationships."

He says some of the routes will have stops at local businesses like E.Z. Orchards, Willamette Valley Fruit Company, Bauman Farm and others.

Tandem teams are generally well-educated, affluent, and fit, with participants ranging from 25-60 and frequently include families with their children. The majority of NWTR participants come from Oregon, Washington and Northern California, with representation from across the country and some venturing from as far away as Europe and Australia.

Organizers are excited about the energy the event will bring to the Salem area.

"Most people haven't seen 300 or 400 tandem bikes rolling down the road together; the rally really brings a buzz to the community," said Haas who rides tandem on a three-seated bike with his wife and seven-year old daughter. "Many of the tandem riders are couples and families. This is really a family-oriented activity!"

For more information about the 2012 Salem NWTR, visit their website at www.nwtr.org/2012.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Salem to Host US Quidditch Northwest Regional Championship Tournament
body:
A little bit of Harry Potter-inspired magic is coming to Salem next year. Travel Salem is pleased to announce that it has secured the 2016 US Quidditch (USQ) Northwest Regional Championship Tournament, which will take place February 6 and 7 at the Capital Futbol Club Soccer Complex in Salem. 

The 2016 tournament will be the second regional championship for the Northwest region. (The 2015 event was held in Tukwila, Washington). Fourteen teams - approximately 280 players - from Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming and British Columbia are expected to compete in the 2016 tournament. 

Brian Chung, Travel Salem's sports and events sales manager, estimates that the cash infusion into the local economy from the tournament will be approximately $58,240.

 "We're really excited to host the USQ Northwest Regional tournament in Salem," said Chung. "Not only does it mean a spike in business for hotels, shops and restaurants during a time of year when business is typically slower, but hosting an event that is still relatively new to the Northwest is sure to generate positive publicity for Salem and draw plenty of spectators who want to see how the sport is played."

Inspired by the game featured in the Harry Potter book series, quidditch is a gender integrated, contact sport that mixes elements of rugby, dodgeball and tag. Each team has a chaser that can score goals, a keeper who defends the goal, two beaters who try to "knock out" other players and a seeker who tries to catch the snitch - which consists of a ball attached to a neutral player. Players must carry a broom between their legs at all times. 

To be selected to host a regional USQ tournament, a city must be able to provide certain essentials, such as electricity, adequate field space for matches and visitor information services throughout the tournament. "We were impressed with Salem's facilities, the level of support from the city and the enthusiasm for the sport of quidditch," said Sarah Woolsey, USQ events director. 

The top qualifiers in the Northwest Regional Championship Tournament will move on to compete in the US Quidditch Cup 9, April 16-17 in Columbia, South Carolina. 

Although there is no Salem area team currently registered with US Quidditch, it's feasible that a team could join the organization and meet the basic requirements in time to compete in the Northwest Regional Tournament in February. 

"We'd love to see a Salem area team form and then play in the regional tournament," said Woolsey. Membership in US Quidditch is open to teams and individuals in any age group in the United States. 

History of US Quidditch

Quidditch got its start in the United States in 2005 at Middlebury College when then-freshman Xander Manshel and his classmates were looking for a variation on their normal Sunday activities. Manshel and his friends laid the foundation for a game that has grown to become a widely respected, physically intense sport. Today, there are more than 4,000 athletes on almost 200 teams nationwide. 

For more information about quidditch or forming a team, go to www.usquidditch.org.

title: Salem Welcomes the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament
body:
Salem will play host to the 2nd Annual Capital Cup Soccer Tournament being held June 28-30, 2013. At least 155 teams from Oregon, Washington, California and Wyoming will gather in Salem to compete for the honor of being named the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament champions. There will be multiple champions since the tournament is divided by gender and grade level, 3rd through 12th.

Multiple venues from throughout the Salem areawill be used, including Cascade Soccer Fields, Sprague High School, South Salem High School, McKay Park, Willamette University, Corban University and Geer Park ball fields.

The estimated economic impact of this event is $1.5 million, which is significant to Salem. Each team has an average of 16 players, plus the families that travel with the teams to support their children.  

Travel Salem has been working with the Capital Cup Soccer organizers and they have partnered with eleven local hotels to assist with housing the teams.

title: Salem Wrestling Event Needs Volunteers!
body:
The K-8th grade Rocky Mountain National's West Coast World Championship held at the Oregon State Fair Expo Center on December 10th and 11th is seeking volunteers for either day to help organize, distribute information and awards, set-up, tear down and coordinate the event throughout the day.

Volunteers will receive free admission to the action-packed wrestling competition and will be aiding an event whose mission is to foster the self esteem, confidence and social skills of young wresters as they compete in a one-in-a-lifetime athletic competition.

The event is one of the highest profile K-8th grade wrestling competitions in the West Coast region and the venue offers competitions held on 10 mats throughout the center with a seating capacity of 4,000 spectators.

To volunteer for the event please contact Debbie McCune at 503-581-4325 ext. 28 or email her at dmmcune@TravelSalem.com.

title: SAVE THE DATE - Tourism Summit, January 14, 2010
body:
Travel Salem, in partnership with Travel Oregon, is hosting a regional Tourism Summit on Thursday, January 14, 2010 from 1:30-3:30 p.m. at the Red Lion Hotel and Conference Center (3301 Market St. NE, Salem). Join in the discussion!

This Summit is a forum to discuss how tourism connects to businesses and powers local economies. A diverse panel has been selected in an effort to put together a broad cross-section of expertise on a variety of issues (e.g. land use, industry, recruitment, retail, development, lodging, policy, education, etc.). Confirmed panelists include: Shelly Hansen, Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde; Steve Johnson, VIPs Industries; Austin McGuigan, Polk County Community Development; Stacy Palmer, Silverton Chamber of Commerce; Ray Burstedt, Strategic Economic Development Corporation; Steve McCoid, Oregon Restaurant Association; Teri Sunderland, Woodburn Company Stores; Craig Smith, Chemeketa Community College; and Hazel Patten, Community Volunteer.

The summit will be moderated by Travel Oregon's Chief Strategy Officer Scott West. This free "town hall" forum will foster a brainstorming roundtable designed to bring out the perceptions and reality of tourism as it relates to the business environment.

This discussion will be a catalyst to a statewide discussion so please plan on attending!

Free and open to the public. RSVP to the Travel Salem office, 503-581-4325, ext. 30 or assistant@TravelSalem.com.

title: Small and Grand Gestures to Tell Mom you Love Her!
body:
Mother's Day is just around the corner. As a child, I loved picking wild purple orchids, tying them with a pretty ribbon and giving them to my mother and grandmother. It's these simple gifts that are sometimes the most powerful - on the giving and receiving end!

While looking for Mother's Day gifts this season, don't forget those small, child-like things you once did, offering hand-picked flowers, creating fun, homemade cards, or making a handmade passport for Mom that she can redeem for family outings such as a performance, gallery walk or wine tours or even for a week's worth of house cleaning or cooking by you! Or give her the gift that keeps on giving (and that the whole family can enjoy too!). Order her a Pie of the Month - 12 pies from Willamette Valley Fruit Company and enjoy pie throughout the year. Or pick another product throughout the month like bread, soap, chocolate, or give her a gift card from a local coffee shop like Governor's Cup Coffee Roasters.

Here's another idea: take her to a place like Wavra Farms and Nursery in southeast Salem and let her pick her favorite flowers and ask the nursery to plant them for her. Then pour her a glass of her favorite pinot noir on the deck overlooking her new flower planters.

There are so many simple things you can do to show Mom your love. Another idea is to devote your time to creating new memories together by exploring our region.

Here's a few local suggestions:

Treat her to a free carriage ride at the Bush House Museum (with paid admission to the house), then take her to Historic Deepwood Estate, for their Annual Champagne Brunch on May 8th, with sumptuous dishes and desserts followed by a tour of the home. Is your mom a bird lover? Take her to Left Coast Cellars' Birdathon with the Portland Audubon Society to wander a 300 acre estate in search of birds on May 7th at 10 a.m.

Or try this grand gesture: What mom wouldn't love to float in the clouds on a hot air balloon ride with a champagne toast afterwards? Let Jim Desch from Balloon Flying Service of Oregon be your Captain Kirk over the Willamette Valley.

Head over to the Stangeland Vineyards and Winery tasting room on May 8th for a Mother's Day chocolate and wine tasting from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. Go on a walk with Mom (and the birds) at the Silver Falls Mother's Day Birding and Wildflower Festival on Saturday, May 7th and Sunday, May 8th from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.

Overwhelm your mom by immersing her in a kaleidoscope of fragrant peonies at Adelman Peony Gardens on Saturday May 7th and Sunday May 8th from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. - admission is free! Or stroll through a rainbow of irises at Schreiner's Gardens from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 2/20/11

title: Small Business Saturday-November 29
body:
In 2010, American Express founded Small Business Saturday to help businesses with their most pressing need - getting more customers. The day encourages people to shop small businesses on the Saturday after Thanksgiving. People across the country are organizing events to celebrate the small businesses in their communities. The single day has grown into a powerful movement, and more people are taking part than ever before. This year, the big day is Nov 29.

title: Something Red Art Walk and Exhibit
body:
The 12th Annual Something Red Artwalk and Exhibit is a juried show that brings the arts-in-community to downtown Salem. Travel Salem is participating as a host business for display of art during this month-long show.

The success of past years continues as Something Red highlights the holiday season for Salem visitors and residents. The event brings vitality, ambiance and a sense of arts-in-community to downtown Salem. Participating artists benefit from sales and contacts as artwork is on display to the public during the holiday month of December. This year the event is scheduled for December 3 through December 31. 

The Art Walk opening night will be Wednesday, December 3 from 5-7 p.m. Mark your calendar and plan to stroll downtown Salem, meet the artists and enjoy some great art! For more information visit www.somethingred.org.

title: Spring is a Time of Renewal
body:
It may be time for your renewal! Your membership with Travel Salem is a valuable marketing partnership. Keep your membership current and take advantage of your membership benefits.

At Travel Salem, our marketing professionals actively promote Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley utilizing strategically designed sales and marketing campaigns. Curious about how our marketing efforts impact your business? Ever wonder how your membership impacts our region's visitor industry? Let's take a look.

We are proud to share these highlights of a very successful year:

  • The 2012-13 estimated economic impact of visitors was $511.3 million. Specifically, travel-generated income for Marion & Polk counties. This represents a 2.7% increase over the previous year. Projections indicate a continued upward trend as market conditions reflect an improving economy.
  • The 2012-13 transient occupancy tax (lodging tax) kept pace with the previous year by generating $2.6 million in revenues for Salem. Occupancy was up 7% to 364,608 room nights sold. Average daily rates continue to rise. Already, reports reflect the 13-14 transient occupancy tax is up 13% over 12-13. 
  • The Willamette Valley received Trip Advisor's "Traveler's Choice ~ Best U.S. Wine Destination' - ranking 3rd out of the top 10 wine destinations in the United States, after Napa and Sonoma. Our region proudly offers visitors from all over the globe an experience rich with culinary, recreational and cultural heritage assets.

Travel Salem works hard for your business, year-round. Our efforts and your support create a strong marketing momentum that benefits both residents and visitors in our region. Thank you for your support through the renewal of your 2014-15 membership. As a Travel Salem member, you are a vital part of our region's destination marketing organization and the results we achieve. 

Thank you for renewing your commitment to our region's visitor industry as a member of Travel Salem!

title: Take Advantage of FREE Marketing Resources!
body:
Photography

We are fortunate to be surrounded by beautiful scenery and a vast array of unique and wonderful venues in the Salem and Mid-Willamette Valley area. Travel Salem wants to share this with visitors and one fantastic way is through photographs!

Images do speak a thousand words and we like to take advantage of that when it comes to promoting our region. At Travel Salem, we carefully select images that inspire and excite the viewer about our exceptional area. 

Digital images are used on the website, in social media posts, and shared with local and national media sources. We also publish a yearly, full-color Salem and Marion/Polk County Area Visitor Guide that is saturated with gorgeous images to entice visitors to our region.

We invite you to submit your photographs taken within Marion and Polk counties that include attractions, gardens, nature, recreation, dining, shopping, events, wine tasting and any other image you think captures the essence of our beautiful area.

If you have images that you would like Travel Salem to consider please review the following criteria:

  • Photos must be a minimum of 300 dpi
  • Photos should include people when possible
  • Photos with people must have a "model release' included that gives permission to use the image(s).

Please submit images either by email or send us a link to Drop Box.

If you have questions contact Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director directly at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext.27.

Events

The Travel Salem Events Calendar is the local resource for activities and events in Marion and Polk counties. Any venue within the area is qualified to submit information to the calendar, whether a member of Travel Salem, or not. Many of the events on our Events Calendar are cross promoted through our social media channels or pitched to the media. Early event submission is encouraged!  You will receive maximum exposure if your events are posted at least 60 days in advance, if not 3-6 months. This allows Travel Salem time to proof, edit, post and syndicate events to local, regional and national media outlets.

If you have any questions regarding event submission, please contact Dee Hendrix, Marketing and Online Manager at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 25.

Salem Area Visitor Guide

The 2013 Travel Salem Visitor Guide highlights lodging, trip ideas and resources in our area. It has been distributed to over 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia. Visitors frequently use the guide to take advantage of all the activities and venues our wonderful area has to offer!

Make sure your business has a good supply!  The Visitor Guide is online at TravelSalem.com, available at the Travel Cafe (181 High St. NE) or you can order copies by contacting Barb Cowan, Travel Salem's Guest Services Coordinator at bcowan@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 21. 

Watch your email for information on the upcoming 2014 Travel Salem Visitor Guide. It will soon be time to collect information for the next great edition!

If you have questions please contact Irene Bernards, Marketing and PR Director at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 27.

title: The Best of Oregon for Summer Vacations
body:
'Must See Oregon' to Help Plan Vacations

From outdoor adventures and resorts to craft brews and world" renowned wines, Oregon has it all. The state's vast array of attractions, destinations, travel, and extended vacation opportunities will be showcased at the first annual Must See Oregon event, presented by Capitol Subaru and coordinated by Class Act Events in partnership with The Oregon Garden, Travel Oregon and Travel Salem.

Must See Oregon will be held at The Oregon Garden in Silverton on Saturday, May 17 from 10 a.m.to 6 p.m. Admission to both the event and The Oregon Garden will be free that day.  Must See Oregon will spotlight the spirit that makes this state great and the destinations and points of interest that will help you explore and enjoy all that Oregon has to offer. Attendees will learn about museums, resorts, cruises and all sorts of adventures around the state.

"There is no other showcase like this in Oregon," said Must See Oregon organizer Susan Adkins. "We have so many exciting opportunities in this state and you'll have one place to go for a glimpse of Oregon's best kept secrets."

Throughout the day, visitors will be immersed in opportunities to learn more about Oregon's treasured tourism opportunities, hidden in every corner of the state. There will be exhibitors from around the state, activities such as fly casting demonstrations and live presentations from travel experts such as Steve Arndt, author of Roads Less Traveled in Oregon, to help with trip planning.

For more information visit: www.MustSeeOr.com
Facebook: facebook.com/mustseeor
Twitter: @mustseeoregon
Instagram: instagram.com/mustseeoregon

title: The Importance of a Thriving Downtown for Tourism
body:
Visitors to a region or city can get a good feel for a community from its downtown. Unique boutiques, one-of-a-kind shops, diversity of local performing and visual art, a mixture of restaurants, combined with outstanding architecture, history and festive events and promotions, characterize a successful downtown. Visitors are attracted to downtowns such as this and Salem's downtown fits that illustration perfectly. Successful downtowns are viewed as a destination in their own right. Travel Salem's Visitor Profile study points out that downtown Salem is viewed as a leading activity during a visitors stay.

Traditionally, a downtown serves as a town square or hub for community gatherings; known for its sense of welcome and hospitality. Although unique shops and promotions are available in other shopping venues, the downtown atmosphere cannot be duplicated.

The distinct look and feel of Salem's downtown core is created by the richness of its history. The Historic Elsinore Theater, a 1926 Tudor Gothic movie palace, and the Reed Opera House, are examples of the significance of historical entities in a thriving downtown community.

As Salem's living room, historic downtown is a vibrant downtown with all the elements needed to maintain its "destination" status. With its inviting atmosphere and coordinated events such as First Wednesday, downtown Salem introduces visitors to the distinctiveness of Salem and encourages the consideration of what the rest of this region has to offer.

Downtown Salem is the focus of Salem Vision 2020, a community-wide team, chaired by Mayor Janet Taylor, that works to shape the future of Salem's City Center. The foresight of Vision 2020 is to transform Salem's downtown into a vibrant, year-round regional destination for employees, visitors, and residents by the year 2020.

With its current amenities, development, revitalization and community involvement, downtown Salem will continue to be one of the region's major destinations.

~ Angie Morris, Travel Salem's CEO

* Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 3/22/09

title: The Stories Salem Tells
body:
Our region is full of places steeped in history, so when you go outside this spring, keep your ears tuned for stories from Oregon's past, they travel like dandelion fluff on the air! Listen carefully, you may hear something remarkable.

Stories abound here, from A.C. Gilbert's magical tales of pole-vaulting and toy-inventing to the stories of two lady landscape architects (Elizabeth Lord and Edith Schryver) whose garden designs are memorialized at Bush's Pasture Park and Historic Deepwood Estate.

Learn a story about how Salem looked to early pioneers through a view of native plants and trees at the remnant oak savannah at Bush's Pasture Park. In March at the Bush Barn Art Center you can learn how artists are using the past for inspiration in the "Parks for the People" exhibit featuring a display of several artists commissioned to draw or paint figurative works based upon historic photos of Lord and Schryver.

At Historic Deepwood Estate on March 15th from 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., learn about silk art embroidery, a craft that upper class Victorian women employed to earn an independent living. Listen to lectures by Donna Cardwell, author of Silk Art Embroidery, A Woman's History of Ornament and Empowerment, along with silver and linen expert Lisa Hand from Wind Horse Antiques. The event is accompanied by three-course tea and a house tour.

And at the Historic Elsinore Theatre later that evening at 7 p.m., you'll be transported back to the Oregon Trail through an Oregon Film special screening of Meek's Cutoff, an Oregon film featured in Sundance, Toronto and Venice film festivals that depicts a short-cut taken by a group of Oregon pioneers that had fatal results. Tickets to the benefit for the Oregon Cultural Trust can be purchased at www.elsinoretheatre.com.

Salem has stories underfoot, so walk slowly as you go about. Retired Linfield College historian John Ritter and creative director for QA Properties, Rebecca Maitland, have been exploring 18 buildings downtown, digging for clues to Salem's past. They plan to host tours that show, in part, a bustling underground center of commerce during the Wild West days. Highlights of the underground tour include an antique bank vault, a stairwell that leads nowhere, a 1930's grocery drop with painted grocery aisles and lockers, a 1920s mural in an old underground cafe and an intact gold drop at the Capitol Building Center (where they claim you can still see specks of gold.) Tours plan to start this June.

In coming weeks, historian Hazel Patton, who spearheaded Salem's Riverfront Carousel, and a group of history lovers are organizing artifacts from the early days at the Oregon State Hospital (including the tub that was thrown out the window in One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest) for the new, upcoming Oregon State Hospital Museum which will open in April of 2012 on the OSH campus in one of the remaining Kirkbride buildings.

And speaking of history in the air! At Willamette University on February 26th and 27th, the Willamette Master Chorus and a few WU choirs will fill Hudson Hall and literally breathe life into a piece of musical history, Handel's brilliant oratorio, the Messiah, first performed in Dublin in the Spring of 1742.

We know the power of stories and storytelling at Travel Salem and that's why next month, we're hosting a storyteller at our Marketing Exchange event. Marilyn Morton, director of the Monmouth/Independence Chamber of Commerce will come to tell how storytelling turned Independence's Ghost Walk from a small gathering into an event that serves more than a thousand! On March 17th, hear Marilyn speak about "Community Spirits: Turning Ghost Stories into Tourism Dollars!" from 11:45 a.m. to 1:15 p.m. at the Dallas Event Center on 939 Main Street. For more information visit: www.TravelSalem.com.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 2/20/11 

  • Back to newsletter

title: The Value of Twitter in 2,247 Characters
body:
Twitter is a social networking site that allows friends, family, and co-workers to communicate and stay connected through the exchange of short (140 characters or less) and frequent answers to one simple question: What are you doing?

It has quickly evolved into a tool that businesses and organizations use to market themselves to a generation focused on obtaining information using technology.

Travel Salem has been using Twitter to communicate and stay connected with consumers and regional partners through the exchange of quick real-time updates. News, upcoming events, and promotions are some examples of what Travel Salem has been tweeting about to an audience of local, national, and international "followers" (people that follow our tweets). In addition, information sent on Twitter is displayed on a public timeline, making tweets (the message that is sent out) viewable to more than 14 million users in the U.S. alone. Talk about getting your name out there!

Travel Salem's social media strategy using Twitter has already seen amazing results -the Travel Cafe coverage on KGW's Live@7, Statesman Journal covering tweets during a recent Santiam River rafting trip, and numerous blogs written about local attractions and lodging facilities from a well-known travel writer from California.

Are you using Twitter already? Follow us at www.twitter.com/travelsalem and we'll follow back! Referencing fellow "tweeps" (people/businesses that use Twitter) on tweets enables us to package the Salem region as a whole by driving consumers that view our tweets to your businesses' page.

Interested in "jumping on the bandwagon?" Contact Anthony Tham, Travel Salem's Public Relations Manager, to assist you in setting up your Twitter account and for effective strategies to strengthen your brand and positively position your business or organization in front of consumers. If you're not looking to create an account but want to be involved, you can feed us information about your business so that we can use to develop a tweet under Travel Salem's account, which represents the Salem region. Information can range from upcoming events, news, promotions, etc. Send possible tweets to Anthony Tham, atham@travelsalem.com with "Twitter" on the subject line.

title: Touring Salem -- Outside the Bottle
body:
Travel Salem recently hosted a group of 20 wine bloggers from the U.S., Canada and Israel. Yes, Israel. They were attending a wine bloggers conference being held in Portland and Travel Salem reached out to event organizers offering a "Salem, Outside the Bottle" pre-conference tour for interested delegates. Our goal? To showcase this region to these 20 individuals who would in turn promote it as a great place for wine and travel.

We picked the group up in Portland and made many stops along the way showcasing wine but also the "outside the bottle" amenities of the region.

Our first stop was the Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum in McMinnville. The bloggers were treated to Evergreen's varietals as well as a tour of the aviation and space museum and water park.

Then we headed south on 99W and enjoyed a relaxing stop at Johan Vineyards where a twisted horned cow welcomed us. The bloggers were busy snapping pictures and verbally and visually admiring the beauty of the pastoral geography. At Johan they experienced not only the fruit of the vine but they were introduced to "wiking." Wiking is a combination of hiking while enjoying wine. We "wiked" through the vineyard toward our final destination for the day, Left Coast Cellars.

The wine bloggers took part in a barrel tasting at Left Coast Cellars and a mouth-watering barbecue in the "Tree House" -a rustic covering adorned with twinkle lights. The barbecue also featured a variety of Left Coast Cellars wines, including a white Pinot, and the bloggers were able to share a knowledgeable wine exchange with the winemaker.

As we headed toward Salem that night the motor coach was lit up by hand held devices. Already, these wine and travel influencers were blogging about their day. They were producing stories and posting photos promoting all they had experienced during day one of their tour. This is the reason we organized this event!

The next morning we kicked off the day at the Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill with an invigorating tour regarding Salem's wool industry and their exhibit "History on Tap." Although this exhibit is no longer available it was really interesting. Be sure to check out their next exhibit "The Art & Tradition of Kimono" (Sept. 21-Dec. 24).

Continuing on our tour we visited Willamette Valley Vineyards where all of the bloggers were treated to a cellar tour and tasting; a T-shirt that states "It's Willamette Dammit" and a gourmet lunch including wine pairing tips and discussion.

As we wound our way through the country roads to Piluso Vineyard & Winery the conversation in the motor coach was lively. These folks were overwhelmed by the beauty of the region. They were discovering quality wines, sharing and learning about Oregon's wine making process and many were experiencing Oregon for the first time. A large majority asked questions about moving to the area and how they would love to live here.

The bloggers discovered a "boutique" winery at Piluso Vineyard & Winery and they took the opportunity to delve into the detail of the vines, the soil and how those translate into the grape and the flavors it extracts.

We ended our tour at E.Z. Orchards Farm Market sampling peach and strawberry shortcake and their hard cidre, which is produced similarly to wine. These wine connoisseurs were delighted with the cidre and really enjoyed learning more about the process.

As the tour was winding down I realized that although I live here, and I'm well versed in the bounty and wealth of opportunities for visitors, this was the first time I experienced the Salem area through the fresh eyes of twenty "wine hungry" visitors. Visitors whose purpose is to share their wine experiences; to share their travel experiences and to encourage their readers to visit new places and savor all the beauty that is wine"_and everything that is also "outside the bottle."

As I write this article, I can barely keep up with the blogs posted from the tour and the positive comments regarding our area and the tour. I would be remiss for not mentioning that everything included in this tour was donated by those mentioned above as well as four local lodging establishments that contributed the overnight rooms for the bloggers (Grand Hotel in Salem, Hampton Inn & Suites, Red Lion Hotel and the Comfort Suites Salem Airport). Thank you for helping make this promotion of the Salem area possible!

Here are a few of the bloggers comments to share:

"Love Oregon and Oregonians!!!" ~ WineCountryGetaways

"The wineries, people and wines were just the best. I am so impressed with the people we met and the wine they craft. As Mac Arthur said during WWII we will return." ~ Mikeonwines.com

"The experience that Travel Salem provided for our small group of wine bloggers attending the 2012 Wine Bloggers Conference in Portland was absolutely first rate. The variety of activities was such a great blend of cultural attractions, wineries and the great Oregon outdoors. Everyone was so gracious - I'm still blown away by the hospitality. Thank you, thank you and I look forward to a return visit to Salem and the surrounding counties." ~ Pursuingpinot.com

"I'm really glad that you added cultural stops in addition to the wineries. I only wish we had more time at each place! Which means I must return for a longer visit. This was a great introduction to the Willamette Valley for me, and I now have a better awareness of what Oregon is doing in the wine world. I also appreciated the variety of wineries. I don't think we had a bad wine." ~ winefashionista.com

~Originally published September 21, 2012 on Travel Salem's blog on StatesmanJournal.com by Angie Morris.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Tourism Boosts All Sectors of the Economy
body:
Travel Salem's "street teams" hit downtown Salem last week during National Tourism Week (May 8-16) to ask Salem residents about what tourism means to them and how it affects their lives. We also reached out through social media channels to hear from online followers.

A Local Perspective
How does tourism to the Salem area help the local economy?

" "Tourism brings in money. Visitors take good thoughts of Salem back to their own communities." Hazel P. from Salem

" "Of course! Tourism helps any economy." Don A. from Salem. (Don had a visitor with him from Bellingham, Wash.)

" "Yes, more people visiting means more money for the local economy." Eric C. from Salem

Where would you take visiting friends or relatives to showcase your city?

"  "Downtown - cute shops, good restaurants and a nice atmosphere. I think people would also take visitors just outside of town to Silver Falls State Park and The Oregon Garden." Brant W. from Salem

" "Local wineries, downtown and Silver Creek Falls." Randy M. from Salem

" "I just had visitors here enjoying Salem! We went to A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village, Salem's Riverfront Carousel and Willamette Valley Vineyards." Wendy J. from Salem

"  "Salem's downtown has nice local shops and a nice classic feel." Don H. from Portland

We also asked folks how much money Salem area visitors generate to our local economy. Some of the responses included: $12,000, $1.5 million, $3 million and $50 million. In reality, roughly $500 million is generated by visitors to the Salem area. All of the respondents were pleasantly surprised to learn about tourism's significant impact.

Just the Facts
Tourism is a vital component of economic development, serving as one of America's largest industries and employers. In the Salem area, tourism is responsible for generating $18.6 million in tax receipts (2008 Travel Impacts research by Dean Runyan Associates), and the $500 million generated by visitors in the Salem area is responsible for 6,000 jobs. Simply put, when people travel, the economy grows, jobs are created, and the money goes right back into the local community.

One Degree of Separation
We all encounter someone directly involved with the tourism industry each day. It can be at the local coffee shop or specialty boutique; during lunch at your favorite restaurant; enjoying the agricultural offerings of a farmers' market; while purchasing tickets to a theatrical performance; laughing over a glass or mug of award-winning wine or beer; or while fishing, birding or hiking. It can be as simple as fueling your car. All of these experiences and many more are tied to the tourism industry. Now think of all the indirect connections. What about the farmer that provides the ingredients for that amazing meal, or the paper product vendor that supplies your favorite coffee shop? And what about the realtor who is working with someone who, after visiting Salem, is now interested in relocating? Tourism touches all of us and connects with all corners of the economy.

Mirror, Mirror on the Wall"_
Promoting the Salem area isn't about finding the "fairest of them all;" it is about promoting all of the various amenities of the region in an integrated way that connects with people and their interests. Selling the entire Salem area - not placing all of our marketing eggs into one basket - is important to attract a wide variety of people with diverse interests, who will stay longer to experience all the region has to offer. A visitor could experience a white water rafting trip on the Santiam River and then spend the evening at Historic Deepwood Estate's Wine Festival. That is the beauty of the Salem area - it really does have something for everyone!

Understanding and Confirmation
As our "street teams" discovered, the majority of people interviewed understand that tourism is a good, robust industry that adds to Salem's economic health. Some of our interviewees actually had visitors with them, which made it evident that visitors are among us each day adding to the vitality of our region. There was one couple that was from Sausalito, Calif. and, although they didn't participate in our research, they were thrilled to learn about the Travel Cafe Visitors Center and how it can assist them with planning their Salem adventure"_another happy customer!

 Yes, tourism works for America and Salem!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 5/16/10

title: Travel Oregon Announces Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program
body:
The Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program was signed by the Oregon Legislature in 2011 to promote wine and culinary tourism in the state. The revenues from the sale of the Wine Country license plate will be used to support culinary projects and tourism programs in Oregon. The program launched May 1, 2015. 

The mission of Travel Oregon is: "A better life for Oregonians through strong, sustainable local economies." Travel Oregon has established a program to make grant awards to "tourism promotion agencies for tourism wine and culinary tourism." The revenue generated by the sale of the Wine Country Plates is enabling over $230,000 available for grant awards in grants of not less than $2,500 or more than $40,000, inclusive of match and subject to matching and other requirements described in the Grants Guidelines.

Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program: The revenues from the sale of the Wine Country license plate will be used to support culinary projects and tourism programs in Oregon. Guidelines to implement this effort are being developed. The 2015/2016 grant cycle has $230,000 available to be awarded in grants of not less than $2,000 or more than $40,000, inclusive of match and subject to matching and additional requirements. Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program Guidelines

Eligible Applicants
Incorporated nonprofit or government units responsible for tourism promotion of a destination on a year-round basis, a nonprofit entity that manages tourism-related economic develop plans, programs and projects, and regional or statewide associations that represent entities that rely on tourism-related business for more than 50 percent of their total income are eligible to apply. Successful grant projects and initiatives must be directly related to promotion of wine and culinary tourism in Oregon.  

Interested in Applying?
Any eligible organization interested in a grant application will be required to contact the local Destination Marketing Organization and Regional Destination Marketing Organization to discuss grant project ideas prior to submitting the Grant Project Idea Worksheet to Travel Oregon. Once the idea worksheet has been reviewed, grant applicants will receive the link to submit an application online. These details and more can be found in the Grant Guidelines.  

Oregon Wine Country License Plate ~ Image Credit: Oregon DMV

Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Adds New Staff
body:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce the addition of three new staff members to its team. 

Kristine Lindholm,
Administrative Assistant
Brian Chung,
Sports and Events Sales Manager
Lourdes Gomez,
Destination Development Manager

Kristine Lindholm is the new administrative assistant for Travel Salem. Originally from Eastern Oregon, Kristine has 15 years of customer service and hospitality experience. She currently serves in a dual role for Travel Salem, working on various projects in an administrative capacity three days a week and working in the Travel Cafe and Visitors Center two days each week. Prior to joining Travel Salem as a paid employee, Kristine volunteered her time assisting visitors in the Travel Cafe and Visitors Center. Contact Kristine at 503-581-4325 x30 or email: klindholm@travelsalem.com.

Brian Chung joins the organization as the new sports and events sales manager. In this new role, Brian is responsible for bringing new sporting events to the Salem area as well as helping current events grow and expand. Brian has more than eight years of experience in the tourism industry, including serving as the group sales manager for Visit Alexandria and as the national sales manager for Choose Chicago. He holds a degree in tourism administration from Bowling Green State University. Brian can be reached at (503) 581-4325 x59 or bchung@travelsalem.com. 

Lourdes Gomez is Travel Salem's new destination development manager and will focus on facilitating the development of new and existing tourism products and opportunities in the region. Most recently, Lourdes worked as an international sales manager for Choose Chicago. She also worked in tourism sales for the Mexico Tourism Board.  Lourdes is a graduate of Northeastern Illinois University and holds a master's degree from Ohio University. Contact her at (503) 581-4325 x33 or by email: lgomez@travelsalem.com. 

"We're so pleased to have these three talented new staff members join our team," says Travel Salem CEO Angie Morris. "Each one brings a wealth of expertise and experience to their respective roles, which will help us generate an even greater positive economic impact for our region."

Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Announces Recipients of Annual Absolutely Fabulous Awards
body:
Travel Salem is proud to announce the recipients of the 2011-12 Absolutely Fabulous Awards presented at their May 17, 2012 Marketing Exchange luncheon.

The annual Ab Fab (Absolutely Fabulous) awards recognize people and organizations in the Salem area (including Marion & Polk counties) that have pushed the envelope and turned ideas upside-down and inside out to capture the best return on their marketing, collaboration, partnerships, innovation and regional strategies! They are Absolutely Fabulous!

The eight Travel Salem Ab Fab awards were presented to:

  • Dwane Brenneman - Absolutely Dedicated Award
    For his dedication to Travel Salem and serving as the Association's Chair 
  • BEST WESTERN PLUS Mill Creek Inn - Absolutely 24/7 Award
    For serving as a Travel Plaza visitor information center for the Salem area
  • A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village - Absolutely Hands-On Award
    For their Hands-On approach to supporting children's education through fun; developing promotions that add to Salem's vibrant community and quality of life; and working in partnership to attract visitors to the community.
  • Jerry Lauzon - Absolutely "OOM-PAPA" Award
    For his 20+ years as the Mt. Angel Oktoberfest's volunteer PR & Marketing Director and his ability to bring people together for the good of the community.
  • Lancaster Mall - Absolutely Active Award
    For being active in the community and for the health of area residents (e.g. mall walkers program; serving as a visitor information location; tour & travel trade fair) 
  • World Beat Festival/Salem Multicultural Institute - Absolutely Global Award
    For their tireless efforts to support all cultures and celebrate diversity.
  • Enchanted Forest - Absolutely Inventive Award
    For 40+ years of innovation and outstanding creativity that has attracted millions of visitors to the area.
  • Nancy Stockdale - Absolutely Fabulous Award
    For her entrepreneurial spirit; creative thinking and her support of Salem's cultural community.

body:
Travel Salem's newly launched Greeters program is receiving national and statewide media attention for good reason.  As one of five Greeters programs in the nation this new visitor services is in demand and you can help us spread the word! Salem Greeters is now providing volunteer guides for visitors to downtown Salem. 

Greeters are volunteers who take individual tourists and small groups of 6 or less on informal, unscripted tours around the city's most iconic places and share their personal perspectives for a truly authentic Salem experience. 

Greeters are part of a global sustainable tourism effort and make visitors feel welcome, comfortable and excited about our city. If you are interested in becoming part of the Salem Greeter program, please contact lgomez@travelsalem.com.

title: Travel Salem Hires MEDIAmerica as Publisher of the Salem Area Visitors Guide
body:
Travel Salem recently announced MEDIAmerica as the new Salem Area Visitors Guide publisher.  In its seventeenth year, the Salem Area Visitors Guide is the official visitors guide and resource for visitors to the Salem and Marion and Polk counties region.  The guide is distributed to 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia and serves as the response piece to all Salem inquiries generated through Travel Salem's advertising, public relations and consumer engagement strategies.

MEDIAmerica is an integrated publishing company focusing in three core areas that touch everyone's lives: business, home and travel.  Oregon-owned and operated since 1981, MEDIAmerica is the most consistent and successful publishing company in Oregon. Since 1995, MEDIAmerica has established itself as the leader in Pacific Northwest travel and tourism publishing and content development.  Some of MEDIAmerica's titles include: Oregon Business Magazine, Oregon Home Magazine, Discover Portland, Oregon Things to See & Do, Oregon Official State Travel Guide and Green Living.

"MEDIAmerica will take the Salem Area Visitors Guide to a new level through creative content, layout and strategies to drive consumers to direct point of sale opportunities on the TravelSalem.com website.  Travel Salem's partnership with MEDIAmerica is beneficial to the entire region!" said Irene Bernards, marketing and PR director for Travel Salem.

Advertising sales for the Salem Area Visitors Guide will begin in November and run through January.  Businesses interested in learning more about Travel Salem and the Salem Area Visitors Guide can contact Irene Bernards at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27 or Salem Area Visitors Guide advertising opportunities contact Terra Moreland at terram@mediamerica.net or 503-445-8830.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Hires New Marketing and Online Manager
body:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce that Dee Hendrix joined the Travel Salem Marketing and Communications team in June. As the new Marketing and Online Manager, Hendrix will be responsible for managing the Travel Salem website, creation and implementation of e-newsletters and managing the digital needs of Travel Salem programs promoting Salem and Marion and Polk Counties for leisure, convention and event tourism. 

Hendrix brings with her over 17 years experience in the field of advertising, marketing and communications design. Prior to joining Travel Salem, Dee worked as Communications Director for Salem's nonprofit children's museum, A. C. Gilbert's Discovery Village. While there, she re-developed and implemented the museum's communications plan to promote the museum, its educational programs and special events. She was responsible for creating promotional materials, and developing and implementing a thorough website redesign. She also helped A. C. Gilbert's Discovery Village by promoting events and programs using social media platforms and provided media relations for the museum.

She holds two degrees from Willamette University, with post graduate studies in Natural Science Illustration from Rhode Island School of Design.

"I have known Dee for many years and have always been impressed with her online and design expertise," said Irene Bernards, Travel Salem's Marketing & PR Director.  "Travel Salem is extremely fortunate to have added another seasoned professional to our team. The MarCom department, with Dee's skill set, will be able to implement some new bells and whistles that will enhance our efforts," said Bernards.

Dee can be reached at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 25.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Hires New Public Relations Manager
body:
Photography

Travel Salem is looking for high resolution images that we can use, rights free, throughout our print, online and social marketing platforms. We are looking for photos within Marion and Polk counties including attractions, gardens, nature, recreation, dining, shopping, events, wine tasting or any image that you think might pique the interest of visitors.

Travel Salem has found that a picture does say a thousand words. We have attracted weddings to the area just from some of the images we have used in the Salem Area Visitors Guide. We weave beautiful photography into all of our marketing efforts and we hear from visitors that the materials we produce are lovely, inspiring and gorgeous.

If you have images that you would like Travel Salem to consider please review the following criteria:

  • Photos must be a minimum of 300dpi
  • Photos should be experiential and include people when possible
  • Photos with people must have a "model release" included that gives permission to use images.

If your images meet the criteria please send or deliver them on a disc to:

Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director
Travel Salem, 181 High St. NE, Salem, Oregon 97301

If you have questions contact Irene directly at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

Events

Please remember to self-submit your events for 2013 for TravelSalem.com through the online form. Travel Salem refers to the events listing frequently when pitching story ideas to the media. We are already pitching summer and fall 2013 story ideas so the sooner your events are submitted the better. Early event submission is also best for visitors who are already planning their 2013 vacations.

For your event to receive maximum exposure you must submit it at least 60 days before the actual event. This gives Travel Salem time to proof, edit, post and syndicate your event to local, regional and national media outlets.

If you have any questions regarding event submission please contact Kathie Reeves, Marketing Manager at kreeves@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 24.

title: Travel Salem Honors Exceptional Tourism Partners at "Absolutely Fabulous" Awards Event!
body:
Travel Salem announced the recipients of their "Absolutely Fabulous" Awards at the Second Annual "Ab Fab" Awards Luncheon Thursday, May 19, 2011 at Northern Lights Theatre Pub. Local celebrity, Sal, the Golden Pioneer jumped down off the Oregon State Capitol to greet visitors to the event!

Mayor Anna Peterson was there to help celebrate the event and read a proclamation from the City of Salem to recognize National Tourism Week.

The Ab Fab Awards recognize tourism industry partners who have gone above and beyond in 2010-11 to increase the economic impact of visitors. These recipients are movers and shakers whose collaboration and partnerships, innovation, vision, awareness, environmental initiatives, product development and regional strategies are Absolutely Fabulous!

Listed below are the winners of the 2011 Ab Fab Award in each category:

"Absolutely Carpe Diem" Award - Salem's Underground Tours - Rebecca Maitland
For seizing the opportunity of bringing to life another cultural asset to share with visitors and the community.

"Absolutely Pioneering" Award - Virginia Green
For her absolute support of all things heritage in Salem.

"Absolutely Keystone" Award - Chemeketa Community College
For the way they champion education and training in the tourism industry!

"Absolutely Green" Award - Grand Cru Wine Tours - Byron Williams
For their commitment to having a sustainable business from first sip to last nibble.

"Absolutely a Home Run" Award - City of Salem Softball Program
For elevating Salem softball to the National level and bringing millions of dollars in economic impact to our community.

"Absolutely Gets it!" Award - Willamette Art Center - Karl Knudson
For the wonderful way they've brought art to the people!

"Absolutely Thinking Big" Award - The Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde
For their remarkable collaboration with our heritage sites to give visitors a truly authentic taste of Oregon.

"Absolutely Fabulous" Award - Ron Cooper
For the way his stellar photographs help brand and promote our beautiful region.

"We are extremely proud to honor these amazing people in the tourism sector, who, through their tireless work, creative energy and remarkable vision make the Salem area one of the best places on the planet to call home!" said CEO of Travel Salem, Angie Morris, about the recipients of this award. "They truly have demonstrated a commitment to creating the best of what Salem has to offer, helping strengthen community and building the travel industry in powerful ways!"

  • Back to the newsletter

title: Travel Salem Honors Local Businesses
body:
En route to Travel Salem's first annual "Absolutely Fabulous" Awards Luncheon, on May 20 at Willamette Valley Vineyards, attendees experienced Oregon's version of the "red carpet" - a lush and rolling hillside up to the winery; stopping every so often to enjoy the amazing panoramic views of our very own "green carpet," also known as the Willamette Valley.

May is National Tourism Month, and as we gathered for the "Ab Fab" awards, it was the perfect time to recognize tourism industry partners who have gone above and beyond this past year to attract visitors to our region and drive $500 million in economic impact to our communities.

The Ab Fab Awards paid tribute to many exceptional tourism partners, here's a few: "Absolutely Green" Award to the Salem Conference Center for their numerous green initiatives to reduce their carbon footprint; "Absolutely Thinking Big" Award to the Willamette Heritage Center for their ability to think big and create an umbrella organization that will benefit a number of heritage resources; and the "Absolutely Fabulous" Award went to"_ the Statesman Journal for their commitment to spreading the word about the wondrous bounty of the region, and sharing stories about how tourism touches every corner of the economy and improves the quality of life for all of us that live here. Visit TravelSalem.com for the complete list of winners.

During the Ab Fab awards ceremony, I looked out and saw the folks who day in and day out, follow their dreams and pour their hearts into their work, making the Salem area one of the best places on the planet to call home. Not only does Travel Salem applaud the achievements of our award recipients, we also applaud all of our partners in the tourism industry. You are all Absolutely Fabulous!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
* Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 5/30/10

title: Travel Salem Hosts Travel and Food Writers -- Members Add Personal Touch
body:
On July 8th and 9th, Travel Salem hosted a handful of travel and food writers on a Familiarization (FAM) Tour through the Salem region. The hospitality and generosity of local businesses and organizations made the FAM tour a huge success.

We'd like to thank these businesses for contributing products for the writers welcome baskets: Willamette Valley Fruit Company, Smokin' Mike's Seafood Delights, The Arbor, Grand Vines, Cherry Country Orchard and Chocolate Factory, S.L.A.B Soap and Fresh to You Produce & Garden Center.

Travel Salem would like thank the participating businesses for their partnership and share the following details of the FAM tour to enlighten others about the richness of our region. A handful of writers stayed at The Grand Hotel in Salem the first evening. The next day, the group started the morning taking a pedicab ride along the Salem Riverfront, with breakfast, tea and a tour led by Lois Cole at Historic Deepwood Estate. The writers met at the future site of the Oregon State Hospital Museum (opening April 2012) where they viewed artifacts of psychiatric medicine with local historian Hazel Patton and curator Kylie Pine-special thanks to Jodie Jones, Deputy Director of the Oregon State Hospital Replacement Project. Locals Rebecca Maitland and historian John Ritter hosted the writers on a special "Salem Underground Tour" of downtown including a visit to a historic gold drop and a Disco Tech frozen in time.

We'd like to thank Karo Thom of Alcyone Cafe & Catering for donating delicious curried chicken salad and other European fare for the lunch at Willamette Valley Vineyards (WVV). Jim Bernau with WVV shared their world-class wine and dessert from their great restaurant. Next, we headed to the Radtke family business, Gilgamesh Brewing Company, who greeted the writers warmly at their brewery. Special thanks to Bryon Williams at Grand Cru Wine Tours who donated his time, transportation and expertise in wine pairing along with wine, pate and cheese to the event and John and Kevin Zielinski for a tour of E.Z. Orchards Farm Market and a taste of their amazing hard cider and fresh berry shortcake.

We'd like to also thank Chef Jeff Nizlek who prepared an unforgettable dinner at the Silver Grille in Silverton. A special thanks to Robin and Larry at the beautiful and secluded Elkhorn Valley Inn Bed and Breakfast for hosting the writers at an overnight stay and a delicious breakfast in the morning!

Brianne Bridges and Winemaker Jerry Murray from Van Duzer Vineyards greeted the writers and provided an amazing lunch. Jerry introduced his wines to the writers. We then met Ivy Hover at Left Coast Cellars, to enjoy a special barrel tasting with Winemaker Luke McCollom and enjoyed delicious appetizers from their cafe and then took a hike on one of the new trails around the vineyard.

"Travel Salem appreciates the generosity and integrity of the participating organizations and businesses, their flexibility and the way they epitomize what's best about the hospitality industry," said Jenie Skoy, Travel Salem's PR Manager who organized the press trip. "The writers raved about the treatment they received in the Salem area and the exceptional hospitality by everyone they encountered. Travel Salem's partners have made an indelible mark and helped brand our region as a premier visitor destination."

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem join forces with SalemAlive.com - Absolutely Eventful to bring new, comprehensive website of Salem Events
body:
Since the summer of 2007, a group of Salem's large downtown employers have been actively pursuing Vision 2020 projects to enhance the heart of the City - downtown, north downtown, and the Edgewater/Wallace area of West Salem. From this collaboration, SalemAlive.com, a comprehensive website of Salem events, has been created.

Travel Salem provided the TravelSalem.com website as a host for SalemAlive.com. Residents and visitors can easily access additional information regarding attractions, special packages, and promotions to encourage the discovery of their community and the two-county region.

One of the Vision 2020 goals, identified in community conversations last year, was to better coordinate the marketing and advertising of City Center activities. A subcommittee was formed specifically tasked with creating a broad-reaching, single source of events information to bring Salem residents and visitors to the City Center. The subcommittee includes several local businesses including Travel Salem, Grand Hotel in Salem, Willamette University, Mission Mill Museum, , Go Downtown Salem!, Chemeketa Community College, Chamber of Commerce, Salem Health, and Elsinore Theatre.

SalemAlive.com went live on March 30 and allows residents to search for activities within the City Center, by location or interest area. SalemAlive.com also offers residents the ability to "self-submit" events that may be of interest to residents and visitors alike.

title: Travel Salem Launches "Absolutely Giving Back" --- Program aims at assisting charitable organizations
body:
Travel Salem promotes the Salem area as a leisure tourism and convention and event destination strengthening the communities it serves through increased visitor expenditures - $496 million in 2008. However, Travel Salem is also committed to strengthening the region by giving back through the organization's "Absolutely Giving Back" program.

Travel Salem holds various events throughout the year such as Marketing Exchange Luncheons, Team Salem meetings, and special events. Travel Salem also operates the Travel Cafe Visitors Center located downtown Salem at 181 High Street NE. These activities, along with the Travel Cafe, attract thousands of people. In an effort to "Absolutely Give Back" Travel Salem is collecting canned or non-perishable food items and new and used winter coats for children throughout the year at the Travel Cafe.

Travel Salem will donate the contributions in a timely manner to various local charities or aid organizations.

Support Travel Salem's "Absolutely Giving Back" campaign and your local community by visiting the Travel Cafe (181 High St. NE, Salem) with contributions.

title: Travel Salem Launches an Interactive Online Map
body:
Travel Salem recently launched a new Interactive Online Map, a media-rich tool on the TravelSalem.com website dedicated to promoting our beautiful region as a visitor destination. The Interactive Online Map (IOM) helps visitors plan their mid-Willamette Valley experience. Currently the map visually represents the region's diverse cultural and heritage assets. Future phases will showcase culinary highlights, recreation hotspots, public gardens and more.

"Travel Salem's goal with implementation of this Interactive Online Map is to draw more attention and visitation to the Salem and mid-Willamette Valley area through illustrating and promoting the rich and diverse offerings of our area," said Kathie Reeves, marketing manager for Travel Salem.

The IOM is also a great tool to help local residents learn more about attractions in their  backyard and is a great resource to employ when planning trips for visiting friends and family.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Makes List of 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon
body:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce it has been selected as one of the "100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon" by Oregon Business magazine. The 100 Best Nonprofits list is comprised of the top 34 large, 33 medium and 33 small nonprofits that participated in the survey. Travel Salem was ranked as the 25th best small nonprofit.  

The rankings were based on an independent assessment of an employer's workplace practices and the confidential input of employees, who were asked to rate their satisfaction in a number of categories including work environment, mission and goals, career development and learning, benefits and compensation, and management and communications. More than 150 nonprofits and over 5,000 employees participated in the seventh annual survey. 

"Those of us who choose nonprofit careers do so for the chance to serve a cause greater than ourselves," said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. "Travel Salem attracts and retains amazing, talented staff, who bring their "A-game' and give a little bit of their heart to their job every single day. There is no question why they are some of the best in the industry."

The free, voluntary survey was conducted by DHM Research along with a research editor at Oregon Business magazine. The "Top 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon" is featured in the October issue of Oregon Business magazine.

There's light on the horizon! The rating for this presentation is "E" for everyone. Every unbridled idea is on the table so be sure to attend!

Call 503-581-4325 ext. 58 now to reserve your seat!

Keynote Speaker:
Angie Morris
Angie Morris was hired as the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Travel Salem in February 2007 after a nationwide search. Angie's high caliber of creative marketing skills coupled with her nonprofit administration, management and leadership skills, as well as her knowledge and ties to Salem made her the ideal CEO for Travel Salem.

During her tenure with Travel Salem Angie has reinvented the organization through pioneering and creative marketing, relationship development and innovation. Examples include Travel Salem's customized membership program, built to suit the diverse needs of businesses; the award-winning Travel Cafe Visitors Center, created through fundraising and collaborative partnerships; the creation of the nation's first Wine Country specialty license plate, that will serve as a rolling billboard for the region while generating revenue for the tourism industry; and the formation of Cultivating Communities, a foundation based on tourism education and awareness.

Angie's professional history includes serving as the Executive Director for Pentacle Theatre, and working for the Portland Opera Broadway Across America series as their Director of Marketing and Public Relations managing a $1.5 million annual budget, generating $9-12 million in ticket sales annually.

title: Travel Salem Named Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon
body:
Travel Salem has been selected as a "Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" by Oregon Business magazine. The rankings were unveiled at a luncheon held at the Hilton Portland & Executive Tower on Tuesday, June 1, 2010. Travel Salem was one of only five Salem businesses recognized - and the only nonprofit - ranking 80th overall.

Travel Salem's "Green Team," a group of employees in charge with making the workplace more sustainable, led the way in developing an eco-savvy culture that buy-in to sustainable practices. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE through Marion County's business environmental assistance program; incorporating sustainable practices in the business such as recycling, reducing waste and saving energy. Travel Salem's Travel Cafe and administrative office was designed with sustainability in mind; using recycled and earth-friendly materials, natural light, among other features. Last March, the Travel Cafe received an award for "Green Building Retrofit of the Year" at the 2010 Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards.

Based on its widely recognized "100 Best Companies to Work For in Oregon" project, the 100 Best Green Companies were determined by an anonymous employee survey and an independent assessment of the employers' sustainability practices. There were 503 organizations and more than 26,000 employees participating in the project. Companies must enter either the 100 Best Companies survey or the 100 Best Nonprofits survey to be eligible for the 100 Best Green ranking. Last year, Travel Salem was recognized as the 16th best small nonprofit and 21st overall to work for in Oregon. The next 100 Best Nonprofits rankings will be announced in September.

The "100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" is featured in the June "Green Issue" of Oregon Business magazine, which is out now.

title: Travel Salem Named Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon
body:
Travel Salem has been selected as a "Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" by Oregon Business magazine. The rankings were unveiled at a luncheon held at the Hilton Portland & Executive Tower on Wednesday, May 25, 2011. Travel Salem was one of only five Salem area businesses recognized and the organization's ranking went up significantly from 80th last year to 54th this year.

"We are committed to maintaining a "green company' and are thrilled to be counted as one of Oregon's most sustainable organizations," said Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem. "We're also pleased about the substantial progress we've made over last year in dramatically improving our ranking to 54th on this prestigious list. Sustainability is not only a philosophy, but it has become a way of doing business because "green' business practices matter to our customers."

Travel Salem's "Green Team," a group of employees charged with making the workplace more sustainable, led the way in developing an eco-savvy culture with buy-in to sustainable practices. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE through Marion County's business environmental assistance program, incorporating sustainable practices in the business such as recycling, reducing waste and saving energy. Travel Salem's Travel Cafe and administrative office was designed with sustainability in mind: using recycled and earth-friendly materials and features that allow for generous natural light, among other things. Two years ago, the Travel Cafe received an award for "Green Building Retrofit of the Year" at the 2010 Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards.

The 100 Best Green Companies in 2011 were selected based on Sustainable Practices sections in both employee and employer surveys completed last year by nearly 19,000 employees from 415 for-profit companies and nonprofit organizations.  The 100 Best Green Companies survey was incorporated into the 100 Best Companies and 100 Best Nonprofits surveys.

The "100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" is featured in the June "Green Issue" of Oregon Business magazine, which is now available for purchase.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Named Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work for in Oregon
body:
Travel Salem has been selected as a "Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" by Oregon Business magazine. Weighing in at number 84, Travel Salem was one of only five Salem area businesses recognized.

"We are committed to maintaining a 'green company' and are thrilled to be counted as one of Oregon's most sustainable organizations," said Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem. "Sustainability is not only a philosophy, but it has become a way of doing business because 'green' business practices matter to our customers."

Travel Salem's 'Green Team,' a group of employees charged with making the workplace more sustainable, led the way in developing an eco-savvy culture with buy-in to sustainable practices. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE through Marion County's business environmental assistance program, incorporating sustainable practices in the business such as recycling, reducing waste and saving energy. Travel Salem's Travel Cafe and administrative office was designed with sustainability in mind: using recycled and earth-friendly materials and features that allow for generous natural light, among other things.

The 100 Best Green Companies in 2012 were selected based on Sustainable Practices sections in both employee and employer surveys completed last year by nearly 20,000 employees from 431 for-profit companies and nonprofit organizations. The "100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" is featured in the June "Green Issue" of Oregon Business magazine.

Other Salem Businesses Recognized: #7 Salem Conference Center; #37 Green Acres Landscape; #41 AJ"s Auto Repair; #50 Cascade Employers Association; #64 Capital Auto Group & #84 Travel Salem.
