title: Travel Salem on the Road
body:
The Travel Salem convention and events sales staff will be covering a lot of ground in November!

Brian Chung, sports and events sales manager will be attending the TEAMS! tradeshow in Las Vegas and Debbie McCune, director of sales will be attending the Amateur Softball Association (ASA) Annual Council Meeting and Tradeshow in Reno. Both of these sales missions will be directly targeting sports events decision makers and making the pitch for them to choose the Salem, Oregon region for their next event.

At the ASA meeting and tradeshow, Travel Salem will partner with the City of Salem to bid on National softball tournaments for 2016. At the TEAMS! tradeshow, the focus will be on introducing our new sports brand "Travel Salem Sports - Absolutely Oregon" to planners we have never met before and to invite them to hold their events in the Salem region.

"This is such an exciting time for the convention and events sales department, said Debbie. "Brian and I will be gone at the same time in November to these tradeshows and the amount of people we'll have an opportunity to reach in one week will be substantial!"

Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Participates in Polk County Rural Tourism Studio
body:
A series of Polk County tourism workshops that began in November recently concluded. The workshops were led by Travel Oregon through their Rural Tourism Studio program. The program assists rural communities interested in sustainable tourism development as a way to increase high-value, authentic experiences for travelers. Tourism development efforts contribute to community livability and ultimately increases visitation, which contributes to the local economy. 

As a result of the program, five major committees were formed to focus development efforts on cycling, agri-tourism, culinary/wine, culture & heritage, and marketing. Travel Salem is taking the lead with the Marketing Committee and the Agri-tourism Committee. Work plans are currently underway with strong support from Polk County residents and the business community.

Anyone interest in rolling up their shirt sleeves and working to implement the strategic outcomes from the Polk County Rural Tourism Studio is encouraged to contact Shawn Irvine with the City of Independence (503-837-1191 or irvine.shawn@ci.independence.or.us)

Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem partners with Box Office Tickets on AbsolutelyTix
body:
Travel Salem has partnered with Box Office Tickets to bring AbsolutelyTix, a new ticketing network for Salem and Marion and Polk counties. The new AbsolutelyTix network makes it easy for local arts, non-profit, and other community organizations to promote events, sell tickets and transact other business over the Internet. It also provides a single source of online information about upcoming local shows and events.

"AbsolutelyTix furthers our mission to be a comprehensive resource for visitors through our Travel Cafe, which will now serve as a centralized ticketing outlet," said Angie Morris, President and CEO of Travel Salem. "It also gives us the opportunity to support our local nonprofit organizations and partners by providing a much-needed service for ticketing. We partnered with Box Office Tickets because of its state-of-the-art ticketing, access to services and local focus." What's more, notes Morris, five cents from each ticket sold on www.absolutelytix.com will be donated to an area non-profit organization each year.

Box Office Tickets Inc., the first ticketing company to bring Web 2.0 to local arts and cultural communities, has been empowering the event and entertainment industry through innovative services since 1993. Known for the quality of its customer service and technology, boxofficetickets.com is a national brand with proven experiences in handling all types of events - the arts, sports, business conferences, etc.

"We're pleased to partner with Travel Salem to create a local ticketing network that will help connect people to events and support the local economy," said George Domurot, President/CEO of Box Office Tickets Inc. "Our online ticketing and transaction capabilities combined with Travel Salem's marketing and visitor outreach enables local organizations to promote their events and sell tickets to a much broader audience through the network."

The AbsolutelyTix network is open to all theaters and groups with ticketing needs in Salem and Marion and Polk Counties. There are no fees for network partner organizations.
Those interested in partnering with Travel Salem in AbsolutelyTix should contact Angie Morris at 503-581-4325, ext. 26 or amorris@travelsalem.com.

title: Travel Salem project wins Merit Award for CB|2 Architects
body:
The American Institute of Architects (AIA) Salem Chapter awarded Travel Salem's Travel Cafe a merit award during the 2009 AIA Salem Design Awards banquet at the Northwest Viticulture Center on January 21, 2010.

A jury of three distinguished architectural professionals selected Travel Salem's Travel Cafe, designed and built by CB|2 Architects & Construction in Salem, for its demonstration of a consistent hand in the development and execution of an idea of reuse and renovation. The design provided a level of attention and refinement that was successful in creating a welcoming area for people to gather and obtain information about the Salem area. A kiosk area was established using existing wood columns, and the existing brick walls brought warmth and material expression to the space and also gave further reference to the existing structure. The jury further comments that the design of the "Jewel Box' glassed-in conference area feature successfully extends and unifies the space.

"The 2009 architectural design award of the Travel Salem interior, places this elegant space; one that brings historic preservation and modern design together into a seamless and well-thought out design, into the top tier of Salem and Portland architectural interiors," said Peter Strauhal, AIA Salem president-elect. "Salem is truly blessed to have such a well-crafted public space to learn more about the vibrant communities and diverse activities and attractions in the region."

Travel Salem's Travel Cafe is one of only four projects to win an award. A design-build process with CB|2 Construction allowed the project to meet the demands of a limited budget and tight schedule. The design vision was to express the character of the historic building by opening up the space and exposing brick walls and wood columns that had been concealed from past renovations in what use to be a downtown bridal shop. CB|2 Architects created a bold, progressive expression with a central reception pavilion, glass conference room, and rich material and color palette. The Travel Cafe was designed with sustainability in mind, including: use of recycled materials saved from demolition; earth-friendly options when purchasing new materials; electrical and HVAC zoning changes to conserve energy and maximize resources; and creative use of natural light to minimize energy consumption. The design creates a variety of spaces that can evolve depending on use and function. Diligent attention to details and craftsmanship was a goal, which is reflected throughout the project.

"The Travel Salem project provided an opportunity to celebrate key Salem-area sights and businesses in a prominent historic downtown location," said Garth Brandaw, principal of CB|2 Architects. "Angie Morris came to us with the vision, and we were committed to making sure it reflected the quality and character of our community."

"This award reflects and comments on Travel Salem's desire to blend the old with the new in visioning the Travel Cafe," said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. "While the project was intended to reinvent how our community could connect with the visitor through a vibrant and dynamic space, it also reflects Travel Salem's continued commitment to the tradition and history of our region. CB|2 brought extraordinary talent and vision to masterfully blend old with new and design a space that takes form and function to a whole new level."

Travel Salem's Travel Cafe is a full service visitors center aimed at connecting with visitors and consumers in new and exciting ways. This one-of-a-kind visitors center offers a wide array of services - personal assistance, event ticket sales, wine tasting, GPS rentals, free Wi-Fi - and provides the platform for innovative partnership, events, and technology to mash up and ultimately drive economic impact for the Salem region.

title: TRAVEL SALEM RANKED #10 ON THE LIST OF 100 BEST NONPROFITS TO WORK FOR IN OREGON
body:
Travel Salem has been ranked tenth on Oregon Business magazine's "100 Best Nonprofit to Work For in Oregon" list. The ranking is determined by employee questionnaires and an independent assessment. Travel Salem was one of only nine Salem businesses recognized and the organization aggressively climbed the rankings from 24th last year to 10th  this year.

Nearly 5,500 employees from 170 nonprofits and not-for-profits statewide participated in this year's survey developed by Oregon Business editor Brandon Sawyer along with research partner DHM Research and the Nonprofit Association of Oregon. Oregon Business launched this project to recognize nonprofits as key businesses critical to the economic health of the state.

Nonprofit employees who responded this year commented that they valued a work environment of trust, professionalism and care, along with opportunities for training, support and career advancement. Flexible schedules, teamwork and taking time to have fun were noted in the surveys as key components to a great workplace.

"Travel Salem has been my professional home for eight years. My first role was as an intern and over the years I have been challenged and allowed the chance to try new roles. The director team is supportive of the staff putting our families first, which means more than can be expressed. We are a close-knit group who celebrates our individual and team successes in a supportive environment where you can freely suggest new ideas. I am thrilled to be a part of such a great team of exceptional people!" said Kathie Reeves, marketing manager at Travel Salem.

The "100 Best Nonprofits to Work for in Oregon" is featured in the October issue of Oregon Business magazine, which is now available for purchase.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Ranked 21 out of 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon
body:
Travel Salem has secured the 2009 West Coast World Championship Wrestling Tournament hosted by Rocky Mountain Nationals (RMN). This event will take place at the Oregon State Fair & Expo Center on December 11-12, 2009 with nearly 1,500 K-8th grade participants from across the country hitting the mats for the first time in Salem.

Since 1999, RMN has been hosting some of the largest and most successful tournaments for young wrestlers. RMN's mission is to promote wrestling and ensure lasting rewards for youth which include: 1) Athletic rigor within a spirit of fair competition; 2) Self-discipline and perseverance through training; 3) Leadership and team-building skills; and 4) Lasting friendships and memorable experiences. Through sportsmanship and related tournament activities, Rocky Mountain Nationals encourages friendships, strengthens families and fosters good citizenship.

title: Travel Salem Ranks 37 on List of 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon
body:
Travel Salem has been selected again as one of Oregon's "Top 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon" by Oregon Business magazine. The rankings were unveiled at a sold-out event held at the Portland Art Museum on September 22, 2010. Travel Salem was recognized as the 24th best small nonprofit and 37th overall.

"Those of us who choose nonprofit careers do so for the chance to serve a cause greater than ourselves," said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. "Travel Salem attracts and retains amazing, talented staff, who bring their "A-game' and give a little bit of their heart to their job every single day. There is no question why they are some of the best in the industry."

The rankings were based on an independence assessment of employer's workplace practices and the confidential input of employees who answered 60 questions about workplace satisfaction such as benefits, management, trust, work environment and development. The criteria employees ranked as most important were: "treatment of employees by supervisors," and "pride and belief in the organization." More than 150 nonprofits participated and almost 5,000 employees completed the survey. The free, voluntary survey was calculated by research partners Davis, Hibbitts and Midghall along with a research editor at Oregon Business magazine.

The "Top 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon" is featured in the October issue of Oregon Business magazine.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Receives $7,500 from Travel Oregon to Produce an Interactive Online Map
body:
Travel Salem's proposal to produce an interactive online map was one of 10 tourism destination projects in the state to garner a portion of a $60,000 grant by Travel Oregon's Matching Grants Program. Travel Salem received $7,500 to produce an interactive map featuring cultural and heritage highlights in Marion and Polk County. Created in 1986, the annual Matching Grants Program supports new projects that improve local economies and communities by enhancing, expanding and promoting Oregon's visitor industry.

"This dynamic, colorful map will help connect visitors with some of our most prized cultural heritage attractions from one user-friendly format," said Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem. "The ultimate goal of the map is to encourage visitors to stay longer in our communities and to take full advantage of the rich cultural diversity of our region."

The Matching Grants Program selection committee, representing private and public sector organizations, selected this year's grant finalists from a pool of 29 applicants. The 10 commission-approved projects are located throughout the state and, when complete, will fulfill a range of local, regional and state needs for improved tourism capacity.

"The grant dollars provide seed money to projects that will increase Oregon destinations' visibility among potential visitors." said Carole Astley, industry relations manager at Travel Oregon. "The 10 applicants we selected are thinking about long term return-oninvestment for developing and promoting tourism in the regional areas their organizations serve."

Those interested in taking advantage of this interactive online resource to promote their attraction can contact Irene Bernards at ibernards@TravelSalem.com. "We encourage cultural and heritage nonprofits in Polk and Marion counties to leverage the dollars we've received through this grant," said Morris.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Recertified as EarthWISE business
body:
Travel Salem, the official destination marketing organization for Salem and Marion and Polk counties, is proud to have been recertified EarthWISE. Our Travel Caf_/Visitors Center in the historic Grand Hotel building was designed with sustainability in mind, including: reuse of materials saved from demolition; electrical and HVAC zoning changes to conserve energy; and creative use of natural light to reduce electrical use. 

EarthWISE is a free business environmental assistance program for Marion County businesses and non-profits.  

This unique program helps businesses with:
Recycling 
Waste reduction and prevention 
Energy efficiency and conservation 
Water pollution prevention 
Outreach and education

The program also recognizes businesses in Marion County that have made a commitment to environmentally friendly practices. Businesses that meet certain criteria in the EarthWISE focus areas may earn EarthWISE certification and will receive public recognition for their green practices.

For more information about how your business may find ways to cut waste and save money, go to: www.mcEarthWISE.net or EarthWISE@co.marion.or.us. You can also contact EarthWISE staff directly at 503 365 3188.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Recognized as Bike Friendly Business
body:
Oregon loves bicyclists - and so does Travel Salem! We are pleased to announce that the Travel Salem Travel Cafe and Visitors Center has achieved recognition in Travel Oregon's statewide Bike Friendly Business Program. 

 

Bike Friendly businesses are those that demonstrate a commitment to serving visitors who ride bikes by providing specific amenities they may need. Specific amenities offered by Travel Salem's Travel Cafe and Visitors Center include complimentary charging for personal devices (tablets and phones); free water refills; access to a public restroom and visitor information geared towards bicycle riders. 

Bicycle-related tourism contributes $400 million to Oregon's economy annually, according to a 2012 study by Dean Runyon Associates. Travel Oregon's statewide Bike Friendly Business program is the first of its kind in the nation and is designed to help Oregon businesses reach out to this quickly-growing segment of the tourism economy. 

Oregon has been a bicycle-tourism innovator since 2010, when Cycle Oregon and the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department co-created the only Scenic Bikeways program in the nation - beginning with the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway, which runs through the heart of Salem. 

In addition to providing amenities for cyclists, Travel Salem continues to offer services to help all visitors make the most of their stay including free copies of visitor guides, ideas about what to see and do in the area, complimentary Wi-Fi and ticket sales for many of the area's arts, culture and heritage events.

For more information about Travel Salem, visit www.travelsalem.com or call 503-581-4325. For more information about the Bike Friendly Business Program, go to www.industry.traveloregon.com/BFB. 

Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Scores Points with Sport Teams
body:
The Travel Salem sales team has been busy over the past month drumming up new business and hosting tournaments in the Salem metro area. Brian Chung, Sports and Events Sales Manager, attended the National Association of Sports Commissions Annual Symposium in Milwaukee, WI with over 30 prescheduled appointments with potential sports events organizers. Brian brought back 19 potential leads including the U.S. Quidditch Association, Soccer by Design, and the United States Australian Football League.

Travel Salem also secured these sport events:

The Willamette Valley Water Polo club hosted the 2015 Girls' Water Polo Pacific Northwest Zone Junior Olympic Qualifier at the Kroc Center on May 1-3, 2015. Nearly 300 athletes, accompanied by coaches and parents from Washington and Oregon, competed in Salem for the chance to participate in the Junior Olympics in Orange County, California later this summer.

On May 16-17, 2015, twelve boys' and girls' Ultimate Frisbee teams from throughout Oregon traveled to the Capital Futbol Club in Salem to compete in the Oregon State High School Championships. Nice weather and pristine field conditions greeted over 200 players, parents and coaches for the two days of competition at the complex. The winners qualified to play in the Western Regional Championship in Corvallis at the end of May.

Photo courtesy of Creative Commons

Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Scores Tournaments for Area Venues
body:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce that both the 2015 Pacific Northwest Zone Girls Water Polo Junior Olympics Qualifying Tournament and the Oregon High School Boys and Girls State Ultimate Frisbee Championship will be hosted in Salem this summer.

The 2015 Pacific Northwest Zone Girls Water Polo Junior Olympics Qualifying Tournament will be held on May 1-3 at the Salvation Army Ray and Joan Kroc Corps Community Center. Hosting the tournament in Salem reflects the 16% growth rate of Water Polo in the Pacific Northwest. The tournament will be hosted by the Willamette Valley Water Polo Club, which is one of the largest Water Polo clubs in the state of Oregon and is comprised of players from all over the Willamette Valley.

Another first for the city of Salem will occur May 16-17 when the city proudly hosts the Oregon High School State Ultimate Frisbee Championships at the Capital Futbol Club. Currently, six boys' teams and four girls' teams from different parts of the state are expected to attend the tournament, including Portland, Eugene and Corvallis. Salem is eager to host its first ever USA Ultimate Frisbee Tournament and hopes that more teams will enter to play for the state championships.

For more information on tournament hosting, please contact Brian Chung at 503-581-4325, ext 159 or email at bchung@TravelSalem.com.

Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem Seeks Story Ideas
body:
Give us your best pitch! Once again, Travel Salem invites representatives from area businesses and organizations to share your best ideas for our "content library" that we can use for potential pitches to the media or for use in blogs, social media posts or other publications.  This year's Speed Pitching open house will occur on Wednesday, May 21. Anyone representing a Marion or Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. and share what's new and newsworthy at your organization.

What constitutes a "newsworthy" pitch? Basically, we're looking for ideas that are unusual, innovative and timely. If your organization or business has recently launched - or is planning to launch - a new product, service, event, or program that is unique and of interest to a large audience (especially visitors), we want to hear about it.

Here's how it works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Travel Salem Travel Cafe & Visitors Center (located at 181 High St. NE in Salem) any time between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. on Wednesday, May 21.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 15 minutes (maximum) to share their news with a member of Travel Salem's marketing staff.
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it needs to occur in late 2014 or 2015. (Most of the regional and national publications we target request information 3-4 months in advance).

You're welcome to bring a short, one-page summary of your pitch or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).

While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published.

If you cannot attend Speed Pitching, but would like to submit an idea, email it to kkuh@travelsalem.com. We look forward to hearing all of your creative ideas!

Back to newsletter

These award recipients are movers and shakers who have pushed the envelope and turned ideas upside-down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaboration, partnerships, innovation and regional strategies! title: Travel Salem's PR is reaching new heights!
body:
During the first four months of fiscal year 2011-12 Travel Salem's PR efforts have secured $1.2 million in earned media coverage (a.k.a. media leverage), already exceeding the earned media secured over FY 2010-11. In FY 2010-11 Travel Salem's earned media was up 63 percent over FY 2009-10. Some of the successful media pitches that Travel Salem secured included coverage of the Salem region in the travel section of The NY Times; a prime-time broadcast on the Food Network (Outrageous Food); Oregon broadcast on Grant's Getaways; in Woman's World, NW Palate, 1895 magazine, Sunset, The Seattle Times, and The Bulletin (Bend) among many others.

Travel Salem hosted press trips for foreign and domestic writers, including as far away as Korea and pitched hundred of story ideas to both travel and industry publications.

Travel Salem would like to thank all of the many partners involved in the press trips and for the products contributed to host these successful promotions! We will continue to aggressively promote our region so keep the amazing story ideas flowing our way.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Travel Salem's Travel Cafe wins Green Building of the Year
body:
Travel Salem's Travel Cafe was recently named Green Building Retrofit of the Year at the 2010 Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards ceremony held at Willamette University. The awards were put on by the Friends of Straub Environmental Learning Center.

The award recognizes outstanding efforts and leadership in green building practices. A green building is one that focuses on resource efficiency - energy, water, and materials - while reducing building impacts on human health and the environment through better siting, design, construction, operation, maintenance, and materials removal.

The Travel Cafe was ddesigned and constructed by CB|2 Architects & Construction (winners of an architectural design award in January for the design of the Travel Cafe), dadnddd dhas green all over its blueprint:

" recycled materials saved from demolition were used
" when purchasing new materials, earth-friendly options were chosen
" electrical and various heating, ventilating and air conditioning zoning changes were made  to conserve energy and maximize resources
" creative use of natural light were incorporated in the design to minimize energy consumption.

In addition to the sustainable features of the Travel Cafe, Travel Salem's staff and volunteers take great strides in reducing our carbon footprint. As a Marion County EarthWISE Certified business, we do our part by recycling, reducing waste, purchasing environmentally-friendly products, and the little things such as flipping the light switch off when not in the office for an extending period of time and turning off computer monitors at night.

You know how Kermit the Frog says "It's not easy being green?" To be green, in other words, to be sustainable, is actually quite easy. It just takes a little bit of effort, which will eventually go a long way in protecting the environment and the planet we live on. If you're a business located in Marion County, the free EarthWISE certification program is a great way for your business and employees to be environmentally friendly. Visit Marion County's website for more information on how your business can be EarthWISE certified.

Photo caption: Kathie Reeves, marketing and online manager, represented Travel Salem at the Green Awards on March 13, 2010.

title: Travel: It's Not Just for Vacation Anymore
body:
For most of us, "travel" invokes ideas boarding a plane or cruise ship, or maybe loading a cooler, tent and the family dog into the back of a minivan. But lately, a picture has emerged of travel as a health regimen-for our bodies and minds, our family relationships and our country's economy.

Take, for instance, jobs. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that the U.S. travel industry recovered faster than other economic sectors. Since losing close to half a million jobs in the Great Recession, the travel industry has added 697,000 jobs and has outpaced job creation by the rest of the economy by 49 percent.

But unless you work for the airlines or own a hotel, does the travel rebound mean much to the average American? The answer is a resounding yes.

Travel is among the top 10 employers in 49 states, directly employing about eight million people at a payroll of $209 billion. Throw in jobs supported by travel and the number almost doubles to 15 million workers: one of every nine American jobs.

In Oregon, travel and tourism generates $9.6 billion and directly supports nearly 94,000 jobs. In the Salem area, the industry generates $537.2 in economic impact and supports 6,110 jobs.   

But travel doesn't just grow our economy and boost our productivity; it also connects us as people, keeps us healthy and makes us happy. People who travel are less stressed and happier at work. Eight in 10 seniors say travel makes them feel energized. And our travel memories stay with us: studies show that into our 50s and beyond, we remember childhood trips more vividly than birthday parties or other special occasions.

So, as we celebrate National Travel & Tourism Month this May, please take a few minutes to think about how you can support and encourage travel - perhaps as an employer, as a leader in your community or even just for you and your family. It's worth our investment, and the travel effect pays us back in spades.

Back to newsletter

title: TravelSalem.com Has A Beautiful New Look!
body:
TravelSalem.com has been redesigned! The new and improved website allows visitors to access our highest traffic pages resulting in longer visits! Rotating images on the home page captivate and encourage traveling to the Salem region.

Take a look at the new website, engage with us and, as always, send us your feedback. Please direct questions or comments to Kathie Reeves, marketing manager at 503-581-4325 ext. 24 or kreeves@TravelSalem.com.

By staying connected with Travel Salem, you will be one of the first to see our new Interactive Online Map that will launch in August! Travel Salem is always enhancing the visitors experience through innovative strategies in which you can engage.

  • Back to newsletter

title: TravelSalem.com Offering Free Online Business Listings
body:
Travel Salem is offering a free listing to businesses within the Salem city limits on their TravelSalem.com website. Travel Salem is a non-profit organization that promotes Salem and Marion and Polk counties for leisure tourism and convention and event business. The TravelSalem.com website is the official tourism and meeting website for Salem and had 250,000 visits to the site during 2007-08.

Businesses interested in a free listing and fit the Association's criteria (within the city limits of Salem, and no political, religious, pornographic or personal content) can go to www.TravelSalem.com to self-submit listing information.

Questions regarding this service can be directed to Kathie Reeves, Travel Salem's Marketing & Online Manager, 503-581-4325 ext. 24 or kreeves@travelsalem.com.

Mon.- Thur. 10 a.m.-10 p.m.; Fri.-Sun. 10 a.m.-11 p.m. 
Fun loves company at the 2014 Oregon State Fair. Come see the State's best in big name entertainment, animals, arts and exhibits -- all for a BIG value. Tickets: Adults $8 (12 and up)... Presale $6; Kids $6 (6 to 11) ... Presale $5; Seniors $6 (62 and up)"_ Presale $5.

2330 17th St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-947-3247 or 1-800-833-0011

Exhibition: John J. Audubon ~ Birds of America
Aug. 29- Nov. 22
Gallery hours: Tues.-Sat. 10 a.m.-5 p.m.; Sun. 1-5 p.m.; Closed Mondays.
John James Audubon (1785-1851) was a French-American painter, ornithologist and naturalist. His major work, "The Birds of America," is considered one of the finest ornithological books ever published. The exhibition features 30 prints from Audubon's Royal Octavo Edition. Admission: Adults $6; Senior 55+ $4; Students 18+ w/ID $3; Youth 17 & under free; Tues. free for everyone.
Hallie Ford Museum of Art
700 State St.
Salem, OR 97301
503-370-6855
www.willamette.edu/arts/hfma/index.html

title: Visitor Intercept Survey
body:
Travel Salem recently launched a Visitor Intercept Survey that asks visitors a few brief questions about their visit. The findings from the survey will ultimately help guide Travel Salem's future strategies and assist with return on investment reporting.

All visitors that take the survey will be entered into a prize drawing for a Salem area travel package. All employees asking visitors to complete the survey will also be entered into a prize drawing. Both prize drawings will take place in November 2012. The more surveys turned into Travel Salem, the greater chance for your employees to win.

If you would like to help Travel Salem with this survey project please contact Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

  • Return to newsletter

title: Volunteers Needed for  NAIA Golf Championships
body:
Be sure you stand out and reach more visitors by showcasing your business on a kiosk panel in the Travel Salem Travel Cafe Visitors Center. One of these 22" x 36" or 22" x 30" panels can be yours, or you can co-op the panel with other businesses. This offer includes space for your company brochure.

There are a limited number of panels so act quickly to reserve your panel today! Travel Salem is offering an introductory price of $100/month for the panel plus the cost of design (12 month minimum commitment).

The Travel Salem Travel Cafe is a full-service Visitors Center offering a wide array of services, where a professional staff person will customize each visitor's Salem area experience.

For more information, contact Tina Winge at 503-581-4325 ext. 59 or membership@TravelSalem.com.

  • Return to newsletter

title: Volunteers Needed for Greeters Program
body:
Become a Salem Greeter and Meet Visitors from Around the World

Do you love Salem and want to share your passion with visitors? Do you consider yourself a natural entertainer with knowledge of interesting, little-known historical facts? Then consider becoming a Salem Greeter and be part of a prestigious international group of volunteer guides affiliated with the Global Greeter Network.

Greeters are volunteers who take individual tourists and small groups of 6 or less on informal, unscripted tours around the city's most iconic places and share their personal perspectives for a truly authentic Salem experience. 

Greeters are part of a global sustainable tourism effort and make visitors feel welcome, comfortable and excited about our city. If you are interested in becoming part of the Salem Greeter program, please contact lgomez@travelsalem.com.

Photo: Eco-Earth Globe ~ Salem's Riverfront Park ~ Photo by Ron Cooper
Back to newsletter

title: Vote for Willamette Valley wine region!
body: The Willamette Valley has been nominated by Budget Travel magazine for a Readers' Choice Award under the category "Most Beautiful Wine Region in the World." Take a minute to cast your vote! Scroll down to the category under the "Destinations" heading and cast your vote to help push the Willamette Valley to the top.

title: Wanted: Your Used Storage Shelves or Filing Cabinets!
body:
Donate your old storage shelves or filing cabinets to Travel Salem who plans to put them to good use!  The shelves don't need to be fancy or even match, but just sturdy with the ability to hold weight.  Contact Debbie McCune, Travel Salem's director of sales, at 503-581-4325 ext. 28 or dmccune@TravelSalem.com to schedule a time to drop them off.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Ways to Bloom in Winter
body:
On cold January days that require bundling up, don't forget we're on the downswing of winter. The Winter Solstice has come and gone, which means we're headed for longer days and more exposure to direct sunlight. Keep this in mind when deciding whether to stay in hibernation or wake up! I suggest waking up! Open your front door to a little fresh wintry air and find ways to bloom in the midst of winter, there are so many things to do in our region! Follow the lead of the Helleborus or Christmas Flower who blooms this month in shades like black, wine and berry. Go to The Oregon Garden to visit her and other winter-blooming flowers like red Camelias or the tropical-smelling Daphne Odora. It's the quieter off-season at The Oregon Garden and the animals know it. This month your companions will be deer, Cedar waxwings, palliated woodpeckers and a rare green heron who comes to soak up the peace - and also eat bullfrogs.

Be like the wildlife and find places where you'll be away from the crowds. Be the only cyclist at Minto-Brown Island Park on a clear day or take a horseback ride through Santiam State Forest with Into the Wild Equine Adventures who offer three-hour to one-day rides and are currently offering  a special of buy one ride package and get one for a companion free through May 31, 2011. When there's wind out, unfurl a kite into the sky at Salem's Riverfront Park.

Valentine's Day is around the corner, create a hand-made card for your loved one at Historic Deepwood Estate's Valentine's Day card making class on Feb 7th from 1 to 3 p.m. Or power-up your intellect by attending Deepwood's free Heritage Talks- start with the American Character discussion on Feb. 9th.

Invite your northern friends to migrate south for the winter - down to our region! Pick up a two-for-one Amtrak Cascades voucher at our Travel Caf_ on 181 High Street NE and share it with those northerners who want to bypass the hassle of driving (the Amtrak route also offers WiFi). Your guests can hop on the Amtrak in Vancouver, Canada or in Seattle or Portland and come play in Salem for the weekend!

Or simply declare your last work day: Flower Friday and buy blooms for your office, or order summery local jams from Fresh to You, a company that will also come to your home and help you spruce up your winter-weary yard with landscaping tips. There's so much to explore, go ahead and let go of that urge to hibernate! Wake up instead! Today is one day closer to spring than yesterday! Happy blooming!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 1/23/11

title: Welcome New and Renewing Members
body:
For thirty years, local businesses and attractions have enjoyed the many benefits Travel Salem offers industry partners as this region's destination marketing organization. Members have the advantage of personal and professional marketing tools and resources available through Travel Salem. Our bi-monthly Marketing Exchange (ME) Luncheons are one on-going example of excellent membership support. Join us for the next ME Luncheon and network among peers while gaining industry insights from dynamic speakers.

Check out our newest list of Current & Renewing Members. If you know of a business that is interested in partnering to promote the region's lucrative $511 million industry that employs 6,290 people, please contact Sue Nichols, Travel Salem's community development director at 503-581-4325, ext. 22 or snichols@TravelSalem.com.

title: What the Heck is Social Media? Learn for Free!
body:
Are you curious about engaging with consumers and building relationships with them through social media tools such as Twitter and Facebook? Do you want more results out of the time you put into social media? Come to one of Travel Salem's FREE interactive social media seminars and learn about the social networking tools that are changing the way businesses and organizations connect with consumers, and strategies on how to effectively utilize these tools.

Based on proficiency, participants have the option of attending one or both of these one and a half hour seminars. The novice seminars will focus on the introduction to each social media platform. This includes Twitter, Facebook, Flickr, YouTube, and blogs. An in-depth look of each platform - including instruction on signing up, usage, etiquette and more - will be discussed in this novice, interactive seminar. This seminar is targeted at participants who are thinking about doing social media for their company/organization and those who are in the beginning stages and want to learn more about social media.

For the advance user, the seminars will focus on the proven strategies that have effectively increased relationships among businesses/organizations and their consumers. We'll be taking an in-depth look at case studies and discuss how to utilize each platform in synergy to achieve your overall goal. This seminar is targeted at participants who are looking to establish a stronger social media presence in the online community.

Dates and times to choose from:

Monday, Nov. 16 (at the Travel Cafe)
1pm-2:30pm: Novice
3pm-4:30pm: Advance

Tuesday, Nov. 17 (Travel Cafe)
9am-10:30am: Novice
11am-12:30pm: Advance

Wednesday, Nov. 18 (Travel Cafe)
9:30am-11am: Novice
11:30am-1pm: Advance

Thursday, Nov. 19 (at Mission Mill Museum after the Luncheon)
1:45pm-3:15pm: Novice/Advance Combine

There is no fee to attend these seminars which will take place at Travel Salem's Travel Cafe (181 High St. NE, Salem) in the Willamette Room (except for the November 19 session which will take place at Mission Mill right after the Marketing Exchange Luncheon). Participants may bring a laptop to engage in this immersive experience. Free Wi-Fi is offered at the Travel Cafe. Participants are encouraged to come prepared with questions. Space is limited. Contact Anthony Tham to reserve your spot at atham@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 25.

Contribute to Travel Salem's "Absolutely Giving Back" program by contributing a canned item, non-perishable foods, or new or gently used clean child's winter coat.

title: Wild Pear Restaurant, E.Z. Orchards Farm Market & Travel Salem Represent Willamette Valley at Feast Portland
body:
Oregon's world-class celebration of food and drink called "Feast Portland" took place September 20-23, 2012 downtown Portland. Feast was held in Pioneer Courthouse Square and held events like the Sandwich Invitational, an Asian-inspired night market, high profile chef demonstrations, conversations with food thought leaders and a whole lot of eating and drinking.

While Portland was the center of this festival Salem was offered the opportunity to shine and represent the Willamette Valley at the Travel Oregon~Oregon Bounty Grand Tasting Tent - Saturday, September 22. Celebrated Salem chef Jeff James, represented the Wild Pear Restaurant, highlighting a 5-spiced cured Carlton Farms pork belly with E.Z. Orchards hard cider glaze, pears dipped in a Gouda cheese and maple syrup dip rolled in hazelnuts using the freshest local ingredients. Chef James along with, sisters and co-owners of the Wild Pear Restaurant, Cecelia and Jessica Ritter were on hand to talk to event goers and promote the agricultural bounty of the Willamette Valley and the Wild Pear. Kevin Zielinski with E.Z. Orchards Farm Market was serving tastes of their hard cidre and sharing information about their traditional French method of fermentation. Travel Salem representatives, Irene Bernards and Debbie McCune were greeting event attendees and promoting Salem's culinary scene as well as the amenities of the mid-Willamette Valley.

"Oregon is a true cornucopia and the Willamette Valley is the corner stone of Oregon's bountiful harvests," said Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director for Travel Salem. "Marion County is Oregon's number one agricultural producing county and we had the opportunity to showcase the delicious offerings of the region and how local chefs partner with farmers and unify agricultural assets into culinary delights. We want visitors and Oregon residents to realize the foodie opportunities of our area," said Bernards.

Travel Salem approached the Wild Pear Restaurant about representing the Willamette Valley due to their commitment to local, seasonal and organic ingredients and how they use these ingredients in familiar and unexpected ways, whenever possible.

 "We are honored to have represented the Willamette Valley at the Oregon Bounty Grand Tasting Tent," said Cecilia and Jessica, Wild Pear Co-Owners.  "We are extremely fortunate to have Chef, Jeff James represent the Wild Pear and our mid-Willamette Valley region. Chef James has been a guest chef at the James Beard House in New York and also selected for L'Ecole des Chefs in Lyon, France and the Oregon Bounty tour for the United States Department of Agriculture in Japan. Chef James' culinary culture and talents has paired well with our company where he has spent the last two years. With a diverse ethnic background of European and Asian descent, we embrace the flavors and styles of many cultures. Our food is best described as New American, which reflects the bold, bright and fresh flavors of our region and the world. We work with local farmers and purveyors to use product that is locally sourced, seasonal, and organic as much as possible," said Cecilia Ritter.

  • Back to newsletter

title: Willamette Heritage Center adds to the depth of Salem's history and historic resources
body:
Last September, Mission Mill Museum and the Marion County Historical Society announced the two groups would be merging to form a unique partnership, which became a reality January 1, 2010 with the creation of the Willamette Heritage Center.

The fusion of Mission Mill and Marion County Historical Society strengthens the attractiveness of both organizations and further enhances our region's clout as a major heritage destination. The Willamette Heritage Center will provide enrichment to the region's culture, history, artifact collection, interpretation, preservation and overall education of our community. It opens doors to new opportunities and programs - such as a potential national heritage area designation for the Willamette Valley, and an opportunity to gain accreditation from the American Association of Museums, which in turn would strengthen support for future tours and exhibits.

According to Travel Salem's Visitor Profile study conducted by Dean Runyan Associates, 41 percent of all Salem area visitors are very satisfied with the historic attractions; and visiting a historic attraction is one of the top three activities that visitors enjoy while in the region. Travel Salem works to promote Salem as a heritage destination because cultural and heritage visitors are also interested in wine, outdoor recreation and a variety of interests that can be found in abundance in the Salem area.

Visitors are looking for an experience - a meaningful and authentic experience. Salem's historic attractions have done a wonderful job of creating that kind of experience for visitors through living history, exhibits, holiday lights, teas, wine dinners, concerts, education and special events. Blending the gems of history with all of the attractions of the region make the Salem area a vibrant and sought after destination.

The creativity and forward thinking of and the collaborative initiative is a perfect example of Salem's pioneering spirit, and illustrates what can be accomplished with innovation and a united vision. Travel Salem salutes our historic partners and the new Willamette Heritage Center!

~ Angie Morris, President and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 1/31/10

title: Willamette Valley Marketing Plan Input
body:
As part of Travel Oregon's Regional Cooperative Marketing Plan (RCMP), Travel Salem and its regional partners in Yamhill, Clackamas, Linn, Benton and Lane counties are beginning the process of updating the Oregon Wine Country (Willamette Valley) regional plan for FY 12-13.

To review the current plan, go to: industry.traveloregon.com and click on Willamette Valley.

If you have questions regarding the plan, please contact Irene Bernards, Travel Salem's Marketing & PR Director at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

title: Willamette Valley Visitors Association Elects Irene Bernards as Board President
body:
Travel Salem's Convention and Tourism programs meet regularly with Salem area marketing and sales representatives to discuss marketing partnerships, opportunities and cooperative efforts.

The next Team Salem meeting will be at The Oregon Garden (879 W Main St., Silverton) on Thursday, August 20 from 12 p.m. - 1:30 p.m. The meeting will be held in the Natural Resources Education Center, located to the right of the main entrance and the visitors center.

Bring your own lunch or purchase lunch items in the visitors center at The Oregon Garden. We have had lots of activity in Salem this summer and a lot more to share that will benefit your business.

If you plan on attending, please RSVP to Christine Edick at cedick@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 58 by Monday, August 17. We'll see you there!
